"[613-your uncle] CHAPTER V DEPARTURE OF [BATHSHEBA]243-bathsheba - A PASTORAL TRAGEDY THE news which one day reached [Gabriel]144-gabriel , that [Bath- sheba Everdene]168-bath- sheba had left [the neighbourhood]615-the neighbourhood , had an influence upon [him]144-gabriel which might have surprised any who never suspected that the more emphatic the renun- ciation the less absolute its character . It may have been observed that there is no regula path for getting out of love as there is for getting in . [Some people]3481-some people look upon marriage as a short cut that way , but it has been known to fail . Separation , which was the means that chance offered to [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel by [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's disappearance though effectual with [people of certain humours]617-people of certain humours is apt to idealise the removed object with [others]618-others - notably those whose affection , placid and regular as it may be flows deep and long . [Oak]144-gabriel belonged to [the even - tempered order of humanity]619-the even - tempered order of humanity , and felt the secret fusion of [himself]144-gabriel in [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba to be burning with a finer flame now that [she]168-bath- sheba was gone - that was all . [His]144-gabriel incipient friendship with [[her]168-bath- sheba aunt]620-her aunt - had been nipped by the failure of [his]144-gabriel suit , and all that [Oak]144-gabriel learnt of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's movements was done indirectly . It ap- peared that [she]168-bath- sheba had gone to [a place called [Weatherbury]196-joseph]621-a place called weatherbury , more than twenty miles off , but in what capacity - whether as [a visitor]3619-a visitor , or permanently , [he]144-gabriel could not discover . [Gabriel]144-gabriel had two dogs . [George]166-george , [the elder]623-the elder , exhibited an ebony - tipped nose , surrounded by a narrow margin of pink flesh , and a coat marked in random splotches approximating in colour to white and slaty grey ; but the grey , after years of sun and rain , had been scorched and washed out of the more prominent locks , leaving them of a reddish - brown , as if the blue component of the grey had faded , like the indigo from the same kind of colour in [Turner]169-turner 's pictures . In substance it had originally been hair , but long contact with sheep seemed to be turning it by degrees into wool of a poor quality and staple . This dog had originally belonged to [a shepherd of inferior morals and dreadful temper]624-a shepherd of inferior morals and dreadful temper , and the result was that [George]166-george knew the exact degrees of condemnation signified by cursing and swearing of all descriptions better than [the wickedest old man in the neighbourhood]625-the wickedest old man in the neighbourhood . Long experience had so precisely taught the animal the difference between such exclamations as " Come in ! "[166-george] and " D - - [ye]3663-ye , come in ! "[166-george] that [he]166-george knew to a hair 's breadth the rate of trotting back from the ewes ' tails that each call involved , if [a staggerer with the sheep crook]626-a staggerer with the sheep crook was to be escaped . Though old , [he]166-george was clever and trustworthy still . [The young dog]627-the young dog , [[George]166-george 's son]628-george 's son , might possibly have been the image of [[his]627-the young dog mother]629-his mother , for there was not much resemblance between [him]627-the young dog and [George]166-george . [He]627-the young dog was learn- ing the sheep - keeping business , so as to follow on at the flock when the other should die , but had got no further than the rudiments as yet - still finding an insuperable difficulty in distinguishing between doing a thing well enough and doing it too well . So earnest and yet so wrong - headed was this young dog [he]166-george had no , name in particular , and answered with perfect readiness to any pleasant interjection , that if sent behind the flock to help [them]630-them on , [he]627-the young dog did it so thoroughly that [he]627-the young dog would have chased [them]630-them across [the whole county]631-the whole county with the greatest pleasure if not called off or reminded when to step by the example of [old George]166-george . Thus much for the dogs . On [the further side of [Norcombe Hill]1-norcombe hill]632-the further side of norcombe hill was [a chalk - pit , from which chalk had been drawn for generations]633-a chalk - pit , from which chalk had been drawn for generations , and spread over [adjacent farms]634-adjacent farms . Two hedges converged upon [it]633-a chalk - pit , from which chalk had been drawn for generations in the form of a V , but without quite meeting . The narrow opening left , which was immediately over [the brow of [the pit]636-the pit]635-the brow of the pit , was protected by a rough railing . One night , when [Farmer Oak]143-farmer oak had returned to , [[his]143-farmer oak house]637-his house , believing there would be no further necessity for [his]143-farmer oak attendance on the down , [he]143-farmer oak called as usual to the dogs , previously to shutting [them]630-them up in [the outhouse]638-the outhouse till next morning . Only one responded - [old George]166-george ; the other - could not be found , either in [the house]552-the house , [lane]640-lane , or [garden]641-garden . - [Gabriel]144-gabriel then remembered that [he]144-gabriel had left the two dogs on [the hill]3452-the hill eating a dead lamb a kind of meat [he]144-gabriel usually kept from [them]630-them , except when other food - ran finished [his]144-gabriel meal , [he]144-gabriel went indoors to the luxury of a bed , which latterly [he]144-gabriel had only enjoyed on Sundays . It was a still , moist night . Just before dawn [he]144-gabriel was assisted in waking by the abnormal reverberation of familiar music . To [the shepherd]528-the shepherd , the note of [the sheep]644-the sheep " chronic sound that only makes itself noticed by ceasing ever distant , that all is well in the fold . In the solemn This exceptional ringing may be caused in two ways - by the rapid feeding of the sheep bearing the bell , as when the flock breaks into new pasture , which gives [it]644-the sheep an intermittent rapidity , or by the sheep starting off in a run , when the sound has a regular palpitation . The experienced ear of [Oak]144-gabriel knew the sound [he]143-farmer oak now heard to be caused by the running of the flock with great velocity . [He]143-farmer oak jumped out of bed , dressed , tore down [the lane]3664-the lane through a foggy dawn , and ascended [the hill]3452-the hill . [The forward ewes]3666-the forward ewes were kept apart from [those among which the fall of lambs]3667-those among which the fall of lambs would be later , there being [two hundred of the latter class in [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's flock]3668-two hundred of the latter class in gabriel 's flock . These two hundred seemed to have absolutely vanished from [the hill]3452-the hill . There were the fifty with [their]3668-two hundred of the latter class in gabriel 's flock lambs , enclosed at the other end as [he]144-gabriel had left [them]3668-two hundred of the latter class in gabriel 's flock , but the rest , forming [the bulk of the flock]3670-the bulk of the flock , were nowhere . [Gabriel]144-gabriel called at the top of [his]144-gabriel voice [the shepherd]528-the shepherd 's call . "[644-the sheep] Ovey , ovey , ovey ! " Not a single bleat . [He]143-farmer oak went to the hedge - a gap had been broken through it , and in the gap were the footprints of the sheep . Rather surprised to find [them]644-the sheep break fence at this season , yet putting it down instantly to [their]644-the sheep great fondness for ivy in winter - time , of which a great deal grew in [the plantation]3480-the plantation , [he]143-farmer oak followed through the hedge . [They]644-the sheep were not in [the plantation]3480-the plantation . [He]143-farmer oak called again : [the valleys and farthest hills]3674-the valleys and farthest hills resounded as when [the sailors]3675-the sailors invoked [the lost Hylas on [the Mysian shore]3677-the mysian shore]3676-the lost hylas on the mysian shore ; but [no sheep]3678-no sheep . [He]143-farmer oak passed through the trees and along [the ridge of [the hill]3452-the hill]3679-the ridge of the hill . On the extreme summit , where the ends of the two converging hedges of which [we]3681-we have spoken were stopped short by meeting the brow of [the chalk - pit]3682-the chalk - pit , [he]143-farmer oak saw the younger dog standing against the sky - dark and motionless as [Napoleon]170-napoleon at [St. Helena]17-st. helena . A horrible conviction darted through [Oak]144-gabriel . With a sensation of bodily faintness [he]143-farmer oak advanced : at one point the rails were broken through , and there [he]143-farmer oak saw the footprints of [his]143-farmer oak ewes . The dog came up , licked [his]143-farmer oak hand , and made signs implying that [he]143-farmer oak expected some great reward for signal services rendered . [Oak]144-gabriel looked over [the precipice]3683-the precipice . The ewes lay dead and dying at its foot - a heap of two hundred mangled carcasses , representing in [their]3684-their condition just now at least two hundred more . [Oak]144-gabriel was [an intensely humane man]3685-an intensely humane man : indeed , [his]144-gabriel humanity often tore in pieces any politic intentions of [his]144-gabriel which bordered on strategy , and carried [him]144-gabriel on as by gravitation . A shadow in [his]144-gabriel life had always been that [his]144-gabriel flock ended in mutton - that a day came and found [every shepherd]3686-every shepherd [an arrant traitor to [his]144-gabriel defenseless sheep]3687-an arrant traitor to his defenseless sheep . [His]144-gabriel first feeling now was one of pity for the untimely fate of these gentle ewes and [their]3684-their unborn lambs . It was a second to remember another phase of the matter . The sheep were not insured . All the savings of a frugal life had been dispersed at a blow ; [his]144-gabriel hopes of being [an independent farmer]3688-an independent farmer were laid low - possibly for ever . [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's energies , patience , and industry had been so severely taxed during the years of [his]144-gabriel life between eighteen and eight - and - twenty , to reach [his]144-gabriel present stage of progress that no more seemed to be left in [him]144-gabriel . [He]144-gabriel hands . Stupors , however , do not last for ever , and [Farmer Oak]143-farmer oak recovered from [his]144-gabriel . It was as remarkable as it was characteristic that the one sentence [he]144-gabriel uttered was in thankfulness : - "[644-the sheep] Thank [God]171-god [I]0-i am not married : what would [she]645-she have done in the poverty now coming upon [me]0-i ! " [Oak]144-gabriel raised [his]144-gabriel head , and wondering what [he]144-gabriel could do listlessly surveyed the scene . By the outer margin of [the Pit]636-the pit was [an oval pond]3690-an oval pond , and over [it]3690-an oval pond hung the attenuated skeleton of a chrome - yellow moon which had only a few days to last - the morning star dogging [her]645-she on the left hand . [The pool]3691-the pool glittered like [a dead man]3692-a dead man 's eye , and as [the world]447-the world awoke a breeze blew , shaking and elongating the reflection of the moon without breaking it , and turning the image of the star to a phosphoric streak upon [the water]3694-the water . All this [Oak]144-gabriel saw and remembered . As far as could be learnt it appeared that the poor young dog , still under the impression that since [he]144-gabriel was kept for running after [sheep]3695-sheep , the more [he]144-gabriel ran after [them]3695-sheep the better , had at the end of [his]144-gabriel meal off the dead lamb , which may have given [him]144-gabriel additional energy and spirits , collected all the ewes into a corner , driven the timid creatures through the hedge , across [the upper field]3696-the upper field , and by main force of worrying had given [them]3695-sheep momentum enough to break down a portion of the rotten railing , and so hurled [them]3695-sheep over the edge . [[George]166-george 's son]628-george 's son had done [his]628-george 's son work so thoroughly that [he]628-george 's son was considered too good [a workman]3698-a workman to live , and was , in fact , taken and tragically shot at twelve o'clock that same day - another instance of the untoward fate which so often attends dogs and [other philosophers who follow out a train of reasoning to its logical conclusion]3699-other philosophers who follow out a train of reasoning to its logical conclusion , and attempt perfectly consistent conduct in a world made up so largely of compromise . [[Gabriel]144-gabriel 's farm]3700-gabriel 's farm had been stocked by [a dealer]3701-a dealer - on the strength of [Oak]144-gabriel 's promising look and character - who was receiving a percentage from [the farmer]3540-the farmer till such time as the advance should be cleared off [Oak]144-gabriel found- that the value of stock , plant , and implements which were really [his]144-gabriel own would be about sufficient to pay [his]144-gabriel debts , leaving [himself]144-gabriel [a free man]3703-a free man with the clothes [he]144-gabriel stood up in , and nothing more . CHAPTER VI THE FAIR - THE JOURNEY - THE FIRE TWO months passed away . [We]3704-we are brought on to a day in February , on which was held the yearly statute or hiring fair in [the county - town of Casterbridge]3705-the county - town of casterbridge . At one end of [the street]3706-the street stood from two to [three hundred blithe and hearty labourers]3707-three hundred blithe and hearty labourers waiting upon [Chance]172-chance - [all men of the stamp to whom labour suggests nothing worse than a wrestle with gravitation , and pleasure nothing better than a renunciation of the same among these]3708-all men of the stamp to whom labour suggests nothing worse than a wrestle with gravitation , and pleasure nothing better than a renunciation of the same among these , [carters and waggoners]3709-carters and waggoners were distinguished by having a piece of whip - cord twisted round [their]3709-carters and waggoners hats ; [thatchers]3710-thatchers wore a fragment of woven straw ; [shepherds]3711-shepherds held [their]3711-shepherds sheep - crooks in [their]3711-shepherds hands ; and thus the situation required was known to [the hirers]3712-the hirers at a glance . In [the crowd]3713-the crowd was [an athletic young fellow of some- what superior appearance to the rest]3714-an athletic young fellow of some- what superior appearance to the rest - in fact , [his]3714-an athletic young fellow of some- what superior appearance to the rest superiority was marked enough to lead [several ruddy peasants standing by]3715-several ruddy peasants standing by to speak to [him]3714-an athletic young fellow of some- what superior appearance to the rest inquiringly , as to [a farmer]3716-a farmer , and to use ` [Sir]3717-sir ' as a finishing word . [His]3714-an athletic young fellow of some- what superior appearance to the rest answer always was , "[645-she] [I]0-i am looking for a place [myself]0-i - [a bailiff]532-a bailiff 's . Do [Ye]647-ye know of [anybody who wants one]648-anybody who wants one ? " [Gabriel]144-gabriel was paler now . [His]144-gabriel eyes were more medi- tative , and [his]144-gabriel expression was more sad . [He]144-gabriel had passed through an ordeal of wretchedness which had given [him]144-gabriel more than it had taken away . [He]144-gabriel had sunk from [his]144-gabriel modest elevation as [pastoral king]3718-pastoral king into [the very slime - pits of [Siddim]173-siddim]3719-the very slime - pits of siddim ; but there was left to [him]144-gabriel a digni- fied calm [he]144-gabriel had never before known , and that indiffer- ence to fate which , though it often makes a villain of [a man]3474-a man , is the basis of [his]3474-a man sublimity when it does not . And thus the abasement had been exaltation , and the loss gain . In the morning [a regiment of cavalry]3721-a regiment of cavalry had left [the town]3722-the town , and [a sergeant]3723-a sergeant and [[his]3723-a sergeant party]3724-his party had been beating up for [recruits]3725-recruits through [the four streets]3726-the four streets . As the end of the day drew on , and [he]144-gabriel found [himself]144-gabriel not hired , [Gabriel]144-gabriel almost wished that [he]144-gabriel had joined [them]3721-a regiment of cavalry , and gone off to serve [[his]144-gabriel country]3727-his country . Weary of standing in [the market- place]3728-the market- place , and not much minding the kind of work [he]144-gabriel turned [his]144-gabriel hand to , [he]144-gabriel decided to offer [himself]144-gabriel in some other capacity than that of [bailiff]3729-bailiff . [All the farmers]3730-all the farmers seemed to be wanting [shepherds]3711-shepherds . Sheep - tending was [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's speciality . Turning down [an obscure street]3732-an obscure street and entering [an obscurer lane]3733-an obscurer lane , [he]144-gabriel went up to [[a smith]3734-a smith 's shop]3735-a smith 's shop . "[647-ye] How long would it take [you]649-you to make [a shepherd 's crook]650-a shepherd 's crook ? " "[649-you] Twenty minutes . " "[649-you] How much ? " "[647-ye] Two shillings . " [He]144-gabriel sat on a bench and the crook was made , a stem being given [him]144-gabriel into the bargain . [He]144-gabriel then went to [a ready - made clothes ' shop]3736-a ready - made clothes ' shop , the owner of which had a large rural connection . As [the crook]3737-the crook had absorbed most of [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's money , [he]144-gabriel attempted , and carried out , an exchange of [his]144-gabriel overcoat for a [shepherd]3738-shepherd 's regulation smock - frock . This transaction having been completed , [he]144-gabriel again hurried off to [the centre of [the town]3722-the town]3739-the centre of the town , and stood on [the kerb of the pavement]3741-the kerb of the pavement , as [a shepherd]518-a shepherd , crook in hand . Now that [Oak]144-gabriel had turned [himself]144-gabriel into [a shepherd]518-a shepherd , it seemed that bailifs were most in demand . However , [two or three farmers]3744-two or three farmers noticed [him]144-gabriel and drew near . [Dialogues]174-dialogues followed , more or lessin the subjoined for : - "[647-ye] Where do [you]651-you come from ? " "[647-ye] [Norcombe]18-norcombe . " "[647-ye] That 's a long way . " Fifteen miles . "[647-ye] " [Who 's farm]3745-who 's farm were [you]651-you upon last ? "[647-ye] " [My]647-ye own . "[647-ye] This reply invariably operated like a rumour of cholera . [The inquiring farmer]652-the inquiring farmer would edge away and shake [his]652-the inquiring farmer head dubiously . [Gabriel]144-gabriel , like [his]144-gabriel dog , was too good to be trustworthy , . and [he]144-gabriel never made advance beyond this point . It is safer to accept any chance that offers itself , and extemporize a procedure to fit it , than to get [a good shepherd]653-a good shepherd , but had laid [himself]144-gabriel out for anything in the whole cycle of labour that was required in the fair . It grew dusk . [Some merry men]654-some merry men were whistling and singing by the corn - exchange . [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's hand , which had lain for some time idle in [his]144-gabriel smock - frock pocket , touched [his]144-gabriel flute which [he]144-gabriel carried there . Here was an opportunity for putting [his]144-gabriel dearly bought wisdom into practice . [He]144-gabriel drew out [his]144-gabriel flute and began to play " Jockey to the Fair "[144-gabriel] in the style of [a man who had never known moment 's sorrow]655-a man who had never known moment 's sorrow . [Oak]144-gabriel could pipe with Arcadian sweetness and the sound of the well - known notes cheered [his]144-gabriel own heart as well as those of [the loungers]656-the loungers . [He]144-gabriel played on with spirit , and in half an hour had earned in pence what was a small fortune to [a destitute man]657-a destitute man . By making inquiries [he]144-gabriel learnt that there was another fair at [Shottsford]19-shottsford the next day . " How far is [Shottsford]19-shottsford ? "[144-gabriel] " [Ten miles t'other side of [Weatherbury]196-joseph]3746-ten miles t'other side of weatherbury . "[144-gabriel] [Weatherbury]196-joseph ! [It]196-joseph was where [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had gone two months before . This information was like coming from night into noon . " How far is it to [Weatherbury]196-joseph ? "[144-gabriel] " Five or six miles . "[243-bathsheba] [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had probably left [Weatherbury]196-joseph long before this time , but [the place]3486-the place had enough interest attaching to [it]3486-the place to lead [Oak]144-gabriel to choose [Shottsford]19-shottsford fair as [[his]144-gabriel next field of inquiry]659-his next field of inquiry , because it lay in [the Weatherbury quarter]660-the weatherbury quarter . Moreover , [the Weatherbury folk]661-the weatherbury folk were by no means uninteresting intrinsically . If report spoke truly [they]661-the weatherbury folk were as hardy , merry , thriving , wicked a set as any in [the whole county]631-the whole county . [Oak]144-gabriel resolved to sleep at [Weatherbury]196-joseph - that - night on [his]144-gabriel way to [Shottsford]19-shottsford , and struck out at once - into [the - high road which had been recommended as the direct route to [the village in question]664-the village in question]663-the - high road which had been recommended as the direct route to the village in question . [The road]477-the road stretched through [water - meadows]666-water - meadows traversed by little brooks , whose quivering surfaces were braided along [their]667-their centres , and folded into creases at the sides ; or , where the flow was more rapid , [the stream]668-the stream was pied with spots of white froth , which rode on in undisturbed serenity . On the higher levels the dead and dry carcasses of leaves tapped the ground as [they]667-their bowled along helter- skelter upon the shoulders of the wind , and little birds in the hedges were rustling [their]669-their feathers and tucking [themselves]669-their in comfortably for the night , retaining [their]669-their places if [Oak]144-gabriel kept moving , but flying away if [he]144-gabriel stopped to look at [them]669-their . [He]144-gabriel passed by [Yalbury - Wood]20-yalbury - wood where the game - birds were rising to their roosts , and heard the crack - voiced cock - pheasants " cu - uck , cuck , "[144-gabriel] and the wheezy whistle of the hens . By the time [he]144-gabriel had walked three or four miles every shape in [the - landscape]670-the - landscape had assumed a uniform hue of blackness . [He]144-gabriel descended [Yalbury Hill]21-yalbury hill and could just discern ahead of [him]144-gabriel a waggon , drawn up under a great over - hanging tree by [the roadside]671-the roadside . On coming close , [he]144-gabriel found there were no horses attached to [it]672-it , the spot being apparently quite deserted . [The waggon]458-the waggon , from [its]458-the waggon position , seemed to have been left there for the night , for beyond about half a truss of hay which was heaped in the bottom , [it]672-it was quite empty . [Gabriel]144-gabriel sat down on the shafts of [the vehicle]460-the vehicle and con- sidered [his]144-gabriel position . [He]144-gabriel calculated that [he]144-gabriel had walked a very fair proportion of the journey ; and having been on foot since daybreak , [he]144-gabriel felt tempted to lie down upon the hay in [the waggon]458-the waggon instead of pushing on to [the village of Weatherbury]676-the village of weatherbury , and having to pay for a lodging . Eating [his]144-gabriel las slices of bread and ham , and drinking from the bottle of cider [he]144-gabriel had taken the precaution to bring with [him]144-gabriel , [he]144-gabriel got into [the lonely waggon]677-the lonely waggon . [Here]575-here [he]144-gabriel spread half of the hay as a bed , and , as well as [he]144-gabriel could in the darkness , pulled the other half over [him]144-gabriel by way of bed - clothes , covering [himself]144-gabriel entirely , and feeling , physically , as comfortable as ever [he]144-gabriel had been in [his]144-gabriel life . Inward melancholy it was impossible for [a man like [Oak]144-gabriel , introspective far beyond [[his]144-gabriel neighbours]432-his neighbours]679-a man like oak , introspective far beyond his neighbours , to banish quite , whilst conning the present . untoward page of [his]144-gabriel history . So , thinking of [his]144-gabriel misfortunes , amorous and pastoral [he]144-gabriel fell asleep , [shepherds]3711-shepherds enjoying , in common with [sailors]682-sailors , the privilege of being able to summon [the god]683-the god instead of having to wait for [him]144-gabriel . On somewhat suddenly awaking after a sleep of whose length [he]144-gabriel had no idea , [Oak]144-gabriel found that the waggon was in motion . [He]144-gabriel was being carried along [the road]477-the road at a rate rather considerable for [a vehicle]685-a vehicle without springs , and under circumstances of physical uneasiness , [his]144-gabriel head being dandled up and down on the bed of the waggon like a kettledrum - stick . [He]144-gabriel then dis- tinguished voices in conversation , coming from [the forpart of [the waggon]458-the waggon]686-the forpart of the waggon . [His]144-gabriel concern at this dilemma which would have been alarm , had [he]144-gabriel been [a thriving man]688-a thriving man ; but - misfortune is a fine opiate to personal terror led [him]144-gabriel to peer cautiously from the hay , and the first sight [he]144-gabriel beheld was the stars above [him]144-gabriel . [Charles]175-charles 's Wain was getting towards a right angle with the Pole star , and [Gabriel]144-gabriel concluded that it must be about nine o'clock - in other words , that [he]144-gabriel had slept two hours . This small astronomical calculation was made without any positive effort , and whilst [he]144-gabriel was stealthily turning to discover , if possible , into whose hands [he]144-gabriel had fallen . [Two figures]689-two figures were dimly visible in front , sitting with [their]689-two figures legs outside [the waggon]458-the waggon , one of whom was driving . [Gabriel]144-gabriel soon found that this was [the waggoner]461-the waggoner , and it appeared [they]689-two figures had come from [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge fair , like [himself]144-gabriel . A conversation was in progress , which continued thus : - " Be as ' twill , [she]693-she 's a fine handsome body as far 's looks be concerned . But that 's only the skin of [the woman]3527-the woman , and [these dandy cattle]3748-these dandy cattle be as - proud as a lucifer in [their]3748-these dandy cattle insides . "[461-the waggoner] " Ay - so ' a do seem , [Billy Smallbury]176-billy smallbury - so ' a do seem . "[461-the waggoner] This utterance was very shaky by nature , and more so by circumstance , the jolting of the waggon not being- without its effect upon [the speaker]692-the speaker 's larynx . It came " from [the man who held the reins]3749-the man who held the reins . "[693-she] [She]693-she 's [a very vain feymell]694-a very vain feymell - so ' tis said here and there . " "[693-she] Ah , now . If so be ' tis like that , [I]0-i ca n't look [her]693-she in the face . [Lord]695-lord , no : not [I]0-i - heh - heh - heh ! [Such a shy man as [I]0-i be]696-such a shy man as i be ! " "[693-she] Yes - [she]693-she 's very vain . ' Tis said that every night at going to bed [she]693-she looks in the glass to put on [her]693-she night- cap properly . " "[693-she] And not [a married woman]697-a married woman . Oh , [the world]447-the world ! " "[693-she] And ' a can play the peanner , so ' tis said . Can play so clever that ' a can make a psalm tune sound as well as the merriest loose song [a man]3474-a man can wish for . " "[3450-man] D'ye tell o't ! A happy time for [us]700-they , and [I]0-i feel quite [a new man]701-a new man ! And how do [she]693-she play ? " "[693-she] That [I]0-i do n't know , [Master Poorgrass]177-master poorgrass . " On hearing these and other similar remarks , a wild thought flashed into [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's mind that [they]700-they might be speaking of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba . There were , however , no ground for retaining such a supposition , for the waggon , though going in the direction of [Weatherbury]196-joseph , might be going beyond it , and [the woman alluded to]3750-the woman alluded to seemed to be [the mistress of [some estate]3752-some estate]3751-the mistress of some estate . [They]700-they were now apparently close upon [Weatherbury]196-joseph and not to alarm the speakers unnecessarily , [Gabriel]144-gabriel slipped out of the waggon unseen . [He]144-gabriel turned to an opening in the hedge , which [he]144-gabriel found to be a gate , and mounting thereon , [he]144-gabriel sat meditating whether to seek [a cheap lodging in [the village]3754-the village]3753-a cheap lodging in the village , or to ensure a cheaper one by lying under some hay or corn - stack . The crunching jangle of the waggon died upon [his]144-gabriel ear . [He]144-gabriel was about to walk on , when [he]144-gabriel noticed on [his]144-gabriel left hand an unusual light - appearing about half a mile distant . [Oak]144-gabriel watched it , and the glow increased . Something was on fire . [Gabriel]144-gabriel again mounted the gate , and , leaping down on the other side upon what [he]144-gabriel found to be ploughed soil , made across [the field]3467-the field in the exact direction of the fire . The blaze , enlarging in a double ratio by [his]144-gabriel approach and its own increase , showed [him]144-gabriel as [he]144-gabriel drew nearer the outlines of ricks beside [it]196-joseph , lighted up to great distinctness . [A rick - yard]3756-a rick - yard was the source of the fire . [His]144-gabriel weary face now began to be painted over with a rich orange glow , and the whole front of [his]144-gabriel smock- frock and gaiters was covered with a dancing shadow pattern of thorn - twigs - the light reaching [him]144-gabriel through a leafless intervening hedge - and the metallic curve of [his]144-gabriel sheep - crook shone silver - bright in the same abound- ing rays . [He]144-gabriel came up to the boundary fence , and stood to regain breath . It seemed as if [the spot]3757-the spot was unoccupied by [a living soul]3758-a living soul . The fire was issuing from a long straw - stack , which was so far gone as to preclude a possibility of saving it . A rick burns differently from [a house]3759-a house . As the wind blows the fire inwards , the portion in flames completely disappears like melting sugar , and the outline is lost to the eye . However , a hay or a wheat - rick , well put together , will resist combustion for a length of time , if it begins on the outside . This before [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's eyes was a- rick of straw , loosely put together , and the flames darted into it with lightning swiftness . It glowed on the windward side , rising and falling in intensity , like the coal of a cigar . Then a superincumbent bundle rolled down , with a whisking noise ; flames elongated , and bent themselves about with a quiet roar , but no crackle . Banks of smoke went off horizontally at the back like passing clouds , and behind these burned hidden pyres , illuminating the semi - transparent sheet of smoke to a lustrous yellow uniformity . Individual straws in the foreground were consumed in a creeping movement of ruddy heat , as if they were knots of red worms , and above shone imaginary fiery faces , tongues hanging from lips , glaring eyes , and other impish forms , from which at intervals sparks flew in clusters like birds from a nest , [Oak]144-gabriel suddenly ceased from being a mere spectator by discovering the case to be more serious than [he]144-gabriel had at first imagined . A scroll of smoke blew aside and revealed to [him]144-gabriel a wheat - rick in startling juxtaposition with the decaying one , and behind this a series of others , composing the main corn produce of [the farm]3760-the farm ; so that instead of the straw - stack standing , as [he]144-gabriel had imagined comparatively isolated , there was a regular connection between [it]196-joseph and the remaining stacks of [the group]3761-the group . [Gabriel]144-gabriel leapt over the hedge , and saw that [he]144-gabriel was not alone . [The first man [he]144-gabriel came to]3762-the first man he came to was running about in a great hurry , as if [his]3762-the first man he came to thoughts were several yards in advance of [his]3762-the first man he came to body , which [they]3763-they could never drag on fast enough . "[177-master poorgrass] O , [man]3450-man - fire , fire ! [A good master]703-a good master and [a. bad servant]704-a. bad servant is fire , fire ! - [I]0-i mane [a bad servant]705-a bad servant and [a good master]703-a good master O , [Mark Clark]178-mark clark - come ! And [you]707-you , [Billy Smallbury]176-billy smallbury - and [you]707-you , [Maryann Money]179-maryann - and [you]707-you , [Jan Coggan]180-coggan , and [Matthew]181-matthew moon [there]3509-there ! " [Other figures]3764-other figures now appeared behind [this shouting man]3765-this shouting man and among the smoke , and [Gabriel]144-gabriel found that , far from being alone [he]144-gabriel was in [a great company]3766-a great company - whose shadows danced merrily up and down , timed by the jigging of the flames , and not at all by [[their]3766-a great company owners]3767-their owners ' movements . The assemblage - belonging to [that class of society which casts its thoughts into the form of feeling , and its feelings into the form of commotion]3768-that class of society which casts its thoughts into the form of feeling , and its feelings into the form of commotion - set to work with a remarkable confusion of purpose . "[181-matthew moon] Stop the draught under the wheat - rick ! " cried [Gabriel]144-gabriel to [those nearest to [him]144-gabriel]3769-those nearest to him . The corn stood on stone staddles , and between these , tongues of yellow hue from the burning straw licked and darted playfully . If the fire once got under this stack , all would be lost . "[181-matthew moon] Get a tarpaulin - quick ! " said [Gabriel]144-gabriel . A rick - cloth was brought , and [they]3770-they hung it like a curtain across [the channel]3771-the channel . The flames immediately ceased to go under the bottom of the corn - stack , and stood up vertical . "[181-matthew moon] Stand here with a bucket of water and keep the cloth wet . " said [Gabriel]144-gabriel again . The flames , now driven upwards , began to attack the angles of the huge roof covering the wheat - stack . "[181-matthew moon] A ladder . " cried [Gabriel]144-gabriel . "[181-matthew moon] The ladder was against the straw - rick and is burnt to a cinder . " said a spectre - like form in the smoke . [Oak]144-gabriel seized the cut ends of the sheaves , as if [he]144-gabriel were going to engage in the operation of "[181-matthew moon] reed - drawing , " and digging in [his]144-gabriel feet , and occasionally sticking in the stem of [his]144-gabriel sheep - crook , [he]144-gabriel clambered up the beetling face . [He]144-gabriel at once sat astride the very apex , and began with [his]144-gabriel crook to beat off the fiery fragments which had lodged thereon , shouting to [the others]3772-the others to get [him]144-gabriel a bough and a ladder , and some water . [Billy Smallbury]176-billy smallbury - one of [the men who had been on the waggon]3773-the men who had been on the waggon - by this time had found a ladder , which [Mark Clark]178-mark clark ascended , holding on beside [Oak]144-gabriel upon the thatch . The smoke at this corner was stifling , and [Clark]178-mark clark , [a nimble fellow , having been handed a bucket of water]3774-a nimble fellow , having been handed a bucket of water , bathed [Oak]144-gabriel 's face and sprinkled [him]144-gabriel generally , whilst [Gabriel]144-gabriel , now with a long beech - bough in one hand , in addition to [his]144-gabriel crook in the other , kept sweeping the stack and dislodging all fiery particles . On the ground [the groups of [villagers]3776-villagers]3775-the groups of villagers were still occupied in doing all [they]3775-the groups of villagers could to keep down the conflagration , which was not much . [They]3775-the groups of villagers were all tinged orange , and backed up by shadows of varying pattern . Round the corner of the largest stack , out of the direct rays of the fire , stood a pony , bearing [a young woman]3777-a young woman on [its]3778-its back . By [her]3777-a young woman side was [another woman]3779-another woman , on foot . These two seemed to keep at a distance from the fire , that the horse might not become restive . "[181-matthew moon] [He]709-he 's [a shepherd]518-a shepherd . " said [the woman on foot]3780-the woman on foot . "[709-he] Yes - [he]709-he is . See how [his]709-he crook shines as [he]709-he beats the rick with it . And [his]709-he smock - frock is burnt in two holes , [I]0-i declare ! " CHAPTER VII RECOGNITION - [A TIMID GIRL BATHSHEBA]184-bathsheba withdrew into the shade . [She]712-ma'am scarcely knew whether most to be amused at the singularity of the meeting , or to be concerned at its awkwardness . There was room for a little pity , also for a very little exultation : the former at [his]144-gabriel position , the latter at [her]712-ma'am own . CHAPTER VIII [THE MALTHOUSE]3832-the malthouse - [THE CHAT - NEWS WARREN 'S Malthouse]3833-the chat - news warren 's malthouse was enclosed by an old wall inwrapped with ivy , and though not much of the exterior was visible at this hour , the character and purposes of [the building]3834-the building were clearly enough shown by [its]3834-the building outline upon the sky . From the walls an overhanging thatched roof sloped up to a point in the centre , upon which rose a small wooden lantern , fitted with louvre - boards on all the four sides , and from these openings a mist was dimly perceived to be escaping into the night air . There was no window in front ; but a square hole in the door was glazed with a single pane , through which red , comfortable rays now stretched out upon the ivied wall in front . Voices were to be heard inside . [Oak]144-gabriel 's hand skimmed the surface of the door with fingers extended to an Elymas - the - Somerer pattern , till [he]144-gabriel found a leathern strap , which [he]144-gabriel pulled . This lifted a wooden latch , and the door swung open . [The room inside]3835-the room inside was lighted only by the , ruddy glow from [the kiln]3836-the kiln mouth , which shone over , the floor with the streaming , horizontality of the setting sun , and threw upwards the shadows of all facial irregularities in those assembled around . The stone - flag floor was worn into a path from the doorway to [the kiln]3836-the kiln , and into undula- tions everywhere . A curved settle of unplaned oak stretched along one side , and in a remote corner was a small bed and bedstead , [the owner]3838-the owner and frequent occupier of which was [the maltster]3839-the maltster . [This aged man]3840-this aged man was now sitting opposite the fire , [his]3840-this aged man frosty white hair and beard overgrowing [his]3840-this aged man gnarled figure like the grey moss and lichen upon a leafless apple - tree . [He]3840-this aged man wore breeches and the laced - up shoes called ankle - jacks ; [he]3840-this aged man kept [his]3840-this aged man eyes fixed upon the fire . [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's nose was greeted by an atmosphere laden with the sweet smell of new malt . The conversation which seemed to have been concerning the origin of the fire immediately ceased , and [every one]3841-every one ocularly criticised [him]3840-this aged man to the degree expressed by contracting the flesh of [their]3841-every one foreheads and looking at [him]3840-this aged man with narrowed eye- lids , as if [he]3840-this aged man had been a light too strong for [their]3841-every one sight . [Several]3842-several exclaimed meditatively , after this operation had been completed : - "[0-i] Oh , ' tis [the new shepherd]3819-the new shepherd , ' a b'lieve . " said [the maltster]3839-the maltster , removing from the fire [his]3839-the maltster eyes , which were vermilion - red and bleared by gazing into it for so many years . "[187-jacob] Take up the God - forgive- [me]0-i , [Jacob]187-jacob . See if ' tis warm , [Jacob]187-jacob . " [Jacob]187-jacob stooped to the God - forgive - [me]187-jacob , which was a two - handled tall mug standing in the ashes , cracked and charred with heat : it was rather furred with ex- traneous matter about the outside , especially in the crevices of the handles , the innermost curves of which may not have seen daylight for several years by reason of this encrustation thereon - formed of ashes accident- ally wetted with cider and baked hard ; but to the mind of [any sensible drinker]3862-any sensible drinker the cup was no worse for that , being incontestably clean on the inside and about the rim . It may be observed that such a class of mug is called a God - forgive - [me]187-jacob in [Weatherbury]196-joseph and [[its]196-joseph vicinity]3863-its vicinity for uncertain reasons ; probably because its size makes [any given toper]3864-any given toper feel ashamed of [himself]3864-any given toper when [he]3864-any given toper sees its bottom in drinking it empty . [Jacob]187-jacob , on receiving the order to see if the liquor was warm enough , placidly dipped [his]187-jacob forefinger into it by way of thermometer , and having pronounced it nearly of the proper degree , raised the cup and very civilly attempted to dust some of the ashes from the bottom with the skirt of [his]187-jacob smock - frock , because [Shepherd Oak]192-shepherd oak was [a stranger]718-a stranger . "[187-jacob] A clane cup for [the shepherd]528-the shepherd . " said [the maltster]3839-the maltster commandingly . "[528-the shepherd] No - not at all , " said [Gabriel]144-gabriel , in a reproving tone of considerateness . "[0-i] [I]0-i never fuss about dirt in its pure state , and when [I]0-i know what sort it is . " Taking the mug [he]144-gabriel drank an inch or more from the depth of its contents , and duly passed it to [the next man]3867-the next man . would n't think of giving such trouble to [neighbours]776-neighbours in washing up when there 's so much work to be done in [the world]447-the world already . "[144-gabriel] continued [Oak]144-gabriel in a moister tone , after recovering from the stoppage of breath which is occasioned by pulls at large mugs . " "[901-a] Well , ' twas a most ungodly remedy . " said [Billy Smallbury]176-billy smallbury , "[0-i] [The man]726-the man 's will was to do right , sure enough , but [his]726-the man heart did n't chime in . " "[726-the man] [He]726-the man got so much better , that [he]726-the man was quite godly in [his]726-the man later years , was n't [he]726-the man , [Jan]180-coggan ? " said [Joseph Poor- grass]188-joseph . "[726-the man] [He]726-the man got [himself]726-the man confirmed over again in a more serious way , and took to saying " Amen "[726-the man] almost as loud as [the clerk]905-the clerk , and [he]726-the man liked to copy comforting verses from the tombstones . "[0-i] Do as [I]0-i told [you]996-mistress , then " [she]0-i said in conclusion , closing the casement . "[0-i] Ay , ay , [mistress]996-mistress ; [we]1001-they will . " [they]1001-they replied , and moved away . That night at [Coggan 's]180-coggan , [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel , beneath the screen of closed eyelids , was busy with fancies , and full of movement , like a river flowing rapidly under its ice . Night had always been the time at which [he]753-the bailiff saw [Bath- sheba]168-bath- sheba most vividly , and through the slow hours of shadow [he]753-the bailiff tenderly regarded [her]168-bath- sheba image now . It is rarely that the pleasures of the imagination will compen- sate for the pain of sleeplessness , but [they]1001-they possibly did with [Oak]144-gabriel to - night , for the delight of merely seeing [her]168-bath- sheba effaced for the time [his]753-the bailiff perception of the great differ- ence between seeing and possessing . [He]753-the bailiff also thought of Plans for fetching [his]753-the bailiff few utensils and books from [Norcombe]18-norcombe . [[The Young Man]218-the young man 's Best Companion]3984-the young man 's best companion , [The Farrier 's Sure Guide]3985-the farrier 's sure guide , [The Veterinary Surgeon]3986-the veterinary surgeon , [Paradise Lost]40-paradise lost , [The Pilgrim]3987-the pilgrim 's Progress , [Robinson Crusoe]219-robinson crusoe , [Ash]220-ash 's Dictionary , [the Walkingame]221-the walkingame 's Arithmetic , constituted [[his]753-the bailiff library]3988-his library ; and though a limited series , it was one from which [he]753-the bailiff had acquired more sound informa- tion by diligent perusal than many [a man of opportunities]3989-a man of opportunities has done from a furlong of laden shelves . CHAPTER IX [THE HOMESTEAD]3990-the homestead - [A VISITOR]3619-a visitor - HALF - CONFIDENCES By daylight , [the Bower of [[Oak]144-gabriel 's new - found mistress]3993-oak 's new - found mistress]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress , [Bathsheba Everdene]243-bathsheba , presented [itself]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress as [a hoary build- ing]3994-a hoary build- ing , of the early stage of Classic Renaissance as regards [its]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress architecture , and of ' a proportion which told at a glance that , as is so frequently the case , [it]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress had once been [the memorial hall upon [a small estate around [it]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress]3996-a small estate around it , now altogether effaced as [a distinct property]3997-a distinct property , and merged in [the vast tract of [a non - resident landlord]3999-a non - resident landlord , which com- prised several such modest demesnes]3998-the vast tract of a non - resident landlord , which com- prised several such modest demesnes]3995-the memorial hall upon a small estate around it , now altogether effaced as a distinct property , and merged in the vast tract of a non - resident landlord , which com- prised several such modest demesnes . Fluted pilasters , worked from the solid stone , decorated [its]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress front , and above the roof the chimneys were panelled or columnar , some coped gables with finials and like features still retaining traces of [their]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress Gothic extraction . Soft Brown mosses , like faded velveteen , formed cushions upon the stone tiling , and tufts of the houseleek or sengreen sprouted from the eaves of [the low surrounding buildings]4000-the low surrounding buildings . A gravel walk leading from the door to [the road in front]4001-the road in front was encrusted at the sides with more moss - here it was a silver - green variety , the nut - brown of the gravel being visible to the width of only a foot or two in the centre . This circum- stance , and the generally sleepy air of the whole prospect here , together with the animated and contrasting state of the reverse facade , suggested to the imagination that on the adaptation of [the building]3834-the building for farming purposes the vital principle ' of [the house]552-the house had turned round inside [its]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress body to face the other way . Reversals of this kind , strange deformities , tremendous paralyses , are often seen to be inflicted by trade upon [edifices]4004-edifices - either individual or in the aggregate as [streets]4005-streets and [towns]542-towns - which were originally planned for pleasure alone . Lively voices were heard this morning in [the upper rooms]4007-the upper rooms , the main staircase to which was of hard oak , the balusters , heavy as bed - posts , being turned and moulded in the quaint fashion of [their]3992-the bower of oak 's new - found mistress century , the handrail as stout as a parapet - top , and the stairs themselves con- tinually twisting round like a person trying to look over [his]4008-his shoulder . Going up , the floors above were found to have a very irregular surface , rising to ridges , sinking into valley ; and being just then uncarpeted , the face of the boards was seen to be eaten into innumerable the opening and shutting of every door a tremble followed every bustling movement , and a creak accom- panied a walker about [the house]552-the house like a spirit , wherever- [he]4008-his went . In [the room from which the conversation proceeded]4010-the room from which the conversation proceeded , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba and [[her]4011-her servant - companion]4012-her servant - companion , [Liddy Small- bury]191-liddy were to be discovered sitting upon the floor , and sorting a complication of papers , books , bottles , and rubbish spread out thereon - remnants from [the house-]4013-the house- hold stores of [the late occupier]4014-the late occupier . [Liddy]191-liddy , [[the maltster]3839-the maltster 's great - granddaughter]4016-the maltster 's great - granddaughter , was about [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's equal in age , and [her]191-liddy face was a prominent advertisement of the features ' might have lacked in form was amply made up for by perfection of hue , which at this winter - time was the softened ruddiness on a surface of high rotundity and , like the presentations of [those great colourists]4017-those great colourists , it was a face which kept well back from the boundary between comeliness and the ideal . Though elastic in nature [she]191-liddy was less daring than [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , and occa- sionally showed some earnestness , which consisted half of genuine feeling , and half of mannerliness superadded by way of duty . Through a partly - opened door the noise of a scrubbing- brush led up to [the charwoman]4018-the charwoman , [Maryann Money]179-maryann , [a person who for a face had a circular disc , furrowed less by age than by long gazes of perplexity at distant objects]4019-a person who for a face had a circular disc , furrowed less by age than by long gazes of perplexity at distant objects . To think of [her]179-maryann was to get good - humoured ; to speak of [her]179-maryann was to raise the image of a dried Normandy pippin . "[0-i] Stop [your]1002-your scrubbing a moment . " said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba through the door to [her]179-maryann . "[0-i] [I]0-i hear something . " [Maryann]179-maryann suspended the brush . The tramp of a horse was apparent , approaching the front of [the building]3834-the building . The paces slackened , turned in at the wicket , and , what was most unusual , came up [the mossy path]4021-the mossy path close to the door . The door was tapped with the end of a crop or stick . "[0-i] What impertinence ! " said [Liddy]191-liddy , in a low voice . "[0-i] To ride up the footpath like that ! Why did n't [he]1003-he stop at the gate ? [Lord]695-lord ! ' Tis [a gentleman]600-a gentleman ! [I]0-i see the top of [his]1003-he hat . " "[1003-he] Be quiet ! " said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba . "[191-liddy] CHAPTER X HALF - AN - HOUR later [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , in finished dress , and followed by [Liddy]191-liddy , entered the upper end of [the old hall]1055-the old hall to find that [[her]191-liddy men]1056-her men had all deposited [themselves]1056-her men on a long form and a settle at the lower extremity . "[1127-this small - thesmothete] Then [this small - thesmothete]1127-this small - thesmothete stepped from the table , and surged out of [the hall]4051-the hall , [her]1127-this small - thesmothete black silk dress licking up a few straws and dragging them along with a scratch- ing noise upon the floor . biddy , elevating [her]1127-this small - thesmothete feelings to the occasion from a sense of grandeur , floated off behind [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba with a milder dignity not entirely free from travesty , and the door was closed . CHAPTER XI OUTSIDE [THE BARRACKS]1129-the barracks - SNOW - A MEETING FOR dreariness nothing could surpass a prospect in [the outskirts of [a certain town]1131-a certain town]1130-the outskirts of a certain town and [military station]1132-military station , [many miles north of [Weatherbury]196-joseph]1133-many miles north of weatherbury , at a later hour on this same snowy evening - if that may be called a prospect of which [the chief constituent]1134-the chief constituent was darkness . It was a night when sorrow may come to the brightest without causing any great sense of incongruity : when , with [impressible persons]1135-impressible persons , love becomes solicitous- ness , hope sinks to misgiving , and faith to hope : when the exercise of memory does not stir feelings of regret at opportunities for ambition that have been passed by , and anticipation does not prompt to enterprise . The scene was [a public path]1136-a public path , bordered on the left hand by [a river]435-a river , behind which rose a high wall . On the right was [a tract of land]1138-a tract of land , partly [meadow'and partly moor]1139-meadow'and partly moor , reaching , at [its]1138-a tract of land remote verge , to a wide undulating uplan . The changes of the seasons are less obtrusive on spots of this kind than amid [woodland scenery]1140-woodland scenery . Still , to [a close observer]1141-a close observer , they are just as perceptible ; the difference is that their media of manifestation are less trite and familiar than such well - known ones as the bursting of the buds or the fall of the leaf . Many are not so stealthy and gradual as [we]1142-we may be apt to imagine in considering the general torpidity of [a moor]1143-a moor or waste . Winter , in coming to [the country]1144-the country hereabout , advanced in well - marked stages , wherein might have been successively observed the retreat of the snakes , the transformation of the ferns , the filling of the pools , a rising of fogs , the embrowning by frost , the collapse of the fungi , and an obliteration by snow . This climax of the series had been reached to - night on [the aforesaid moor]1145-the aforesaid moor , and for the first time in the season its irregularities were forms without features ; suggestive of anything , proclaiming nothing , and without more character than that of being the limit of something else - the lowest layer of a firmament of snow . From this chaotic skyful of crowding flakes [the mead and moor]1146-the mead and moor momentarily received additional clothing , only to appear momentarily more naked thereby . The vast arch of cloud above was strangely low , and formed as it were the roof of [a large dark cavern]1147-a large dark cavern , gradually sinking in upon [its]1147-a large dark cavern floor ; for the instinctive thought was that the snow lining [the heavens]1148-the heavens and that encrusting [the earth]1149-the earth would soon unite into one mass without any intervening stratum of air at all . [We]1142-we turn [our]1142-we attention to the left - hand characteristics ; which were flatness in respect of [the river]1150-the river , verticality in respect of the wall behind [it]1150-the river , and darkness as to both . These features made up the mass . If anything could be darker than the sky , it was the wall , and if any thing could be gloomier than the wall it was [the river beneath]1151-the river beneath . The indistinct summit of the facade was notched and pronged by chimneys here and there , and upon [its]1147-a large dark cavern face were faintly signified the oblong shapes of windows , though only in the upper part . Below , down to [the water]3694-the water 's edge , the flat was unbroken by hole or projection . An indescribable succession of dull blows , perplexing in their regularity , sent their sound- with difficulty through the fluffy atmosphere . It was a neighbouring clock striking ten The bell was in the open air , and being overlaid with several inches of muffling snow , had lost its voice for the time . About this hour the snow abated : ten flakes fell where twenty had fallen , then one had [the room of ten]1153-the room of ten . Not long after a form moved by [the brink of [the river]1150-the river]1154-the brink of the river . By its outline upon the colourless background , [a close observer]1141-a close observer might have seen that it was small . This was all that was positively discoverable , though it seemed human . The shape went slowly along , but without much exertion , for the snow , though sudden , was not as yet more than two inches deep . At this time some words were spoken aloud : - " One . Two . Three . Four . Five . "[1157-the figure] Between each utterance the little shape advanced about half a dozen yards . It was evident now that the windows high in the wall were being counted . The word " Five "[1170-this person] represented the fifth window from the end of the wall . Here the spot stopped , and dwindled smaller . [The figure]1157-the figure was stooping . Then a morsel of snow flew across [the river]1150-the river towards the fifth window . It smacked against the wall at a point several yards from its mark . The throw was the idea of [a man]3474-a man conjoined with the execution of [a woman]459-a woman . [No man who had ever seen bird , rabbit , or squirrel in [his]1161-no man who had ever seen bird , rabbit , or squirrel in his childhood childhood]1161-no man who had ever seen bird , rabbit , or squirrel in his childhood , could possibly have thrown with such utter imbecility as was shown here . Another attempt , and another ; till by degrees the wall must have become pimpled with the adhering lumps of snow At last one fragment struck the fifth window . [The river]1150-the river would have been ; seen by day to be of that deep smooth sort which races middle and sides with the same gliding precision , any irregularities of speed being immediately corrected by a small whirl- pool . Nothing was heard in reply to the signal but the gurgle and cluck of one of these invisible wheels - together with a few small sounds which [a sad man]1163-a sad man would have called moans , and [a happy man]1164-a happy man laughter - caused by the flapping of the waters against trifling objects in [other parts of [the stream]668-the stream]1165-other parts of the stream . The window was struck again in the same manner . Then a noise was heard , apparently produced by the opening of the window . This was followed by a voice from the same quarter . " Who 's there ? "[3527-the woman] The tones were masculine , and not those of surprise . The high wall being that of [a barrack]1167-a barrack , and marriage being looked upon with disfavour in [the army]1168-the army , assigna- tions and communications had probably been made across [the river]1150-the river before tonight . " Is it [Sergeant Troy]243-bathsheba ? "[3527-the woman] said the blurred spot in the snow , tremulously . [This person]1170-this person was so much like a mere shade upon [the earth]1149-the earth , and [the other speaker so much a part of [the building]3834-the building]1172-the other speaker so much a part of the building , that one would have said the wall was holding a conversation with [the snow]1174-the snow . " Yes . "[462-the girl] came suspiciously from the shadow . " [What girl]4110-what girl are [you]1170-this person ? "[462-the girl] " O , [Frank]244-frank - do n't [you]244-frank know [me]3527-the woman ? "[3527-the woman] said the spot . " [[Your]244-frank wife]4111-your wife , [Fanny Robin]217-fanny . "[462-the girl] " [Fanny]217-fanny ! "[462-the girl] said the wall , in utter astonishment . " Yes . "[462-the girl] said [the girl]462-the girl , with a half - suppressed gasp of emotion . There was something in [the woman]3527-the woman 's tone which is not that of [the wife]4091-the wife , and there was a mannerin [the man]726-the man which is rarely [a husband]3655-a husband 's . The dialogue went on : " How did [you]1170-this person come here ? "[462-the girl] " [I]462-the girl asked which was [your]1170-this person window . Forgive [me]462-the girl ! CHAPTER XII FARMERS - A RULE - IN [EXCEPTION]51-exception THE first public evidence of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's decision to be [a farmer in [her]1185-her own person]1186-a farmer in her own person and by proxy no more was [her]1185-her appearance the following market - day in . [the cornmarket at [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge]1187-the cornmarket at casterbridge . [The low though extensive hall]1188-the low though extensive hall , supported by beams and pillars , and latterly dignified by - the name of Corn Ex- change , was thronged with hot men who talked among [each other in twos and threes]1189-each other in twos and threes , [the speaker of the minute]1190-the speaker of the minute looking sideways into [[his]1190-the speaker of the minute auditor]1191-his auditor 's face and concentrating [his]1190-the speaker of the minute argument by a contraction of one eyelid during de- livery . The greater number carried in [their]1192-their hands ground - ash saplings , using [them]1193-them partly as walking - sticks and partly for poking up pigs , sheep , [neighbours]776-neighbours with [their]776-neighbours backs turned , and restful things in general , which seemed to require such treatment in the course of [their]1192-their peregrinations . During conversations each subjected [his]1195-his sapling to great varieties of usage - bending it round [his]1195-his back , forming an"arch of it between [his]1195-his two hands , overweighting it on the ground till it reached nearly a semicircle ; or perhaps it was hastily tucked under the arm whilst the sample - bag was pulled forth and a hand- ful of corn poured into the palm , which , after criticism , was flung upon the floor , an issue of events perfectly well known to half - a - dozen acute town - bred fowls which had as usual crept into [the building]3834-the building unobserved , and waited the fulfilment of [their]1192-their anticipations with a high- stretched neck and oblique eye . Among [these heavy yeomen]4123-these heavy yeomen [a feminine figure]4124-a feminine figure glided , the single one of [her]4124-a feminine figure sex that [the room]4025-the room contained . [She]4124-a feminine figure was prettily and even daintily dressed . [She]4124-a feminine figure moved between [them]4123-these heavy yeomen as a chaise between carts , was heard after [them]4123-these heavy yeomen as a romance after sermons , was felt among [them]4123-these heavy yeomen like a breeze among furnaces . It had required a little determination - far more than [she]4124-a feminine figure had at first imagined - to take up a position here , for at [her]4124-a feminine figure first entry the lumbering dialogues had ceased , nearly every face had been turned towards [her]4124-a feminine figure , and those that were already turned rigidly fixed there . [Two or three only of [the farmers]4127-the farmers]4126-two or three only of the farmers were personally known to [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , and to these [she]4124-a feminine figure had made [her]4124-a feminine figure way . But if [she]4124-a feminine figure was to be [the practical woman [she]4124-a feminine figure had intended to show [herself]4124-a feminine figure]4128-the practical woman she had intended to show herself , business must be carried on , introductions or none , and [she]4124-a feminine figure ultimately acquired con- fidence enough to speak and reply boldly to men merely known to [her]4124-a feminine figure by hearsay . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba too had [her]4124-a feminine figure sample - bags , and by degrees adopted the professional pour into the hand - holding up the grains in [her]4124-a feminine figure narrow palm for inspection , in perfect Casterbridge manner . Something in the exact arch of [her]4124-a feminine figure upper unbroken row of teeth , and in the keenly pointed corners of [her]4124-a feminine figure red mouth when , with parted lips , [she]4124-a feminine figure somewhat defiantly turned up [her]4124-a feminine figure face to argue a point with [a tall man]4129-a tall man , suggested that there was potentiality enough in that lithe slip of humanity for alarming exploits of sex , and daring enough to carry them out . But [her]4124-a feminine figure eyes had a softness - invariably a softness - which , had they not been dark , would have seemed mistiness ; as they were , it lowered an expression that might have been piercing to simple clearness , Strange to say of [a woman in full bloom and vigor]4130-a woman in full bloom and vigor , [she]4124-a feminine figure always allowed [[her]4124-a feminine figure interlocutors]4131-her interlocutors to finish [their]4131-her interlocutors state- [ments]4132-ments before rejoining with [hers]4124-a feminine figure . In arguing on prices , [he]4129-a tall man held to [her]4124-a feminine figure own firmly , as was natural in [a dealer]3701-a dealer , and reduced theirs persistently , as was inevitable in a oman . But there was an elasticity in [her]4124-a feminine figure firmness which removed it from obstinacy , as there was a naivete in [her]4124-a feminine figure cheapening which saved it from meanness . "[191-liddy] [CHAPTER XIII SORTES SANCTORUM]53-chapter xiii sortes sanctorum - THE VALENTINE IT was Sunday afternoon in [the farmhouse]3979-the farmhouse , on the thirteenth of February . [The mouldy pile]1224-the mouldy pile was dreary in winter - time before the candles were lighted and the shutters closed ; the atmosphere of [the place]3486-the place seemed as old as the walls ; every nook behind the furniture had a temperature of its own , for the fire was not kindled in [this part of [the house]552-the house]1226-this part of the house early in the day ; and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's new piano , which was an old one in other annals , looked particularly sloping and out of level on the warped floor before night threw a shade over its less prominent angles and hid the unpleasantness . [Liddy]191-liddy , like a little brook , though shallow , was always rippling ; [her]191-liddy presence had not so much weight as to task thought , and yet enough to exercise it . On the table lay an old quarto Bible , bound in leather . [Liddy]191-liddy looking at it said , - " Did [you]1228-child ever find out , [miss]1011-miss , who [you]1228-child are going to marry by means of the Bible and key ? , "[191-liddy] Do n't be so foolish , [Liddy]191-liddy . "[0-i] Go and get the front door key . " [Liddy]191-liddy fetched it . "[0-i] [I]0-i wish it was n't Sunday . " [she]191-liddy said , on returning . "[0-i] Perhaps ' tis wrong .
