"[0-i] A large red seal was duly affixed . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba looked closely at the hot wax to discover the words . " Capital ! "[1242-their] [she]0-i exclaimed , throwing down the letter frolicsomely . " ' Twould upset the solemnity of [a parson]4190-a parson The same evening the letter was sent , and was duly returned to [Weatherbury]196-joseph again in the morning . Of love as a spectacle [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had a fair knowledge ; but of love subjectively [she]0-i knew nothing . CHAPTER XIV EFFECT OF THE LETTER - SUNRISE AT dusk , on the evening of [St. Valentine]248-valentine 's Day , [Bold-]249-bold- wood sat down to supper as usual , by a beaming fire of aged logs . Upon the mantel - shelf before [him]249-bold- was a time - piece , surmounted by a spread eagle , and upon the eagle 's wings was the letter [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had sent . Here [the bachelor]4191-the bachelor 's gaze was continually fastening itself , till the large red seal became as a blot of blood on the retina of [his]249-bold- eye ; and as [he]249-bold- ate and drank [he]249-bold- still read in fancy the words thereon , although they were too remote for [his]249-bold- sight - "[231-boldwood] MARRY [ME]0-i . " The pert injunction was like those crystal substances which , colourless themselves , assume the tone of objects about them . Here , in the quiet of [[Boldwood]231-boldwood 's parlour]4192-boldwood 's parlour , where everything that , was not grave was extraneous , and where the atmosphere was that of [a Puritan Sunday lasting all the week]4193-a puritan sunday lasting all the week , the letter and its dictum changed "[726-the man] [their]1242-their tenor from the thoughtlessness of their origin to a deep solemnity , imbibed from their accessories now . Since the receipt of the missive in the morning , [Boldwood]231-boldwood had felt the symmetry of [his]231-boldwood existence to be slowly getting distorted in the direction of an ideal passion . The disturbance was as the first floating weed to [Columbus]250-columbus - the eontemptibly little suggesting possibilities of the infinitely great . The letter must have had an origin and a motive . That the latter was of the smallest magnitude com- patible with its existence at all , [Boldwood]231-boldwood , of course , did not know . And such an explanation did not strike [him]231-boldwood as a possibility even . It is foreign to a mystified condition of mind to realize of the mystifier that the processes of approving a course suggested by circumstance , and of striking out a course from inner impulse , would look the same in the result . The vast difference between starting a train of events , and direct- ing into a particular groove a series already started , is rarely apparent to [the person confounded by the issue]1243-the person confounded by the issue . When [Boldwood]231-boldwood went to bed [he]231-boldwood placed the valen- tine in the corner of the looking - glass . [He]231-boldwood was conscious of its presence , even when [his]231-boldwood back was turned upon it . It was the first time in [Boldwood]231-boldwood 's life that such an event had occurred . The same fascination that caused [him]231-boldwood to think it an act which had a deliberate motive prevented [him]231-boldwood from regarding it as an impertinence . [He]231-boldwood looked again at the direction . The mysterious influences of night invested the writing with the presence of [the unknown writer]1244-the unknown writer . [Somebody]3576-somebody 's [some woman]1246-some woman 's - hand had travelled softly over the paper bearing [his]231-boldwood name ; [her]1246-some woman unrevealed eyes had watched every curve as [she]1246-some woman formed it ; [her]1246-some woman brain had seen [him]231-boldwood in imagination the while . Why should [she]1246-some woman have imagined [him]231-boldwood ? [Her]1246-some woman mouth - were the lips red or pale , plump or creased ? - had curved itself to a certain expression as the pen went on - the corners had moved with all their natural tremulousness : what had been the expression ? The vision of [the woman]3527-the woman writing , as a supplement to the words written , had no individuality . [She]1246-some woman was a misty shape , and well [she]1246-some woman might be , considering that [her]1246-some woman original was at that moment sound asleep and oblivious of all love and letter - writing under the sky . [Whenever Boldwood]231-boldwood dozed [she]1246-some woman took a form , and com- paratively ceased to be a vision : when [he]231-boldwood awoke there was the letter justifying the dream . The moon shone to - night , and its light was not of a customary kind . [His]231-boldwood window admitted only a reflection of its rays , and the pale sheen had that reversed direction which snow gives , coming upward and lighting up [his]231-boldwood ceiling in an unnatural way , casting shadows in strange places , and putting lights where shadows had used to be . The substance of the epistle had occupied [him]231-boldwood but little in comparison with the fact of its arrival . [He]231-boldwood suddenly wondered if anything more might be found in the envelope than what [he]231-boldwood had withdrawn . [He]231-boldwood jumped out of bed in the weird light , took the letter , pulled out the flimsy sheet , shook the envelope - searched it . Nothing more was there . [Boldwood]231-boldwood looked , as [he]231-boldwood had a hundred times the preceding day , at the insistent red seal : " Marry [me]726-the man . "[726-the man] [he]231-boldwood said aloud . [The solemn and reserved yeoman]1248-the solemn and reserved yeoman again closed the letter , and stuck it in the frame of the glass . In doing so [he]231-boldwood caught sight of [his]231-boldwood reflected features , wan in expression , and insubstantial in form . [He]231-boldwood saw how closely compressed was [his]231-boldwood mouth , and that [his]231-boldwood eyes were wide - spread and vacant . Feeling uneasy and dis- satisfied with [himself]231-boldwood for this nervous excitability , [he]231-boldwood returned to bed . Then the dawn drew on . The full power of the clear heaven was not equal to that of a cloudy sky at noon , when [Boldwood]231-boldwood arose and dressed [himself]231-boldwood . [He]231-boldwood descended the stairs and went out towards the gate of [a field to the east]1249-a field to the east , leaning over which [he]231-boldwood paused and looked around . It was one of the usual slow sunrises of this time of the year , and the sky , pure violet in the zenith , was leaden to the northward , and murky to the east , where , over the snowy down or ewe - lease on [Weatherbury Upper Farm]52-weatherbury upper farm , and apparently resting upon [the ridge]1250-the ridge , the only half of the sun yet visible burnt rayless , like a red and flameless fire shining over a white hearthstone . The whole effect resembled a sunset as childhood resembles age . In other directions , [the fields]527-the fields and sky were so much of one colour by the snow , that it was difficult in a hasty glance to tell whereabouts the horizon occurred ; and in general there was here , too , that before - mentioned preternatural inversion of light and shade which attends the prospect when the garish brightness commonly in the sky is found on [the earth]1149-the earth , and the shades of earth are in the sky . Over the west hung the wasting moon , now dull and greenish - yellow , like tarnished brass . [Boldwood]231-boldwood was listlessly noting how the frost had hardened and glazed the surface of the snow , till it shone in the red eastern light wit - h the polish of marble ; how , in some portions of the slope , withered grass - bents , encased in icicles , bristled through the smooth wan coverlet in the twisted and curved shapes of old Venetian glass ; and how the footprints of a few birds , which had hopped over the snow whilst it lay in the state of a soft fleece , were now frozen to a short perma- nency . A half - muffled noise of light wheels interrupted [him]231-boldwood . [Boldwood]231-boldwood turned back into [the road]477-the road . It was [the mail - cart]1254-the mail - cart - [a crazy , two - wheeled vehicle]1255-a crazy , two - wheeled vehicle , hardly heavy enough to resist a puff of wind . [The driver]1256-the driver held out a letter . [Boldwood]231-boldwood seized it and opened it , ex- pecting another anonymous one - so greatly are [people]3461-people 's ideas of probability a mere sense that precedent will repeat itself . " [I]231-boldwood do n't think it is for [you]231-boldwood , [sir]3717-sir . "[231-boldwood] said [the man]726-the man , when [he]726-the man saw [Boldwood]231-boldwood 's action . " Though there is no name [I]0-i think it is for [[your]231-boldwood shepherd]4195-your shepherd . "[0-i] [Boldwood]231-boldwood looked then at the address - To [the New Shepherd]3819-the new shepherd , [Weatherbury Farm]61-weatherbury farm , Near [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge . " Oh - what a mistake ! - it is not [mine]0-i . Nor is it for [[my]1260-the man on the hill shepherd]4196-my shepherd . It is for [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene 's . "[1260-the man on the hill] [You]231-boldwood had better take it on to [him]3819-the new shepherd - [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel - and say [I]0-i opened it in mistake . " At this moment , on [the ridge]1250-the ridge , up against the blazing sky , [a figure]4198-a figure was visible , like the black snuff in the midst of a candle - flame . Then it moved and began to bustle about vigorously from place to place , carrying square skeleton masses , which were riddled by the same rays . [A small figure on all fours]4199-a small figure on all fours followed behind . The tall form was that of [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel ; the small one that of [George]166-george ; the articles in course of transit were hurdles . "[0-i] Wait , " said [Boldwood]231-boldwood . "[0-i] That 's [the man on [the hill]3452-the hill]1260-the man on the hill . [I]0-i 'll take the letter to [him]1260-the man on the hill [myself]0-i . " To [Boldwood]231-boldwood it was now no longer merely a letter to [I]0-i [another man]4200-another man . It was an opportunity . Exhibiting a face pregnant with intention , [he]231-boldwood entered [the snowy field]4201-the snowy field . [Gabriel]144-gabriel , at that minute , descended [the hill]3452-the hill towards the right . The glow stretched down in this direction now , and touched the distant roof of [Warren 's Malthouse]23-warren 's malthouse whither [the shepherd]528-the shepherd was apparently bent : [Boldwood]231-boldwood followed at a distance . CHAPTER XV THE scarlet and orange light outside [the malthouse]3832-the malthouse did not penetrate to [its]3832-the malthouse interior , which was , as usual , lighted by a rival glow of similar hue , radiating from the hearth . [The maltster]3839-the maltster , after having lain down in [his]3839-the maltster clothes for a few hours , was now sitting beside a three - legged table , breakfasting of bread and bacon . This was eaten on the plateless system , which is performed by placing a slice of bread upon the table , the meat flat upon the bread , a mustard plaster upon the meat , and a pinch of salt upon the whole , then cutting them vertically downwards with a large pocket - knife till wood is reached , when the severed lamp is impaled on the knife , elevated , and sent the proper way of food . [The maltster]3839-the maltster 's lack of teeth appeared not to sensibly diminish [his]3839-the maltster powers as [a mill]4207-a mill . [He]3839-the maltster had been without them for so many years that toothlessness was felt less to be a defect than hard gums an acquisition . Indeed , [he]3839-the maltster seemed to approach [the grave]4208-the grave as a hyperbolic curve approaches a straight line - less directly as [he]3839-the maltster got nearer , till it was doubtful if [he]3839-the maltster would ever reach it at all . In the ashpit was a heap of potatoes roasting , and a boiling pipkin of charred bread , called "[0-i] coffee . " for the benefit of whomsoever should call , for [Warren]185-warren 's was a sort of clubhouse . used as an alternative to the in ! "[1263-she] [I]0-i say , says [I]0-i , [we]1262-we get a fine day , and then down comes a snapper at night . " was a remark now suddenly heard spreading into the malthouse from the door , which had been opened the previous moment . The form of [Henery Fray]195-henery advanced to the fire , stamping the snow from [his]195-henery boots when about half - way there . The speech and entry had not seemed to be at all an abrupt begin- ning to [the maltster]3839-the maltster , introductory matter being often omitted in [this neighbourhood]4210-this neighbourhood , both from word and deed , and [the maltster]3839-the maltster having the same latitude allowed [him]3839-the maltster , did not hurry to reply . [He]3839-the maltster picked up a fragment of cheese , by pecking upon it with [his]3839-the maltster knife , as [a butcher]4212-a butcher picks up skewers . [Henery]195-henery appeared in a drab kerseymere great - coat , buttoned over [his]195-henery smock - frock , the white skirts of the latter being visible to the distance of about a foot below the coat - tails , which , when [you]4213-you got used to the style of dress , looked natural enough , and even ornamental - it certainly was comfortable . [Matthew Moon]181-matthew moon , [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph , and [other carters and waggoners]4214-other carters and waggoners followed at [his]195-henery heels , with great lanterns dangling from [their]4214-other carters and waggoners hands , which showed that [they]4214-other carters and waggoners had just come from [the cart - horse stables]4215-the cart - horse stables , where [they]4214-other carters and waggoners had been busily engaged since four o'clock that morning . "[1263-she] And how is [she]1263-she getting on without [a baily]1264-a baily ? " [the maltster]3839-the maltster inquired . [Henery]195-henery shook [his]195-henery head , and smiled one of the bitter smiles , dragging all the flesh of [his]195-henery forehead into a corrugated heap in the centre . "[1263-she] [She]1263-she 'll rue it - surely , surely ! " [he]195-henery said "[0-i] [Benjy Pennyways]251-pennyways were not [a true man]1265-a true man or [an honest baily]1266-an honest baily - as big a betrayer as [Judas Iscariot]149-judas iscariot [himself]149-judas iscariot . But to think [she]1263-she can carr ' on alone ! " [He]195-henery allowed [his]195-henery head to swing laterally three or four times in silence . "[1270-a headstrong maid] Never in all [my]0-i creeping up - never ! " This was recognized by all as the conclusion of some gloomy speech which had been expressed in thought alone during the shake of the head ; [Henery]195-henery meanwhile retained several marks of despair upon [his]195-henery face , to imply that they would be required for use again directly [he]195-henery should go on speaking . "[1274-a man in travel] All will be ruined , and [ourselves]1267-ourselves too , or there 's no meat in [[gentlemen]1268-gentlemen 's houses]1269-gentlemen 's houses ! " said [Mark Clark]178-mark clark . "[195-henery] [A headstrong maid]1270-a headstrong maid , that 's what [she]1270-a headstrong maid is - and wo n't listen to no advice at all . " "[1270-a headstrong maid] True , [Henery]195-henery , [you]195-henery do , [I]0-i 've heard [ye]195-henery . " said [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph in a voice of thorough attestation , and with a wire - drawn smile of misery . "[0-i] ' Twould do [a martel man]1275-a martel man no harm to have what 's under [her]1270-a headstrong maid bonnet . "[144-gabriel] said [the conclave]1284-the conclave . The door was flung back till it kicked the wall and trembled from top to bottom with the blow . "[1311-a dutchman] Now - [the first man in [the parish]422-the parish that [I]0-i hear prophesying bad of [[our]1308-we mistress]1309-our mistress]1306-the first man in the parish that i hear prophesying bad of our mistress , why " here the fist was raised and let fall as [T'hor]256-t'hor might have done with [his]256-t'hor hammer in assaying it - "[1311-a dutchman] [he]1310-he 'll smell and taste that - or [I]0-i 'm [a Dutchman]1311-a dutchman . CHAPTER XVI ALL SAINTS ' AND [ALL SOULS]4279-all souls ' ON a week - day morning [a small congregation , con- sisting mainly of [women]493-women and [girls]3618-girls]4280-a small congregation , con- sisting mainly of women and girls , rose from [its]4280-a small congregation , con- sisting mainly of women and girls knees in [the mouldy nave of [a church called [All Saints ']4285-all saints ']4284-a church called all saints ' , in [the distant barrack - town before mentioned]4286-the distant barrack - town before mentioned]4283-the mouldy nave of a church called all saints ' , in the distant barrack - town before mentioned , at the end of a service without a sermon . [They]4280-a small congregation , con- sisting mainly of women and girls were about to disperse , when a smart footstep , entering [the porch]4287-the porch and coming up [the central passage]4288-the central passage , arrested [their]4280-a small congregation , con- sisting mainly of women and girls attention . The step echoed with a ring unusual in [a church]4289-a church ; it was the clink of spurs . [Everybody]954-everybody looked . [A young cavalry soldier]4291-a young cavalry soldier in a red uniform , with the three chevrons of a sergeant upon [his]4291-a young cavalry soldier sleeve , strode up [the aisle]4292-the aisle , with an embarrassment which was only the more marked by the intense vigour of [his]4291-a young cavalry soldier step , and by the deter- mination upon [his]4291-a young cavalry soldier face to show none . A slight flush had mounted [his]4291-a young cavalry soldier cheek by the time [he]4291-a young cavalry soldier had run the gauntlet between [these women]4293-these women ; but , passing on through [the chancel arch]4294-the chancel arch , [he]4291-a young cavalry soldier never paused till [he]4291-a young cavalry soldier came close to the altar railing . Here for a moment [he]4291-a young cavalry soldier stood alone . [The officiating curate]4295-the officiating curate , who had not yet doffed [his]4295-the officiating curate surplice , perceived [the new - comer]4296-the new - comer , and followed [him]4295-the officiating curate to [the communion - space]4297-the communion - space . [He]4295-the officiating curate whispered to [the soldier]4298-the soldier , and then beckoned to [the clerk]905-the clerk , who in [his]905-the clerk turn whispered to [an elderly woman]4300-an elderly woman , apparently [[his]4291-a young cavalry soldier wife]4301-his wife , and [they]4302-they also went up [the chancel steps]4303-the chancel steps . "[224-boldwood] ' Tis a wedding ! " murmured [some of [the women]3489-the women]4304-some of the women , brightening . "[224-boldwood] Let 's wait ! " [The majority]4306-the majority again sat down . There was a creaking of machinery behind , and [some of [the young ones]4308-the young ones]4307-some of the young ones turned [their]4307-some of the young ones heads . From the interior face of the west wall of [the tower]4309-the tower projected a little canopy with a quarter - jack and small bell beneath it , the automaton being driven by the same clock machinery that struck the large bell in [the tower]4309-the tower . Be- tween [the tower]4309-the tower and [the church]489-the church was a close screen , the door of which was kept shut during services , hiding this grotesque clockwork from sight . At present , how- ever , the door was open , and the egress of the jack , the blows on the bell , and the mannikin 's retreat into.the nook again , were visible to [many]4313-many , and audible through- out [the church]489-the church . The jack had struck half - past eleven . "[3527-the woman] Where 's [the woman]3527-the woman ? " whispered [some of [the spectators]4316-the spectators]4315-some of the spectators . [The young sergeant]4317-the young sergeant stood still with the abnormal rigidity of the old pillars around . [He]4317-the young sergeant faced [the south- east]4318-the south- east , and was as silent as [he]4317-the young sergeant was still . The silence grew to be a noticeable thing as the minutes went on , and [nobody else]4319-nobody else appeared , and [not a soul]4320-not a soul moved . The rattle of the quarter - jack again from its niche , its blows for three - quarters , its fussy retreat , were almost painfully abrupt , and caused [many of [the congregation]4322-the congregation]4321-many of the congregation to start palpably . "[3527-the woman] [I]0-i wonder where [the woman]3527-the woman is ! " a voice whispered again . There began now that slight shifting of feet , that artificial coughing among several , which betrays a nervous suspense . At length there was a titter . But [the soldier]4298-the soldier never moved . There [he]4298-the soldier stood , [his]4298-the soldier face to the south - east , upright as a column , [his]4298-the soldier cap in [his]4298-the soldier hand . The clock ticked on . [The women]3489-the women threw off [their]3489-the women nervousness , and titters and giggling became more frequent . Then came a dead silence . [Every one]3841-every one was waiting for the end . [Some persons]4326-some persons may have noticed how extraordinarily the striking of quarters . seems to quicken the flight of time . It was hardly credible that [the jack]4327-the jack had not got wrong with the minutes when the rattle began again , the puppet emerged , and the four quarters were struck fitfully as before : [One]4328-one could al- most be positive that there was a malicious leer upon the hideous creature 's face , and a mischievous delight in its twitchings . Then , followed the dull and remote resonance of the twelve heavy strokes in [the tower above]4329-the tower above . [The women]3489-the women were impressed , and there was no giggle this time . [The clergyman]4331-the clergyman glided into [the vestry]798-the vestry , and [the clerk]905-the clerk vanished . [The sergeant]1330-the sergeant had not yet turned ; [every woman in [the church]489-the church]4335-every woman in the church was waiting to see [his]4298-the soldier face , and [he]4298-the soldier appeared to know it . At last [he]4298-the soldier did turn , and stalked resolutely down [the nave]4337-the nave , braving [them]3489-the women all , with a compressed lip . [Two bowed and toothless old almsmen]4338-two bowed and toothless old almsmen then looked at [each other]3826-each other and chuckled , innocently enough ; but the sound had a strange weird effect in that place . Opposite to [the church]489-the church was [a paved square]4341-a paved square , around which [several overhanging wood buildings of old time]4342-several overhanging wood buildings of old time cast a picturesque shade . [The young man on leaving the door]4343-the young man on leaving the door went to cross [the square]4344-the square , when , in the middle , [he]4298-the soldier met [a little woman]4345-a little woman . The expression of [her]4345-a little woman face , which had been one of intense anxiety , sank at the sight of [his]4298-the soldier nearly to terror . "[1355-you fool] Well ? " [he]4298-the soldier said , in a suppressed passion , fixedly looking at [her]4345-a little woman . "[1355-you fool] O , [Frank]244-frank - [I]0-i made a mistake ! - [I]0-i thought [that church with the spire]1353-that church with the spire was [All Saints ']59-all saints ' , and [I]0-i was at the door at half - past eleven to a minute as [you]244-frank said . waited till a quarter to twelve , and found then that [I]0-i was in [All Souls]4279-all souls ' . But [I]0-i was n't much frightened , for [I]0-i thought it could be to - morrow as well . " "[244-frank] [[You]244-frank fool]1355-you fool , for so fooling [me]0-i ! But say no more . " "[244-frank] Shall it be to - morrow , [Frank]244-frank ? " [she]4345-a little woman asked blankly . "[244-frank] To - morrow ! " and [he]244-frank gave vent to a hoarse laugh . "[244-frank] [I]0-i do n't go through that experience again for some time , [I]0-i warrant [you]244-frank ! " "[244-frank] But after all . " [she]4345-a little woman expostulated in a trembling voice , "[244-frank] the mistake was not such a terrible thing ! Now , [dear Frank]244-frank , when shall it be ? " "[167-miss everdene] Ah , when ? God knows ! " [he]244-frank said , with a light irony , and turning from [her]4345-a little woman walked rapidly away . CHAPTER XVII IN [THE MARKET]60-the market - PLACE ON Saturday [Boldwood]224-boldwood was in [Casterbridge market house]4346-casterbridge market house as usual , when [the disturber of]4347-the disturber of [his]224-boldwood dreams entered and became visible to [him]224-boldwood . [Adam]259-adam had awakened from [his]259-adam deep sleep , and behold ! there was [Eve]260-eve . [The farmer]3540-the farmer took courage , and for the first time really looked at [her]260-eve . Material causes and emotional effects are not to be arranged in regular equation . The result from capital employed in the production of any movement of a mental nature is sometimes as tremendous as the cause itself is absurdly minute . When [women]493-women are in a freakish mood , [their]493-women usual intuition , either from carelessness or inherent defect , seemingly fails to teach [them]493-women this , and hence it was that [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was fated to be astonished today . [Boldwood]224-boldwood looked at [her]260-eve - not slily , critically , or understandingly , but blankly at gaze , in the way [a reaper]4350-a reaper looks up at [a passing train]4351-a passing train - as something foreign to [his]224-boldwood element , and but dimly understood . To [Bold-]249-bold- wood [women]493-women had been remote phenomena rather than necessary complements - comets of such uncertain aspect , movement , and permanence , that whether [their]493-women orbits were as geometrical , unchangeable , and as subject to laws as [his]224-boldwood own , or as absolutely erratic as [they]493-women superficially appeared , [he]224-boldwood had not deemed it [his]224-boldwood duty to consider . [He]224-boldwood saw [her]260-eve black hair , [her]260-eve correct facial curves and profile , and the roundness of [her]260-eve chin and throat . [He]224-boldwood saw then the side of [her]260-eve eyelids , eyes , and lashes , and the shape of [her]260-eve ear . Next [he]224-boldwood noticed [her]260-eve figure , [her]260-eve skirt , and the very soles of [her]260-eve shoes . [Boldwood]224-boldwood thought [her]260-eve beautiful , but wondered whether [he]224-boldwood was right in [his]224-boldwood thought , for it seemed impossible that this romance in the flesh , if so sweet as [he]224-boldwood imagined , could have been going on long without creating a commotion of delight among [men]474-men , and pro- voking more inquiry than [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had done , even though that was not a little . To the best of [his]224-boldwood judge- ment neither nature nor art could improve [this perfect one of an imperfect many]4354-this perfect one of an imperfect many . [His]224-boldwood heart began to move within [him]224-boldwood . [Boldwood]224-boldwood , it must be remembered , though forty years of age , had never before inspected [a woman with the very centre and force of]4355-a woman with the very centre and force of [his]224-boldwood glance ; [they]4355-a woman with the very centre and force of had struck upon all [his]224-boldwood senses at wide angles . Was [she]260-eve really beautiful ? [He]224-boldwood could not assure [himself]224-boldwood that [his]224-boldwood opinion was true even now . [He]224-boldwood fur- tively said to [a neighbour]4356-a neighbour , "[1357-a very handsome girl] Is [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene considered handsome ? " "[1358-the injured lover] O yes ; [she]167-miss everdene was a good deal noticed the first time [she]167-miss everdene came , if [you]1356-you remember . [A very handsome girl]1357-a very handsome girl indeed . " [A man]3474-a man is never more credulous than in receiving favourable opinions on the beauty of [a woman [he]3474-a man is half , or quite , in love with]4358-a woman he is half , or quite , in love with ; [a mere child]4359-a mere child 's word on the point has the weight of an R.A. 's . [Boldwood]224-boldwood was satisfied now . And [this charming woman]4360-this charming woman had in effect said to [him]224-boldwood , "[1358-the injured lover] Marry [me]0-i . " Why should [she]4360-this charming woman have done that strange thing ? [Boldwood]224-boldwood 's blindness to the difference between approving of what circumstances suggest , and originating what [they]4361-they do not suggest , was well matched by [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's insensibility to the possibly great issues of little beginnings . [She]4360-this charming woman was at this moment coolly dealing with [a dashing young farmer]4362-a dashing young farmer , adding up accounts with [him]4362-a dashing young farmer as indiffer- ently as if [his]4362-a dashing young farmer face had been the pages of a ledger . It was evident that such a nature as [his]224-boldwood had no attraction for [a woman of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba]4363-a woman of bathsheba 's taste . But [Boldwood]224-boldwood grew hot down to [his]224-boldwood hands with an incipient jealousy ; [he]224-boldwood trod for the first time the threshold of "[1358-the injured lover] [the injured lover]1358-the injured lover 's hell . " [His]224-boldwood first impulse was to go and thrust [himself]224-boldwood between [them]4364-them . This could be done , but only in one way - by asking to see a sample of [her]4360-this charming woman corn . [Boldwood]224-boldwood renounced the idea . [He]224-boldwood could not make the request ; it was debasing loveliness to ask it to buy and sell , and jarred with [his]224-boldwood conceptions of [her]4360-this charming woman . All this time [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was conscious of having broken into that dignified stronghold at last . [His]224-boldwood eyes , [she]4360-this charming woman knew , were following [her]4360-this charming woman everywhere . This was a triumph ; and had it come naturally , such a triumph would have been the sweeter to [her]4360-this charming woman for this piquing delay . But it had been brought about by misdirected ingenuity , and [she]4360-this charming woman valued it only as [she]4360-this charming woman valued an artificial flower or a wax fruit . Being [a woman with some good sense in reasoning on subjects wherein [her]4360-this charming woman heart was not involved]4365-a woman with some good sense in reasoning on subjects wherein her heart was not involved , [Bath-]168-bath- sheba [sheba]243-bathsheba genuinely repented that a freak which had owed its existence as much to [Liddy]191-liddy as to [herself]243-bathsheba , should ever have been undertaken , to disturb the placidity of [a man [she]4360-this charming woman respected too highly to deliberately tease]4366-a man she respected too highly to deliberately tease . [She]4360-this charming woman that day nearly formed the intention of begging [his]224-boldwood pardon on the very next occasion of [their]4367-their meeting . The worst features of this arrangement were that , if [he]224-boldwood thought [she]4360-this charming woman ridiculed [him]224-boldwood , an apology would in- crease the offence by being disbelieved ; and if [he]224-boldwood thought [she]4360-this charming woman wanted [him]224-boldwood to woo [her]4360-this charming woman , it would read like additional evidence of [her]4360-this charming woman forwardness . CHAPTER XVIII [BOLDWOOD]224-boldwood IN MEDITATION - REGRET [BOLDWOOD]224-boldwood was tenant of what was called [Little Weatherbury Farm]61-weatherbury farm , and [[his]224-boldwood person]4368-his person was the nearest ap- proach to aristocracy that [this remoter quarter of [the parish]422-the parish]4369-this remoter quarter of the parish could boast of . [Genteel strangers]4371-genteel strangers , whose god was [[their]4371-genteel strangers town]4372-their town , who might happen to be compelled to linger about [this nook]4373-this nook for a day , heard the sound of light wheels , and prayed to see good society , to the degree of [a solitary lord]4374-a solitary lord , or [squire]4375-squire at the very least , but it was only [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood going out for the day . [They]4371-genteel strangers heard the sound of wheels yet once more , and were re - animated to expectancy : it was only [Mr. Bold- wood]249-bold- coming [home]556-home again . [[His]224-boldwood house]637-his house stood recessed from [the road]477-the road , and [the stables]4379-the stables , which are to [a farm]4380-a farm what a fireplace is to [a room]4381-a room , were behind , [their]4379-the stables lower portions being lost amid bushes of laurel . Inside the blue door , open half - way down , were to be seen at this time the backs and tails of half - a - dozen warm and contented horses standing in [[their]4379-the stables stalls]4382-their stalls ; and as thus viewed , [they]4379-the stables pre- sented alternations of roan and bay , in shapes like a Moorish arch , the tail being a streak down the midst of each . Over these , and lost to the eye gazing in from the outer light , the mouths of the same animals could be heard busily sustaining the above - named warmth and plumpness by quantities of oats and hay . The restless and shadowy figure of [a colt]4383-a colt wandered about a loose - box at the end , whilst the steady grind of all the eaters was occasionally diversified by the rattle of a rope or the stamp of a foot . Pacing up and down at the heels of the animals was [Farmer Boldwood]231-boldwood [himself]224-boldwood . [This place]561-this place was [[his]224-boldwood almonry and cloister]4385-his almonry and cloister in one : here , after looking to the feeding of [[his]224-boldwood four - footed dependants]4386-his four - footed dependants , [the celibate]4387-the celibate would walk and meditate of an evening till the moon 's rays streamed in through the cobwebbed windows , or total darkness enveloped the scene . [His]224-boldwood square - framed perpendicularity showed more fully now than in the crowd and bustle of [the market - house]4388-the market - house . In this meditative walk [his]224-boldwood foot met the floor with heel and toe simultaneously , and [his]224-boldwood fine reddish - fleshed face was bent downwards just enough to render obscure the still mouth and the well - rounded though rather prominent and broad chin . A few clear and thread - like horizontal lines were the only interruption to the otherwise smooth surface of [his]224-boldwood large forehead . The phases of [Boldwood]224-boldwood 's life were ordinary enough , but [his]224-boldwood was not an ordinary nature . That stillness , which struck [casual observers]4389-casual observers more than anything else in [his]224-boldwood character and habit , and seemed so precisely like the rest of inanition , may have been the perfect balance of enormous antagonistic forces - positives and negatives in fine adjustment . [His]224-boldwood equilibrium disturbed , [he]224-boldwood was in extremity at once . If an emotion possessed [him]224-boldwood at all , it ruled [him]224-boldwood ; a feeling not mastering [him]224-boldwood was entirely latent . Stagnant or rapid , it was never slow . [He]224-boldwood was always hit mortally , or [he]224-boldwood was missed . [He]224-boldwood had no light and careless touches in [his]224-boldwood constitu- tion , either for good or for evil . Stern in the outlines of action , mild in the details , [he]224-boldwood was serious throughout all . [He]224-boldwood saw no absurd sides to the follies of life , and thus , though not quite companionable in the eyes of [merry men]4390-merry men and [scoffers]4391-scoffers , and [those to whom all things show life as a jest]4392-those to whom all things show life as a jest , [he]224-boldwood was not intolerable to [the earnest and those acquainted with grief]4393-the earnest and those acquainted with grief . Being [a man]3474-a man -who read all the dramas of life seriously , if [he]224-boldwood failed to please when they were comedies , there was no frivolous treat- ment to reproach [him]224-boldwood for when [they]4395-they chanced to end tragically . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was far from dreaming that the dark and silent shape upon which [she]4396-her had so carelessly thrown a seed was a hotbed of tropic intensity . Had [she]4396-her known [Boldwood]224-boldwood 's moods , [her]4396-her blame would have been fearful , and the stain upon [her]4396-her heart ineradicable . Moreover , had [she]4396-her known [her]4396-her present power for good or evil over [this man]4150-this man , [she]4396-her would have trembled at [her]4396-her responsibility . Luckily for [her]4396-her present , unluckily for [her]4396-her future tran- quillity , [her]4396-her understanding had not yet told [her]4396-her what [Boldwood]224-boldwood was . [Nobody]439-nobody knew entirely ; for though it was possible to form guesses concerning [his]224-boldwood wild capa- bilities from old floodmarks faintly visible , [he]224-boldwood had never been seen at the high tides which caused them . [Farmer Boldwood]231-boldwood came to [the stable]4399-the stable - door and looked forth across [the level fields]4400-the level fields . Beyond the first enclosure was a hedge , and on the other side of this a meadow belonging to [[Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's farm]4401-bathsheba 's farm . It was now early spring - the time of going to grass with the sheep , when [they]4402-they have the first feed of [the meadows]4403-the meadows , before these are laid up for mowing . The wind , which had been blowing east for several weeks , had veered to the southward , and the middle of spring had come abruptly - almost without a beginning . It was that period in [the vernal quarter]4404-the vernal quarter when [we]4405-we map suppose [the Dryads]261-the dryads to be waking for the season . [The vegetable world]4406-the vegetable world begins to move and swell and the saps to rise , till in the completest silence of [lone gardens]4407-lone gardens and [trackless plantations]4408-trackless plantations , where- everything seems -help- less and still after the bond and slavery of frost , there are bustlings , strainings , united thrusts , and pulls - all- together , in comparison with which the powerful tugs of cranes and pulleys in [a noisy city]4409-a noisy city are but pigmy efforts . [Boldwood]224-boldwood , looking into [the distant meadows]4410-the distant meadows , saw there [three figures]4411-three figures . [They]4411-three figures were those of [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene , [Shepherd Oak]192-shepherd oak , and [Cainy Ball]252-cainy . When [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's figure shone upon [the farmer]3540-the farmer 's eyes it lighted [him]224-boldwood up as the moon lights up [a great tower]4413-a great tower . [A man]3474-a man 's body is as the shell ; or the tablet , of [his]3474-a man soul , as [he]3474-a man is reserved or ingenuous , overflowing or self - contained . There was a change in [Boldwood]224-boldwood 's exterior from its former impassibleness ; and [his]224-boldwood face showed that [he]224-boldwood was now living outside [his]224-boldwood defences for the first time , and with a fearful sense of exposure . It is the usual experience of strong natures when [they]4415-they love . At last [he]224-boldwood arrived at a conclusion . It was to go across and inquire boldly of [her]4416-her . The insulation of [his]224-boldwood heart by reserve during these many years , without a channel of any kind for disposable emotion , had worked its effect . It has been observed more than once that the causes of love are chiefly subjective , and [Boldwood]224-boldwood was a living testimony to the truth of the proposition . [No mother]4417-no mother existed to absorb [his]224-boldwood devotion , [no sister]4418-no sister for [his]224-boldwood tenderness , no idle ties for sense . [He]224-boldwood became surcharged with the compound , which was genuine [lover]4419-lover 's love . [He]224-boldwood approached the gate of [the meadow]4420-the meadow . Beyond [it]4421-it [the ground]4422-the ground was melodious with ripples , and the sky with larks ; the low bleating of the flock mingling with both . [Mistress]996-mistress and [man]3450-man were engaged in the operation of making a lamb "[1358-the injured lover] take . " which is performed whenever an ewe has lost [[her]996-mistress own offspring]4425-her own offspring , [one of [the twins of [another ewe]4428-another ewe]4427-the twins of another ewe being given [her]996-mistress as a substitute]4426-one of the twins of another ewe being given her as a substitute . [Gabriel]144-gabriel had skinned the dead lamb , and was tying the skin over the body of the live lamb , in the customary manner , whilst [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was holding open a little pen of four hurdles , into which [the Mother and foisted lamb]4429-the mother and foisted lamb were driven , where [they]4429-the mother and foisted lamb would remain till [the old sheep]4430-the old sheep conceived an affection for [the young one]4431-the young one . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba looked up at the completion of the manouvre , and saw [the farmer]3540-the farmer by the gate , where [he]3540-the farmer was overhung by a willow tree in full bloom . [He]224-boldwood was still in [the road]477-the road , and by moving on [he]224-boldwood hoped that [neither]4434-neither would recognize that [he]224-boldwood had originally intended to enter [the field]3467-the field . The cabala of this erotic philosophy seemed to consist of the subtlest meanings expressed in misleading ways . Every turn , look , word , and accent contained a mystery quite distinct from its obvious import , and not one had ever been pondered by [him]224-boldwood until now . [She]996-mistress resolved never again , by look or by sign , to interrupt the steady flow of [this man]4150-this man 's life . But a resolution to avoid an evil is seldom framed till the evil is so far advanced as to make avoidance impossible . CHAPTER XIX [THE SHEEP - WASHING - THE OFFER BOLDWOOD]262-the sheep - washing - the offer boldwood did eventually call upon [her]996-mistress . [She]996-mistress was not at [home]556-home . "[1358-the injured lover] Of course not . " [he]231-boldwood murmured . In con- templating [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba as [a woman]459-a woman , [he]231-boldwood had forgotten the accidents of [her]996-mistress position as [an agriculturist]4448-an agriculturist - that being as much of [a farmer]3716-a farmer , and as extensive [a farmer]3716-a farmer , as [himself]231-boldwood , [her]996-mistress probable whereabouts was out - of - doors at this time of the year . This , and the other oversights [Boldwood]231-boldwood was guilty of , were natural to the mood , and still more natural to the circumstances . The great aids to idealization in love were present here : occasional observation of [her]996-mistress from a distance , and the absence of social intercourse with [her]996-mistress - visual familiarity , oral strangeness . The smaller human elements were kept out of sight ; the pettinesses that enter so largely into all earthly living and doing were disguised by the accident of [lover]4419-lover and [loved]4452-loved - one not being on visiting terms ; and there was hardly awakened a thought in [Boldwood]231-boldwood that sorry [household]4453-household realities appertained to [her]996-mistress , or that [she]996-mistress , like [all others]4454-all others , had moments of commonplace , when to be least plainly seen was to be most prettily remembered . Thus a mild sort of apotheosis took place in [his]231-boldwood fancy , whilst [she]996-mistress still lived and breathed within [his]231-boldwood own horizon , [a troubled creature like [himself]231-boldwood]4455-a troubled creature like himself . It was the end of May when [the farmer determined to be no longer repulsed by trivialities or distracted by suspense]4456-the farmer determined to be no longer repulsed by trivialities or distracted by suspense . [He]231-boldwood had by this time grown used to being in love ; the passion now startled [him]231-boldwood less even when it tortured [him]231-boldwood more , and [he]231-boldwood felt [himself]231-boldwood adequate to the situation . On inquiring for [her]996-mistress at [[her]996-mistress house]4457-her house [they]4458-they had told [him]231-boldwood [she]996-mistress was at the sheepwashing , and [he]231-boldwood went off to seek [her]996-mistress there . [The sheep - washing pool]4459-the sheep - washing pool was [a perfectly circular basin of brickwork in [the meadows]4403-the meadows]4460-a perfectly circular basin of brickwork in the meadows , full of the clearest water . To birds on the wing [its]4459-the sheep - washing pool glassy surface , reflecting the light sky , must have been visible for miles around as a glistening Cyclops ' eye in a green face . The grass about the margin at this season was a sight to remember long - in a minor sort of way . Its activity in sucking the moisture from the rich damp sod . was almost a pro- cess observable by the eye . [The outskirts of [this level water - meadow]4463-this level water - meadow]4462-the outskirts of this level water - meadow were diversified by [rounded and hollow pastures]4464-rounded and hollow pastures , where just now every flower that was not a buttercup was a daisy . [The river]1150-the river slid along noiselessly as a shade , the swelling reeds and sedge forming a flexible palisade upon [its]1150-the river moist brink . To the north of [the mead]4466-the mead were trees , the leaves of which were new , soft , and moist , not yet having stiffened and darkened under summer sun and drought , their colour being yellow beside a green - green beside a yellow . From the recesses of this knot of foliage the loud notes of three cuckoos were resounding through the still air . [Boldwood]231-boldwood went meditating down [the slopes]4467-the slopes with [his]231-boldwood eyes on [his]231-boldwood boots , which the yellow pollen from the buttercups had bronzed in artistic gradations . A tribu- tary of the main stream flowed through the basin of the pool by an inlet and outlet at opposite points of [its]4459-the sheep - washing pool diameter . [Shepherd Oak]192-shepherd oak , [Jan Coggan]180-coggan , Moon , Poor- grass , [Cain Ball]235-cain , and several others were assembled [here]575-here , all dripping wet to the very roots of [their]4469-their hair , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was standing by in a new riding - habit - the most elegant [she]4470-she had ever worn - the reins of [her]4470-she horse being looped over [her]4470-she arm . Flagons of cider were rolling about upon [the green]4471-the green . [The meek sheep]4472-the meek sheep were pushed into the pool by [Coggan]180-coggan and [Matthew Moon]181-matthew moon , who stood by the lower hatch , immersed to [their]4469-their waists ; then [Gabriel]144-gabriel , who stood on the brink , thrust [them]4472-the meek sheep under as [they]4472-the meek sheep swam along , with an instrument like a crutch , formed for the purpose , and also for assisting the exhausted animals when the wool became saturated and [they]4472-the meek sheep began to sink . [They]4472-the meek sheep were let out against [the stream]668-the stream , and through the upper opening , all impurities flowing away below . [Cainy Ball]252-cainy and [Joseph]196-joseph , who performed this latter operation , were if possible wetter than the rest ; [they]4469-their resembled dolphins under a fountain , every protuberance and angle of [their]4469-their clothes dribbling forth a small rill . [Boldwood]231-boldwood came close and bade [her]4470-she good - morning , with such constraint that [she]4470-she could not but think [he]231-boldwood had stepped across to the washing for its own sake , hoping not to find [her]4470-she there ; more , [she]4470-she fancied [his]231-boldwood brow severe and [his]231-boldwood eye slighting . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba immediately contrived to withdraw , and glided along by [the river]1150-the river till [she]4470-she was a stone 's throw off . [She]4470-she heard footsteps brushing the grass , and had a consciousness that love was encircling [her]4470-she like a perfume . Instead of turning or waiting , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba went further among the high sedges , but [Boldwood]231-boldwood seemed determined , and pressed on till [they]4475-they were completely past [the bend of [the river]1150-the river]4476-the bend of the river . Here , without being seen , [they]4475-they could hear the splashing and shouts of [the washers above]4478-the washers above . "[1358-the injured lover] [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene ! " said [the farmer]3540-the farmer . [She]167-miss everdene trembled , turned , and said "[0-i] Good morning . " [His]231-boldwood tone was so utterly removed from all [she]167-miss everdene had expected as a beginning . It was lowness and quiet accentuated : an emphasis of deep meanings , their form , at the same time , being scarcely expressed . Silence has sometimes a remarkable power of showing itself as the disembodied soul of feeling wandering without its carcase , and it is then more impressive than speech . In the same way , to say a little is often to tell more than to say a great deal . [Boldwood]231-boldwood told everything in that word . As the consciousness expands on learning that what was fancied to be the rumble of wheels is the reverbera- tion of thunder , so did [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's at [her]167-miss everdene intuitive conviction . "[0-i] [I]0-i feel - almost too much - to think . " [he]231-boldwood said , with a solemn simplicity . "[0-i] [I]0-i have come to speak to [you]167-miss everdene with- out preface . [My]0-i life is not [my]0-i own since [I]0-i have beheld [you]167-miss everdene clearly , [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene - [I]0-i come to make [you]167-miss everdene an offer of marriage . " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba tried to preserve an absolutely neutral countenance , and all the motion [she]167-miss everdene made was that of closing lips which had previously been a little parted . "[0-i] [I]0-i am now forty - one years old . " [he]3655-a husband went on . "[167-miss everdene] [I]0-i may have been called [a confirmed bachelor]1359-a confirmed bachelor , and [I]0-i was [a confirmed bachelor]1359-a confirmed bachelor . [I]0-i had never any views of [myself]0-i as [a husband]3655-a husband in [my]0-i earlier days , nor have [I]0-i made any calculation on the subject since [I]0-i have been older . But [we]1362-we all change , and [my]0-i change , in this matter , came with seeing [you]167-miss everdene . CHAPTER XX PERPLEXITY - [GRINDING THE SHEARS]264-grinding the shears - A QUARREL "[0-i] [HE]249-bold- is so disinterested and kind to offer [me]0-i all that [I]0-i can desire . " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba mused . Yet [Farmer Boldwood]231-boldwood , whether by nature kind or the reverse to kind , did not exercise kindness , here . The rarest offerings of the purest loves are but a self- indulgence , and no generosity at all . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , not being the least in love with [him]224-boldwood , was eventually able to look calmly at [his]224-boldwood offer . It was one which [many women of [her]0-i own station in [the neighbour- hood]4497-the neighbour- hood]4496-many women of her own station in the neighbour- hood , and [not a few of higher rank]4498-not a few of higher rank , would have been wild to accept and proud to publish . In every point of view , ranging from politic to passionate , it was desirable that [she]0-i , [a lonely girl]4499-a lonely girl , should marry , and marry [this earnest , well - to - do , and respected man]4500-this earnest , well - to - do , and respected man . [He]224-boldwood was close to [her]0-i doors : [his]224-boldwood standing was sufficient : [his]224-boldwood qualities were even supererogatory . Had [she]0-i felt , which [she]0-i did not , any wish whatever for the married state in the abstract , [she]0-i could not reasonably have rejected [him]224-boldwood , being [a woman who frequently appealed to [her]0-i under]4501-a woman who frequently appealed to her under , standing for deliverance from [her]0-i whims . [Boldwood]224-boldwood as a means to marriage was unexceptionable : [she]0-i esteemed and liked [him]224-boldwood , yet [she]0-i did not want [him]224-boldwood . It appears that [ordinary men]3934-ordinary men take [wives]4503-wives because possession is not possible without marriage , and that [ordinary women]4504-ordinary women accept [husbands]895-husbands because marriage is not possible with , out possession ; with totally differing aims the method is the same on both sides . But the understood incentive on [the woman]3527-the woman 's part was wanting [here]575-here . Besides , [Bath- sheba]168-bath- sheba 's position as [absolute mistress of [a farm]4380-a farm and [house]4510-house]4508-absolute mistress of a farm and house was a novel one , and the novelty had not yet begun to wear off . But a disquiet filled [her]0-i which was somewhat to [her]0-i credit , for it would have affected [few]4511-few . Beyond the men- tioned reasons with which [she]0-i combated [her]0-i objections , [she]0-i had a strong feeling that , having been [the one who began the game]4512-the one who began the game , [she]0-i ought in honesty to accept the conse- quences . Still the reluctance remained . [She]0-i said in the same breath that it would be ungenerous not to marry [Boldwood]224-boldwood , and that [she]0-i could n't do it to save [her]0-i life . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's was an impulsive nature under a delibera- tive aspect . An [Elizabeth]265-elizabeth in brain and a [Mary Stuart]266-maryann in spirit , [she]0-i often performed actions of the greatest temerity with a manner of extreme discretion . Many of [her]0-i thoughts were perfect syllogisms ; unluckily they always remained thoughts . Only a few were irrational assumptions ; but , unfortunately , they were the ones which most frequently grew into deeds . The next day to that of the declaration [she]0-i found [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel at the bottom of [[her]0-i garden]4513-her garden , grinding [his]144-gabriel shears for the sheep - shearing . All [the surrounding cottages]4514-the surrounding cottages were more or less scenes of the same operation ; the scurr of whetting spread into the sky from [all parts of [the village]3754-the village]4515-all parts of the village as from an armury previous to a campaign . Peace and war kiss each other at [their]4517-their hours of prepara- tion - sickles , scythes , shears , and pruning - hooks , ranking with swords , bayonets , and lances , in [their]4517-their common necessity for point and edge . [Cainy Ball]252-cainy turned the handle of [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's grindstone , [his]252-cainy head performing a melancholy see - saw up and down with each turn of the wheel . [Oak]144-gabriel stood somewhat as [Eros]267-eros is represented when in the act of sharpening [his]267-eros arrows : [his]267-eros figure slightly bent , the weight of [his]267-eros body thrown over on the shears , and [his]267-eros head balanced side- ways , with a critical compression of the lips and contrac- tion of the eyelids to crown the attitude . [[His]267-eros mistress]4518-his mistress came up and looked upon [them]4519-them in silence for a minute or two ; then [she]0-i said - "[0-i] [Cain]235-cain , go to [the lower mead]1370-the lower mead and catch the bay mare . [I]0-i 'll turn the winch of the grindstone . [I]0-i want to speak to [you]235-cain , [Gabriel]144-gabriel . [Cain]235-cain departed , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba took the handle . [Gabriel]144-gabriel had glanced up in intense surprise , quelled its expression , and looked down again . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba turned the winch , and [Gabriel]144-gabriel applied the shears . The peculiar motion involved in turning a wheel has a wonderful tendency to benumb the mind . It is a sort of attenuated variety of [Ixion]268-ixion 's punishment , and contributes a dismal chapter to the history of heavy , and the body 's centre of gravity seems to settle by degrees in a leaden lump somewhere be- tween the eyebrows and the crown . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba felt the unpleasant symptoms after two or three dozen turns . " Will [you]144-gabriel turn , [Gabriel]144-gabriel , and let [me]3799-the men hold the shears ? "[3799-the men] [she]0-i said . " [My]3799-the men head is in a'whirl , and [I]3799-the men ca n't talk . [Gabriel]144-gabriel turned . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba then began , with some awkwardness , allowing [her]0-i thoughts to stray occasion- ally from [her]0-i story to attend to the shears , which required a little nicety in sharpening . "[3799-the men] [I]0-i wanted to ask [you]235-cain if [the men]3799-the men made any observa- tions on [my]0-i going behind the sedge with [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood yesterday ? " "[243-bathsheba] Yes , [they]3799-the men did . " said [Gabriel]144-gabriel . "[0-i] said [Gabriel]144-gabriel bitterly , and going on with [his]144-gabriel turning , [his]144-gabriel words rising and falling in a regular swell and cadence as [he]144-gabriel stooped or rose with the winch , which directed them , according to [his]144-gabriel position , perpendicularly into [the earth]1149-the earth , or horizontally along [the garden]3633-the garden , [his]144-gabriel eyes being fixed on a leaf upon the ground . With [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba a hastened act was a rash act ; but , as does not always happen , time gained was prudence insured . It must be added , however , that time was very seldom gained . At this period the single opinion in [the parish]422-the parish on [herself]243-bathsheba and [her]0-i doings that [she]0-i valued as sounder than [her]0-i own was [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel 's . And the outspoken honesty of [his]144-gabriel character was such- that on any subject even that of [her]0-i love for , or marriage with , [another man]4200-another man , the same disinter- estedness of opinion might be calculated on , and be had for the asking . Thoroughly convinced of the impossibility of [his]144-gabriel own suit , a high resolve constrained [him]144-gabriel not to injure that of another . This is [a lover]1382-a lover 's most stoical virtue , as the lack of it is [a lover]1382-a lover 's most venial sin . Knowing [he]144-gabriel would reply truly , [she]0-i asked the question , painful as [she]0-i must have known the sub- ject would be . Such is the selfishness of [some charm- ing women]1384-some charm- ing women . Perhaps it was some excuse for [her]0-i thus torturing honesty to [her]0-i own advantage , that [she]0-i had absolutely no other sound judgment within easy reach . " Well , what is [your]144-gabriel opinion of [my]0-i conduct . "[0-i] [she]0-i said , quietly . " [A woman]459-a woman may be treated with a bitterness which is sweet to [her]459-a woman , and with a rudeness which is not offensive . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba would have submitted to an indignant chastisement for [her]0-i levity had [Gabriel]144-gabriel pro- tested that [he]144-gabriel was loving [her]0-i at the same time ; the impetuosity of passion unrequited is bearable , even if it stings and anathematizes there is a triumph in the humiliation , and a tenderness in the strife . This was what [she]0-i had been expecting , and what [she]0-i had not got . To be lectured because [the lecturer]4526-the lecturer saw [her]0-i in the cold morning light of open - shuttered disillusion was exasperating . [He]4526-the lecturer had not finished , either . [He]4526-the lecturer continued in a more agitated voice : - "[0-i] [My]0-i opinion is since [you]1386-you ask it that [you]1386-you are greatly to blame for playing pranks upon [a man like [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood]1387-a man like mr. boldwood , merely as a pastime . " It may have been a peculiarity - at any rate it was a fact - that when [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was swayed by an emotion of an earthly sort [her]0-i lower lip trembled : when by a refined emotion , [her]0-i upper or heavenward one . [Her]0-i nether lip quivered now . "[0-i] Very well , so [I]0-i will . " said [Gabriel]144-gabriel calmly . [He]144-gabriel had been held to [her]0-i by a beautiful thread which it pained [him]144-gabriel to spoil by breaking , rather than by a chain [he]144-gabriel could not break . "[0-i] [I]0-i should be even better pleased to go at once . " [he]144-gabriel added . "[0-i] Go at once then , in [Heaven]269-heaven 's name ! " said [she]0-i , [her]0-i eyes flashing at [his]1386-you , though never meeting [them]1386-you . "[167-miss everdene] Do n't let [me]0-i see [your]1386-you face any more . " "[272-sixty] Very well , [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene - so it shall be . " And [he]1386-you took [his]1386-you shears and went away from [her]0-i in placid dignity , as [Moses]270-moses left the presence of [Pharaoh]271-pharaoh . CHAPTER XXI TROUBLES IN [THE FOLD]4527-the fold - A MESSAGE [GABRIEL OAK]144-gabriel had ceased to feed [the Weatherbury flock]4528-the weatherbury flock for about four - and - twenty hours , when on Sunday afternoon [the elderly gentlemen]4529-the elderly gentlemen [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph , [Matthew Moon]181-matthew moon , [Fray]195-henery , and [half - a - dozen others]4530-half - a - dozen others , came running up to [the house of [the mistress of [the Upper Farm]4533-the upper farm]4532-the mistress of the upper farm]4531-the house of the mistress of the upper farm . "[272-sixty] Whatever is the matter , [men]474-men ? " [she]0-i said , meeting [them]474-men at the door just as [she]0-i was coming out on [her]0-i way to [church]424-church , and ceasing in a moment from the close compression of [her]0-i two red lips , with which [she]0-i had accompanied the exertion of pulling on a tight glove . "[272-sixty] [Sixty]272-sixty ! " said [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph . "[262-the sheep - washing - the offer boldwood] Seventy ! " said [Moon]181-matthew moon . "[262-the sheep - washing - the offer boldwood] Fifty - nine ! " said [[Susan Tall]211-susan tall 's husband]935-susan tall 's husband . "[262-the sheep - washing - the offer boldwood] - [Sheep]262-the sheep - washing - the offer boldwood have broke fence . " said [Fray]195-henery . "[273-clover] - And got into [a field of young clover]1392-a field of young clover . " said [Tall]211-susan tall . "[273-clover] - Young clover ! " said [Moon]181-matthew moon . "[1393-they] - [Clover]273-clover ! " said [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph . "[1393-they] And [they]1393-they be getting blasted . " said [Henery Fray]195-henery . "[196-joseph] That [they]1393-they be . " said [Joseph]196-joseph . "[196-joseph] And will all die as dead as nits , if [they]1393-they bain't got out and cured!'said [Tall]211-susan tall . [Joseph]196-joseph 's countenance was drawn into lines and puckers by [his]196-joseph concern . [Fray]195-henery 's forehead was wrinkled both perpendicularly and crosswise , after the pattern of a portcullis , expressive of a double despair . [Laban Tall]211-susan tall 's lips were thin , and [his]1394-his face were rigid . [Matthew]181-matthew moon 's jaws sank , and [his]181-matthew moon eyes turned whichever way the strongest muscle happened to pull them . " Yes . "[196-joseph] said [Joseph]196-joseph , " and [I]196-joseph was sitting at [home]556-home , looking for [Ephesians]274-ephesians , and says [I]196-joseph to [myself]196-joseph , "[196-joseph] ' Tis nothing but Corinthians and [Thessalonians]63-thessalonians in this danged Testament . "[1398-the stupid numskulls] That 's enought - that 's enough ! - oh , [[you]1395-you fools]1396-you fools ! " [she]0-i cried , throwing the parasol and Prayer - book into [the passage]4537-the passage , and running out of doors in the direction signified . "[1398-the stupid numskulls] To come to [me]0-i , and not go and get [them]1397-them out directly ! Oh , [the stupid numskulls]1398-the stupid numskulls ! " [Her]0-i eyes were at their darkest and brightest now . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's beauty belonged rather to [the demonian]4538-the demonian than to [the angelic school]4539-the angelic school , [she]0-i never looked so well as when [she]0-i was angry - and particularly when the effect was heightened by a rather dashing velvet dress , care- fully put on before a glass . [All the ancient men]4540-all the ancient men ran in a jumbled throng after [her]0-i to [the clover - field]4541-the clover - field , [Joseph]196-joseph sinking down in the midst when about half - way , like [an individual withering in a world which was more and more insupportable]4542-an individual withering in a world which was more and more insupportable . The majority of the afflicted animals were lying down , and could not be stirred . [These]4543-these were bodily lifted out , and [the others]3772-the others driven into [the adjoining field]4545-the adjoining field . Here , after the lapse of a few minutes , [several more fell down]4546-several more fell down , and lay helpless and livid as [the rest]4547-the rest . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , with a sad , bursting heart , looked at these primest specimens of [[her]0-i prime flock]4548-her prime flock as [they]3695-sheep rolled there - [Swoln]275-swoln with wind and the rank mist [they]3695-sheep drew . Many of [them]3695-sheep foamed at the mouth , [their]3695-sheep breathing being quick and short , whilst the bodies of all were fearfully distended . "[0-i] O , what can [I]0-i do , what can [I]0-i do ! " said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , helplessly . "[0-i] [Sheep]3695-sheep are such unfortunate animals ! - there 's always something happening to [them]3695-sheep ! [I]0-i never knew a flock pass a year without getting into some scrape or other . " "[3695-sheep] There 's only one way of saving [them]3695-sheep . " said [Tall]211-susan tall . "[3695-sheep] What way ? Tell [me]0-i quick ! " "[0-i] [They]3695-sheep must be pierced in the side with a thing made on purpose . " "[518-a shepherd] Can [you]0-i do it ? Can [I]0-i ? " "[518-a shepherd] No , [ma'am]712-ma'am . "[1415-she] [she]1415-she said firmly . One of the ewes here contracted its muscles horribly , extended itself , and jumped high into the air . The leap was an astonishing one . [The ewe]1402-the ewe fell heavily , and lay still . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba went up to it . [The sheep]644-the sheep was dead . It is often flung out as a sort of prop to support a decaying conviction which , whilst strong , required no enunciation to prove it so . [The cottage to which [Gabriel]144-gabriel had retired before taking [his]144-gabriel final departure from [the locality]1427-the locality]1426-the cottage to which gabriel had retired before taking his final departure from the locality was visible as a white spot on [the opposite hill]1428-the opposite hill , backed by blue firs . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba walked up and down . [The men]3799-the men entered [the field]3467-the field and endeavoured to ease the anguish of the dumb creatures by rubbing [them]3799-the men . "[1063-the young farmer] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , unwilling to believe that [her]1433-she verbal lettre - de - cachet could possibly have miscarried . " [He]144-gabriel says [beggars]4551-beggars must n't be [choosers]4552-choosers . "[196-joseph] replied [Laban]213-laban . " What !
