[The men]3799-the men looked grave , as if [they]3799-the men suppressed opinion . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba turned aside , [her]1011-miss eyes full of tears . The strait [she]1011-miss was in through pride and shrewishness could not be disguised longer : [she]1011-miss burst out crying bitterly ; [they]3799-the men all saw it ; and [she]1011-miss attempted no further concealment . "[186-gable] [I]0-i would n't cry about it , [miss]1011-miss . " said [William Small- bury]278-william small- bury , compassionately . "[196-joseph] Why not ask [him]196-joseph softer like ? [I]0-i 'm sure [he]196-joseph 'd come then . [Gable]186-gable is [a true man]1265-a true man in that way . " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba checked [her]1011-miss grief and wiped [her]1011-miss eyes . "[196-joseph] O , it is a wicked cruelty to [me]0-i - it is - it is ! " [she]0-i murmured . "[144-gabriel] And [he]196-joseph drives [me]0-i to do what [I]0-i would n't ; yes , [he]196-joseph does ! - Tall , come [indoors]1439-indoors . " After this collapse , not very dignified for the head of [an establishment]4557-an establishment , [she]0-i went into [the house]552-the house , Tall at [her]0-i heels . Here [she]0-i sat down and hastily scribbled a note between the small convulsive sobs of convalescence which follow a fit of crying as a ground - swell follows a storm . The note was none the less polite for being written in a hurry . [She]0-i held it at a distance , was about to fold it , then added these words at the bottom : - "[144-gabriel] Do not desert [me]0-i , [Gabriel]144-gabriel ! " [She]0-i looked a little redder in refolding it , and closed [her]0-i lips , as if thereby to suspend till too late the action of conscience in examining whether such strategy were justifiable . The note was despatched as the message had been , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba waited indoors for the result . It was an anxious quarter of an hour that intervened between [the messenger]4559-the messenger 's departure and the sound of the horse 's tramp again outside . [She-]0-i could not watch this time , but , leaning over the old bureau at which [she]0-i had written the letter , closed [her]0-i eyes , as if to keep out both hope and fear . The case , however , was a promising one . [Gabriel]144-gabriel was not angry : [he]144-gabriel was simply neutral , although [her]0-i first command had been so haughty . Such imperiousness would have damned a little less beauty ; and on the other hand , such beauty would have redeemed a little less imperiousness . [She]0-i went out when the horse was heard , and looked up . A mounted figure passed between [her]0-i and the sky , and drew on towards the field of sheep , [the rider]1434-the rider turning [his]1434-the rider face in receding . [Gabriel]144-gabriel looked at [her]0-i . It was a moment when [a woman]459-a woman 's eyes and tongue tell distinctly opposite tales . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba looked full of gratitude , and [she]0-i said : - "[0-i] O , [Gabriel]144-gabriel , how could [you]144-gabriel serve [me]0-i so unkindly ! " Such a tenderly - shaped reproach for [his]144-gabriel previous delay was the one speech in the language that [he]144-gabriel could pardon for not being commendation of [his]144-gabriel readiness now . [Gabriel]144-gabriel murmured a confused reply , and hastened on . [She]0-i knew from the look which sentence in [her]0-i note had brought [him]144-gabriel . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba followed to [the field]3467-the field . [Gabriel]144-gabriel was already among [the turgid , prostrate forms]4563-the turgid , prostrate forms . [He]144-gabriel had flung off [his]144-gabriel coat , rolled up [his]144-gabriel shirt - sleeves , and taken from [his]144-gabriel pocket the instrument of salvation . It was a small tube or trochar , with a lance passing down the inside ; and [Gabriel]144-gabriel began to use it with a dexterity that would have graced [a hospital surgeon]4564-a hospital surgeon . Passing [his]144-gabriel hand over the sheep 's left flank , and selecting the proper point , [he]144-gabriel punctured the skin and rumen with the lance as it stood in the tube ; then [he]144-gabriel suddenly withdrew the lance , retaining the tube in its place . A current of air rushed up the tube , forcible enough to have extinguished a candle held at the orifice . It has been said that mere ease after torment is de- light for a time ; and the countenances of [these poor creatures]4565-these poor creatures expressed it now . Forty - nine operations were successfully performed . Owing to the great hurry necessitated by the far - gone state of [some of [the flock]539-the flock]4566-some of the flock , [Gabriel]144-gabriel missed [his]144-gabriel aim in one case , and in one only - striking wide of the mark , and inflicting a mortal blow at once upon [the suffering ewe]4568-the suffering ewe . Four had died ; three recovered without an operation . The total number of sheep which had thus strayed and injured [themselves]4565-these poor creatures so dangerously was fifty - seven . When [the love - led man]4569-the love - led man had ceased from [his]144-gabriel labours , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba came and looked [him]144-gabriel in the face . "[0-i] [Gabriel]144-gabriel , will [you]144-gabriel stay on with [me]0-i ? " [she]0-i , said , smiling winningly , and not troubling to bring [her]0-i lips quite together again at the end , because there was going to be another smile soon . "[243-bathsheba] [I]0-i will . " said [Gabriel]144-gabriel . And [she]0-i smiled on [him]144-gabriel again . CHAPTER XXII [THE GREAT BARN]4570-the great barn AND [THE SHEEP - SHEARERS MEN]4571-the sheep - shearers men thin away to insignificance and oblivion quite as often by not making the most of good spirits when [they]4571-the sheep - shearers men have [them]4571-the sheep - shearers men as by lacking good spirits when [they]4571-the sheep - shearers men are indispensable . [Gabriel]144-gabriel lately , for the first time since [his]144-gabriel prostration by misfortune , had been independent in thought and vigorous in action to a marked extent - conditions which , powerless without an opportunity as an opportunity without [them]4571-the sheep - shearers men is barren , would have given [him]144-gabriel a sure lift upwards when the favourable - con- junction should have occurred . But this incurable loitering beside [Bathsheba Everdene]243-bathsheba stole [his]144-gabriel time ruinously . The spring tides were going by without floating [him]144-gabriel off , and the neap might soon come which could not . It was the first day of June , and the sheep - shearing season culminated , [the landscape]3471-the landscape , even to the leanest pasture , being all health and colour . Every green was young , every pore was open , and every stalk was swollen with racing currents of juice . [God]171-god was palpably present in [the country]1144-the country , and [the devil]834-the devil had gone with [the world]447-the world to [town]4160-town . [Flossy catkins of the later kinds]4577-flossy catkins of the later kinds , fern - sprouts like [bishops]4578-bishops ' croziers , the square - headed moschatel , the odd cuckoo - pint , - like [an apoplectic saint in a niche of malachite]4579-an apoplectic saint in a niche of malachite , - snow - white ladies'-smocks , the toothwort , approximating to human flesh , [the enchanter]4580-the enchanter 's night- shade , and the black - petaled doleful - bells , were among the quainter objects of the vegetable world in and about [Weatherbury]196-joseph at this teeming time ; and of the animal , the metamorphosed figures of [Mr. Jan Coggan]180-coggan , [the master - shearer]4581-the master - shearer ; [the second and third shearers , who travelled in the exercise of]4582-the second and third shearers , who travelled in the exercise of [their]4582-the second and third shearers , who travelled in the exercise of calling , and do not re- quire definition by name ; [Henery Fray]195-henery [the fourth shearer]4583-the fourth shearer , [[Susan Tall]211-susan tall 's husband]935-susan tall 's husband the fifth , [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph the sixth , [young Cain Ball]235-cain as [assistant - shearer]4585-assistant - shearer , and [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel as [general supervisor]4586-general supervisor . None of these were clothed to any extent worth mentioning , each appearing to have hit in the matter of raiment the decent mean between a high and low caste Hindoo . An angularity of lineament , and a fixity of facial machinery in general , proclaimed that serious work was the order of the day . [They]4587-they sheared in [the great barn]4570-the great barn , called for the nonce [the Shearing - barn]4589-the shearing - barn , which on ground - plan resembled [a church with transepts]4590-a church with transepts . It not only emulated the form of [the neighbouring church of [the parish]422-the parish]4591-the neighbouring church of the parish , but vied with it in antiquity . Whether [the barn]719-the barn had ever formed one of a group of [conventual buildings]4594-conventual buildings [nobody]439-nobody seemed to be aware ; no trace of such surroundings remained . [The vast porches at the sides , lofty enough to admit a waggon laden to its highest with corn in the sheaf]4596-the vast porches at the sides , lofty enough to admit a waggon laden to its highest with corn in the sheaf , were spanned by heavy - pointed arches of stone , broadly and boldly cut , whose very simplicity was the origin of a grandeur not apparent in erections where more ornament has been attempted . The dusky , filmed , chestnut roof , braced and tied in by huge collars , curves , and diagonals , was far nobler in design , because more wealthy in material , than nine - tenths of those in [[our]4597-our modern churches]4598-our modern churches . Along each side wall was a range of striding buttresses , throwing deep shadows on the spaces between them , which were perforated by lancet openings , combining in their proportions the precise requirements both of beauty and ventilation . [One]4328-one could say about [this barn]4600-this barn , what could hardly be said of either [the church]489-the church or [the castle]4602-the castle , akin to [it]4600-this barn in age and style , that the purpose which had dictated [its]4600-this barn original erection was the same with that to which it was still applied . Unlike and superior to either of those two typical remnants of mediaevalism , [the old barn]4603-the old barn embodied practices which had suffered no mutila- tion at the hands of time . Here at least the spirit of [the ancient builders]4604-the ancient builders was at one with the spirit of [the modern beholder]4605-the modern beholder . Standing before this abraded pile , the eye regarded its present usage , the mind - dwelt upon its past history , with a satisfied sense of functional continuity throughout - a feeling almost of gratitude , and quite of pride , at the permanence of the idea which had heaped it up . The fact that four centuries had neither proved it to be founded on a mistake , inspired any hatred of its purpose , nor given rise to any reaction that had battered it down , invested this simple grey effort of old minds with a repose , if not a grandeur , which a too curious reflection was apt to disturb in [its]4600-this barn ecclesiastical and military compeers . For once medievalism and modernism had a common stand- point . The lanccolate windows , the time - eaten arch- stones and chamfers , the orientation of the axis , the misty chestnut work of the rafters , referred to no exploded fortifying art or worn - out religious creed . The defence and salvation of the body by daily bread is still a study , a religion , and a desire . To - day the large side doors were thrown open towards the sun to admit a bountiful light to the immediate spot of [[the shearers]4606-the shearers ' operations]4607-the shearers ' operations , which was the wood threshing - floor in the centre , formed of thick oak , black with age and polished by the beating of flails for many generations , till [it]4600-this barn had grown as slippery and as rich in hue as [the state - room floors of [an Elizabethan mansion]4609-an elizabethan mansion]4608-the state - room floors of an elizabethan mansion . Here [the shearers]4606-the shearers knelt , the sun slanting in upon [their]4606-the shearers bleached shirts , tanned arms , and the polished shears [they]4606-the shearers flourished , causing these to bristle with a thousand rays strong enough to blind [a weak - eyed man]4611-a weak - eyed man . Beneath [them]4606-the shearers [a captive sheep]4612-a captive sheep lay panting , quickening its pants as misgiving merged in terror , till it quivered like the hot landscape outside . This picture of to - day in [its]4600-this barn frame of four hundred years ago did not produce that marked contrast between ancient and modern which is implied by the contrast of date . In comparison with [cities]4613-cities , [Weatherbury]196-joseph was immutable . [The citizen]4614-the citizen 's Then is [the rustic]4615-the rustic 's Now . In [London]70-london , twenty or thirty - years ago are old times ; in [Paris]71-paris ten years , or five ; in [Weatherbury]196-joseph three or four score years were included in the mere present , and nothing less than a century set a mark on its face or tone . Five decades hardly modified the cut of a gaiter , the embroidery of a smock - frock , by the breadth of a hair . Ten generations failed to alter the turn of a single phrase . In [these Wessex nooks]4616-these wessex nooks the busy out- sider 's ancient times are only old ; [his]4615-the rustic old times are still new ; [his]4615-the rustic present is futurity . So [the barn]719-the barn was natural to [the shearers]4606-the shearers , and [the shearers]4606-the shearers were in harmony with [the barn]719-the barn . [The spacious ends of [the building]3834-the building]4621-the spacious ends of the building , answering ecclesi- astically to [nave]4623-nave and chancel extremities , were fenced off with hurdles , the sheep being all collected in a crowd within these two enclosures ; and in one angle a catching- pen was formed , in which [three or four sheep]4624-three or four sheep were continuously kept ready for [the shearers]4606-the shearers to seize without loss of time . In the background , mellowed by tawny shade , were [the three women]4626-the three women , [Maryann Money]179-maryann , and [Temperance and Soberness Miller]233-temperance miller , gathering up the fleeces and twisting ropes of wool with a wimble for tying them round . [They]4626-the three women were indifferently well assisted by [the old maltster , who , when the malting season from October to April had passed]4627-the old maltster , who , when the malting season from october to april had passed , made [himself]4627-the old maltster , who , when the malting season from october to april had passed useful upon [any of [the bordering farmsteads]4629-the bordering farmsteads]4628-any of the bordering farmsteads . "[243-bathsheba] Behind all was [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , carefully watching [the men]3799-the men to see that there was no cutting or wounding through carelessness , and that the animals were shorn close . [Gabriel]144-gabriel , who flitted and hovered under [her]1441-her bright eyes like a moth , did not shear continuously , half [his]144-gabriel time being spent in attending to [the others]3772-the others and selecting the sheep for [them]3772-the others . At the present moment [he]144-gabriel was engaged in handing round a mug of mild liquor , supplied from a barrel in the corner , and cut pieces of bread and cheese . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , after throwing a glance here , a caution there , and lecturing one of [the younger operators who had allowed [his]144-gabriel last finished sheep to go off among the flock without re - stamping it with [her]1441-her initials]1443-the younger operators who had allowed his last finished sheep to go off among the flock without re - stamping it with her initials , came again to [Gabriel]144-gabriel , as [he]144-gabriel put down the luncheon to drag a frightened ewe to [[his]144-gabriel shear - station]1444-his shear - station , flinging it over upon its back with a dexterous twist of the arm [He]144-gabriel lopped off the tresses about its head , and opened up the neck and collar , [[his]144-gabriel mistress]4518-his mistress quietly looking on : " [She]4518-his mistress blushes at the insult . "[144-gabriel] murmured [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , watching the pink flush which arose and overspread the neck and shoulders of the ewe where they were left bare by the clicking shears - a flush which was enviable , for its delicacy , by [many queens of [coteries]1447-coteries]1446-many queens of coteries , and would have been creditable , for its promptness , to [any woman in [the world]447-the world]1448-any woman in the world . [Poor Gabriel]279-poor gabriel 's soul was fed with a luxury of content by having [her]4518-his mistress over [him]144-gabriel , [her]4518-his mistress eyes critically regarding [his]144-gabriel skilful shears , which apparently were going to gather up a piece of the flesh at every close , and yet never did so . Like [Guildenstern]280-guildenstern , [Oak]144-gabriel was happy in that [he]144-gabriel was not over happy . [He]144-gabriel had no wish to converse with [her]4518-his mistress : that [[his]144-gabriel bright lady]1450-his bright lady and [himself]144-gabriel formed [one group , exclusively [their]1452-their own]1451-one group , exclusively their own , and containing [no others in [the world]447-the world]1453-no others in the world , was enough . So the chatter was all on [her]4518-his mistress side . There is a loquacity that tells nothing , which was [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's ; and there is a silence which says much : that was [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's . Full of this dim and temperate bliss , [he]144-gabriel went on to fling the ewe over upon [her]4518-his mistress other side , covering [her]4518-his mistress head with [his]144-gabriel knee , gradually running the shears line after line round [her]4518-his mistress dewlap ; thence about [her]4518-his mistress flank and back , and finishing over the tail . " Well done , and done quickly ! "[144-gabriel] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , looking at [her]4518-his mistress watch as the last snip resounded . " How long , [miss]1011-miss ? "[252-cainy] said [Gabriel]144-gabriel , wiping [his]144-gabriel brow . " Three - and - twenty minutes and a half since [you]1011-miss took the first lock from its forehead . It is the first time that [I]252-cainy have ever seen one done in less than half an hour . "[252-cainy] [The clean , sleek creature]1455-the clean , sleek creature arose from its fleece - how perfectly like Aphrodite rising from the foam should have been seen to be realized - looking startled and shy at the loss of its garment , which lay on the floor in one soft cloud , united throughout , the portion visible being the inner surface only , which , never before exposed , was white as snow , and without flaw or blemish of the minutest kind . " [Cain Ball]235-cain ! "[252-cainy] " Yes , [Mister Oak]146-mr. oak ; here [I]4518-his mistress be ! "[4518-his mistress] [Cainy]252-cainy now runs forward with the tar - pot . " B. E. "[4518-his mistress] is newly stamped upon the shorn skin , and away the simple dam leaps , panting , over the board into the shirtless flock outside . Then up comes [Maryann]179-maryann ; throws the loose locks into the middle of the fleece , rolls it up , and carries it into the background as three - and - a - half pounds of unadulterated warmth for the winter enjoy- ment of persons unknown and far away , who will , however , never experience the superlative comfort derivable from the wool as it here exists , new and pure - before the unctuousness of its nature whilst in a living state has dried , stiffened , and been washed out - rendering it just now as superior to anything woollen as cream is superior to milk - and - water . But heartless circumstance could not leave [entire Gabriel]144-gabriel 's happiness of this morning . The rams , [old ewes]1456-old ewes , and [two - shear ewes]1457-two - shear ewes had duly undergone [their]1458-their stripping , and [the men]3799-the men were proceeding with the shear- lings and hogs , when [Oak]144-gabriel 's belief that [she]4518-his mistress was going to stand pleasantly by and time [him]144-gabriel through another performance was painfully interrupted by [Farmer Bold- wood]281-farmer bold- wood 's appearance in [the extremest corner of [the barn]719-the barn]1460-the extremest corner of the barn . [Nobody]439-nobody seemed to have perceived [his]144-gabriel entry , but there [he]144-gabriel certainly was . [Boldwood]231-boldwood always carried with [him]231-boldwood a social atmosphere of [his]231-boldwood own , which [everybody]954-everybody felt who came near [him]231-boldwood ; and the talk , which [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's presence had somewhat suppressed , was now totally suspended . [He]231-boldwood crossed over towards [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , who turned to greet [him]231-boldwood with a carriage of perfect ease . [He]231-boldwood spoke to [her]4518-his mistress in low tones , and [she]4518-his mistress instinctively modulated [her]4518-his mistress own to the same pitch , and [her]4518-his mistress voice ultimately even caught the inflection of [his]231-boldwood . [She]4518-his mistress was far from having a wish to appear mysteriously connected with [him]231-boldwood ; but [woman at the impressionable age]1464-woman at the impressionable age gravitates to the larger body not only in [her]1464-woman at the impressionable age choice of words , which is apparent every day , but even in [her]1464-woman at the impressionable age shades of tone and humour , when the influence is great . What [they]1465-they conversed about was not audible to [Gabriel]144-gabriel , who was too independent to get near , though too concerned to disregard . The issue of [their]1465-they dialogue was the taking of [her]4518-his mistress hand by [the courteous farmer]1466-the courteous farmer to help [her]4518-his mistress over the spreading - board into the bright June sunlight outside . Standing beside the sheep already shorn , [they]1465-they went on talking again . Concerning the flock ? Apparently not . [Gabriel]144-gabriel theorized , not without truth , that in quiet discussion of any matter within reach of [the speakers]1467-the speakers ' eyes , these are usually fixed upon it . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba demurely regarded a contemptible straw lying upon the ground , in a way which suggested less ovine criticism than womanly embarrassment . [She]4518-his mistress became more or less red in the cheek , the blood wavering in uncertain flux and reflux over the sensitive space between ebb and flood . [Gabriel]144-gabriel sheared on , constrained and sad . [She]4518-his mistress left [Boldwood]231-boldwood 's side , and [he]231-boldwood walked up and down alone for nearly a quarter of an hour . Then [she]4518-his mistress reappeared in [her]4518-his mistress new riding - habit of myrtle - green , which fitted [her]4518-his mistress to the waist as a rind fits its fruit ; and [young Bob Coggan]180-coggan led -on -her mare , [Boldwood]231-boldwood fetching [his]231-boldwood own horse from the tree under which it had been tied . [Oak]144-gabriel 's eyes could not forsake them ; and in en- deavouring to continue [his]231-boldwood shearing at the same time that [he]231-boldwood watched [Boldwood]231-boldwood 's manner , [he]231-boldwood snipped the sheep in the groin . The animal plunged ; [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba instantly gazed towards it , and saw the blood . " O , [Gabriel]144-gabriel ! "[231-boldwood] [she]4518-his mistress exclaimed , with severe remon- strance [you]144-gabriel who are so strict with [the other men]1019-the other men - see what [you]144-gabriel are doing [yourself]144-gabriel ! " To [an outsider]4631-an outsider there was not much to complain of in this remark ; but to [Oak]144-gabriel , who "[4518-his mistress] knew [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba to be well aware that [she]4518-his mistress [herself]4518-his mistress was the cause of the poor ewe 's wound , because [she]4518-his mistress had wounded [[the ewe]1402-the ewe 's shearer]1470-the ewe 's shearer in a - still more vital part , it had a sting which the abiding sense of [his]1470-the ewe 's shearer inferiority to both [herself]4518-his mistress and [Boldwood]231-boldwood was not calculated to heal . But a manly resolve to recognize boldly that [he]231-boldwood had no longer [a lover]1382-a lover 's interest in [her]4518-his mistress , helped [him]231-boldwood occasionally to conceal a feeling . " [Bottle]283-bottle ! "[233-temperance miller] [he]231-boldwood shouted , in an unmoved voice of routine . [Cainy Ball]252-cainy ran up , the wound was anointed , and the shearing continued . [Boldwood]231-boldwood gently tossed [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba into the saddle , and before [they]1472-they turned away [she]4518-his mistress again spoke out to [Oak]144-gabriel with the same dominative and tantalizing graciousness . " [I]180-coggan am going now to see [[Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood 's Leicesters]4632-mr. boldwood 's leicesters . "[180-coggan] The horses ' heads were put about , and [they]1472-they trotted away . [Boldwood]224-boldwood 's deep attachment was a matter of great interest among [all around [him]224-boldwood]1473-all around him ; but , after having been pointed out for so many years as the perfect exemplar of thriving bachelorship , [his]224-boldwood lapse was an anticlimax somewhat resembling that of [St. John Long]148-st. john 's death by consumption in the midst of [his]224-boldwood proofs that it was not a fatal disease . " [Coggan]180-coggan furnished a suitable reply . [Oak]144-gabriel went on with [his]144-gabriel shearing , and said not another word . Pestilent moods had come , and teased away [his]144-gabriel quiet . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had shown indications of anointing [him]144-gabriel above [[his]144-gabriel fellows]4653-his fellows by installing [him]144-gabriel as [the bailiff that [the farm]3760-the farm imperatively required]4654-the bailiff that the farm imperatively required . [He]144-gabriel did not covet the post relatively to [the farm]3760-the farm : in relation to [herself]243-bathsheba , as beloved by [him]144-gabriel and unmarried to [another]3843-another , [he]144-gabriel had coveted it . [His]144-gabriel readings of [her]0-i seemed now to be vapoury and indistinct . [His]144-gabriel lecture to [her]0-i was , [he]144-gabriel thought , one of the absurdest mistakes . Far from coquetting with [Boldwood]231-boldwood , [she]0-i had trifled with [himself]231-boldwood in thus feigning that [she]0-i had trifled with another . [He]144-gabriel was inwardly convinced that , in accordance with the anticipations of [[his]144-gabriel easy - going and worse - educated comrades]4658-his easy - going and worse - educated comrades , that day would see [Boldwood]231-boldwood [the accepted husband of [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene]4659-the accepted husband of miss everdene . [Gabriel]144-gabriel at this time of [his]144-gabriel life had out- grown the instinctive dislike which [every Christian boy]4660-every christian boy has for reading the Bible , perusing it now quite frequently , and [he]144-gabriel inwardly said , "[1506-we] [I]0-i find more bitter than death [the woman whose heart is snares and nets]1505-the woman whose heart is snares and nets ! " This was mere exclamation - the froth of the storm . [He]144-gabriel adored [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba just the same . "[0-i] [[We]1506-we workfolk]1507-we workfolk shall have some lordly- junketing to - night . " said [Cainy Ball]252-cainy , casting forth [his]252-cainy thoughts in a new direction . "[0-i] This morning [I]0-i see'em making the great puddens in the milking - pails - lumps of fat as big as [yer]1508-yer thumb , [Mister Oak]146-mr. oak ! [I]0-i 've never seed such splendid large knobs of fat before in the days of [my]0-i life - they never used to be bigger then a horse - bean . And there was a great black crock upon the brandish with [his]146-mr. oak legs a - sticking out , but [I]0-i do n't know what was in within . " "[144-gabriel] And there 's two bushels of biffins for apple - pies , " said [Maryann]179-maryann . "[144-gabriel] Well , [I]0-i hope to do [my]0-i duty by it all . " said [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph , in a pleasant , masticating manner of anticipa- tion . "[144-gabriel] Yes ; victuals and drink is a cheerful thing , and gives nerves to the nerveless , if the form of words may be used . ' Tis the gospel of the body , without which [we]1506-we perish , so to speak it . " CHAPTER XXIII EVENTIDE - A SECOND DECLARATION FOR the shearing - supper a long table was placed on the grass - plot beside [the house]552-the house , the end of the table being thrust over the sill of the wide parlour window and a foot or two into [the room]4025-the room . [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene sat inside the window , facing down the table . [She]167-miss everdene was thus at the head without mingling with [the men]3799-the men . This evening [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was unusually excited , [her]167-miss everdene red cheeks and lips contrasting lustrously with the mazy skeins of [her]167-miss everdene shadowy hair . [She]167-miss everdene seemed to expect assistance , and the seat at the bottom of the table was at [her]167-miss everdene request left vacant until after [they]1506-we had begun and the duties appertaining to that end , which [he]224-boldwood did with great readiness . At this moment [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood came in at the gate , and crossed the green to [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba at the window . [He]224-boldwood apologized for [his]224-boldwood lateness : [his]224-boldwood arrival was evidently by arrangement . "[224-boldwood] [Gabriel]144-gabriel . " said [she]167-miss everdene , "[177-master poorgrass] will [you]144-gabriel move again , please , and let [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood come [there]3509-there ? " [Oak]144-gabriel moved in silence back to [his]144-gabriel original seat . [The gentleman - farmer]4664-the gentleman - farmer was dressed in cheerful style , in a new coat and white waistcoat , quite contrasting with [his]4664-the gentleman - farmer usual sober suits of grey . [Inwardy]290-inwardy , too , [he]4664-the gentleman - farmer was blithe , and consequently chatty to an exceptional degree . So also was [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba now that [he]4664-the gentleman - farmer had come , though the uninvited presence of [Pennyways]251-pennyways , [the bailiff who had been dismissed for theft]4665-the bailiff who had been dismissed for theft , disturbed [her]167-miss everdene equan- imity for a while . Supper being ended , [Coggan]180-coggan began on [his]180-coggan own private account , without reference to [listeners]4666-listeners : - l've lost [my]177-master poorgrass love and l care not , [I]177-master poorgrass 've lost [my]177-master poorgrass love , and l care not ; [I]177-master poorgrass shall soon have another That 's better than t'other ! [I]177-master poorgrass 've lost [my]177-master poorgrass love , and [I]177-master poorgrass care not . This lyric , when concluded , was received with a silently appreciative gaze at the table , implying that the performance , like a work by [those established authors who are independent of notices in the papers]4667-those established authors who are independent of notices in the papers , was a well - known delight which required no applause . "[177-master poorgrass] Now , [Master Poorgrass]177-master poorgrass , [your]177-master poorgrass song ! " said [Coggan]180-coggan . "[196-joseph] [I]0-i be all but in liquor , and the gift is wanting in [me]0-i . " said [Joseph]196-joseph , diminishing [himself]196-joseph . "[996-mistress] Nonsense ; wou'st never be so ungrateful , [Joseph]196-joseph - never ! " said [Coggan]180-coggan , expressing hurt feelings by an inflection of voice . "[180-coggan] And [mistress]996-mistress is looking hard at [ye]177-master poorgrass , as much as to say , " Sing at once , [Joseph]196-joseph Poor- grass . "[180-coggan] " Faith , so [she]996-mistress is ; well , [I]196-joseph must suffer it ! ... Just eye [my]196-joseph features , and see if the tell - tale blood overheats [me]196-joseph much , [neighbours]776-neighbours ? "[196-joseph] " No , [yer]177-master poorgrass blushes be quite reasonable . "[196-joseph] said [Coggan]180-coggan . " [I]243-bathsheba always tries to keep [my]243-bathsheba colours from rising when [a beauty]4669-a beauty 's eyes get fixed on [me]243-bathsheba . "[243-bathsheba] said [Joseph]196-joseph , differently ; " but if so be ' tis willed [they]4669-a beauty do , [they]4669-a beauty must . "[196-joseph] " Now , [Joseph]196-joseph , [your]196-joseph song , please . "[196-joseph] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , from the window . " Well , really , [ma'am]712-ma'am . "[196-joseph] [he]196-joseph replied , in a yielding tone , " [I]196-joseph do n't know what to say . It would be a poor plain ballet of [my]196-joseph own composure . "[196-joseph] Hear , hear ! " said [the supper - party]4671-the supper - party . [Poorgrass]196-joseph , thus assured , trilled forth a flickering yet commendable piece of sentiment , the tune of which consisted of the key - note and another , the latter being the sound chiefly dwelt upon . This was so successful that [he]196-joseph rashly plunged into a second in the same breath , after a few false starts : - [I sow'-ed]4672-i sow'-ed th'-e [I]196-joseph sow'-ed [I]196-joseph sow'-ed the'-e seeds ' of love ' , [I]196-joseph - it was ' all ' i'-in the'-e spring ' , [I]196-joseph - in A'-pril ' , [Ma'-ay]291-ma'-ay , a'-nd sun'-ny ' June ' , When sma'-all bi'-irds [they]4669-a beauty ' do ' sing . "[196-joseph] Well put out of hand . " said [Coggan]180-coggan , at the end of the verse . ` [They]4669-a beauty do sing ' was a very taking paragraph . "[196-joseph] " Ay ; and there was a pretty place at ' seeds of love . "[177-master poorgrass] and ' twas well heaved out . Though " love "[196-joseph] is a nasty high corner when [a man]3474-a man 's voice is getting crazed . Next verse , [Master Poorgrass]177-master poorgrass . " But during this rendering [young Bob Coggan]180-coggan ex- hibited one of those anomalies which will afflict [little people]4673-little people when [other persons]4674-other persons are particularly serious : in trying to check [his]180-coggan laughter , [he]180-coggan pushed down [his]180-coggan throat as much of the tablecloth as [he]180-coggan could get hold of , when , after continuing hermetically sealed for a short time , [his]180-coggan mirth burst out through [his]180-coggan nose . [Joseph]196-joseph perceived it , and with hectic cheeks of indignation instantly ceased singing . [Coggan]180-coggan boxed [Bob]180-coggan 's ears immediately . "[167-miss everdene] Go on , [Joseph]196-joseph - go on , and never mind [the young scamp]1512-the young scamp . " said [Coggan]180-coggan . "[1519-her] ' Tis a very catching ballet . Now then again - the next bar ; [I]0-i 'll help [ye]1513-ye to flourish up the shrill notes where [yer]1513-ye wind is rather wheezy : - O the wi'-il - lo'-ow tree ' will ' twist ' , And the wil'-low ' tre'-ee wi'ill twine ' . But [the singer]1514-the singer could not be set going again . [Bob Coggan]180-coggan was sent [home]556-home for [his]180-coggan ill manners , and tran- quility was restored by [Jacob Smallbury]187-jacob , who volunteered a ballad as inclusive and interminable as that with which [the worthy toper old Silenus]292-the worthy toper old silenus amused on a similar occasion the swains Chromis and [Mnasylus]293-mnasylus , and other jolly dogs of [his]180-coggan day . It was still the beaming time of evening , though night was stealthily making itself visible low down upon the ground , the western lines of light taking [the earth]1149-the earth without alighting upon it to any extent , or illuminating the dead levels at all . The sun had crept round the tree as a last effort before death , and then began to sink , [the shearers]4606-the shearers ' lower parts becoming steeped in embrowning twilight , whilst [their]4606-the shearers heads and shoulders were still enjoying day , touched with a yellow of self- sustained brilliancy that seemed inherent rather than acquired . The sun went down in an ochreous mist ; but [they]4606-the shearers sat , and talked on , and grew as merry as the gods in [[Homer]294-homer 's heaven]1518-homer 's heaven . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba still remained enthroned inside the window , and occupied [herself]243-bathsheba in knitting , from which [she]1519-her sometimes looked up to view the fading scene outside . The slow twilight expanded and enveloped [them]4606-the shearers completely before the signs of moving were shown . [Gabriel]144-gabriel suddenly missed [Farmer Boldwood]231-boldwood from [his]231-boldwood place at the bottom of the table . How long [he]231-boldwood had been gone [Oak]144-gabriel did not know ; but [he]231-boldwood had apparently withdrawn into the encircling dusk . Whilst [he]144-gabriel was thinking of this , [Liddy]191-liddy brought candles into the back part of [the room]4025-the room overlooking [the shearers]4606-the shearers , and [their]1522-their lively new flames shone down the table and over [the men]3799-the men , and dispersed among the green shadows behind . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's form , still in its original position , was now again distinct between [their]4606-the shearers eyes and the light , which revealed that [Boldwood]231-boldwood had gone inside [the room]4025-the room , and was sitting near [her]1519-her . Next came the question of the evening . Would [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene sing to [them]4606-the shearers the song [she]167-miss everdene always sang so charmingly - " The Banks of [Allan Water]72-allan water "[1519-her] - before [they]4606-the shearers went [home]556-home ? After a moment 's consideration [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba assented , beckoning to [Gabriel]144-gabriel , who hastened up into the coveted atmosphere . " Have [you]144-gabriel brought [your]144-gabriel flute ? "[1519-her] [she]1519-her whispered . " Yes , [miss]1011-miss . "[231-boldwood] " Play to [my]231-boldwood singing , then . "[231-boldwood] [She]1519-her stood up in the window - opening , facing [the men]3799-the men , the candles behind [her]1519-her , [Gabriel]144-gabriel on [her]1519-her right hand , immediately outside the sash - frame . [Boldwood]231-boldwood had drawn up on [her]1519-her left , within [the room]4025-the room . [Her]1519-her singing was soft and rather tremulous at first , but it soon swelled to a steady clearness . Subsequent events caused one of the verses to be remembered for many months , and even years , by [more than one of [those who were gathered [there]3509-there]1529-those who were gathered there]1528-more than one of those who were gathered there : - For [[his]144-gabriel bride]1531-his bride [a soldier]995-a soldier sought [her]1519-her , And a winning tongue had [he]144-gabriel : On [the banks of [Allan Water]72-allan water]1533-the banks of allan water None was gay as [she]1519-her ! In addition to the dulcet piping of [Gabriel]144-gabriel 's flute , [Boldwood]231-boldwood supplied a bass in [his]231-boldwood customary profound voice , uttering [his]231-boldwood notes so softly , however , as to abstain entirely from making anything like an ordinary duet of the song ; [they]1534-they rather formed a rich unexplored shadow , which threw [her]1519-her tones into relief . [The shearers]4606-the shearers reclined against [each other]3826-each other as at suppers in the early ages of [the world]447-the world , and so silent and absorbed were [they]4606-the shearers that [her]1519-her breathing could almost be heard between the bars ; and at the end of the ballad , when the last tone loitered on to an inexpressible close , there arose that buzz of pleasure which is the attar of applause . It is scarcely necessary to state that [Gabriel]144-gabriel could not avoid noting [the farmer]3540-the farmer 's bearing to - night towards [[their]3540-the farmer entertainer]1539-their entertainer . Yet there was nothing exceptional in [his]144-gabriel actions beyond what appertained to [his]144-gabriel time of performing them . It was when [the rest]4547-the rest were all looking away that [Boldwood]231-boldwood observed [her]1519-her ; when [they]4547-the rest regarded [her]1519-her [he]231-boldwood turned aside ; when [they]4547-the rest thanked or praised [he]231-boldwood was silent ; when [they]4547-the rest were inattentive [he]231-boldwood murmured [his]231-boldwood thanks . The meaning lay in the difference between actions , none of which had any meaning of itself ; and the necessity of being jealous , which [lovers]1541-lovers are troubled with , did not lead [Oak]144-gabriel to underestimate these signs . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba then wished [them]4547-the rest good - night , withdrew from the window , and retired to the back part of [the room]4025-the room , [Boldwood]231-boldwood thereupon closing the sash and the shutters , and remaining inside with [her]1519-her . [Oak]144-gabriel wandered away under the quiet and scented trees . Recovering from the softer impressions produced by [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's voice , [the shearers]4606-the shearers rose to leave , [Coggan]180-coggan turning to [Pennyways]251-pennyways as [he]231-boldwood pushed back the bench to pass out : - " [I]231-boldwood like to give praise where praise is due , and [the man]726-the man deserves it - that ' a do so . "[231-boldwood] [he]231-boldwood remarked , looking at [the worthy thief]1544-the worthy thief , as if [he]1544-the worthy thief were the masterpiece of [some world - renowned artist]1545-some world - renowned artist . " [I]1546-i 'm sure [I]1546-i should never have believed it if [we]4677-we had n't proved it , so to allude , "[1546-i] hiccupped [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph , " that every cup , every one of the best knives and forks , and every empty bottle be in [their]4678-their place as perfect now as at the beginning , and [not one stole at all]4679-not one stole at all . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm sure [I]0-i do n't deserve half the praise [you]1546-i give [me]0-i . " said [the virtuous thief]4680-the virtuous thief , grimly . "[251-pennyways] Well , [I]0-i 'll say this for [Pennyways]251-pennyways . " added [Coggan]180-coggan , "[251-pennyways] that whenever [he]251-pennyways do really make up [his]251-pennyways mind to do a noble thing in the shape of a good action , as [I]0-i could see by [his]251-pennyways face [he]251-pennyways . did to - night afore sitting down , [he]251-pennyways 's generally able to carry it out . Yes , [I]0-i 'm proud to say . neighbours , that [he]251-pennyways 's stole nothing at all . " Well . "[167-miss everdene] - ' tis an honest deed , and [we]1547-we thank [ye]251-pennyways for it , [Pennyways]251-pennyways . " said [Joseph]196-joseph ; to which opinion [the remainder of [the company]3918-the company]4681-the remainder of the company subscribed unanimously . At this time of departure , when nothing more was visible of the inside of [the parlour]4683-the parlour than a thin and still chink of light between the shutters , a passionate scene was in course of enactment there . "[167-miss everdene] [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene and [Boldwood]231-boldwood were alone . [Her]167-miss everdene cheeks had lost a great deal of [their]1548-their healthful fire from the very seriousness of [her]167-miss everdene position ; but [her]167-miss everdene eye was bright with the excitement of a triumph - though it was a triumph which had rather been contemplated than desired . [She]167-miss everdene was standing behind a low arm - chair , from which [she]167-miss everdene had just risen , and [he]251-pennyways was kneeling in [it]1549-it - inclining [himself]251-pennyways over its back towards [her]167-miss everdene , and holding [her]167-miss everdene hand in both [his]251-pennyways own . [His]251-pennyways body moved restlessly , and it was with what [Keats]295-keats daintily calls a too happy happiness . This unwonted abstraction by love of all dignity from [a man of whom it had ever seemed the chief component]1550-a man of whom it had ever seemed the chief component , was , in its distressing incongruity , a pain to [her]167-miss everdene which quenched much of the pleasure [she]167-miss everdene derived from the proof that [she]167-miss everdene was idolized . " [I]167-miss everdene will try to love [you]251-pennyways . "[167-miss everdene] [she]167-miss everdene was saying , in a trembling voice quite unlike [her]167-miss everdene usual self - confidence . " And if [I]4111-your wife can believe in any way that [I]4111-your wife shall make [you]251-pennyways [a good wife]4684-a good wife [I]4111-your wife shall indeed be willing to marry [you]251-pennyways . But , [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood , hesitation on so high a matter is honourable in [any woman]4685-any woman , and [I]4111-your wife do n't want to give a solemn promise to - night . [I]4111-your wife would rather ask [you]251-pennyways to wait a few weeks till [I]4111-your wife can see [my]4111-your wife situation better . "But[4111-your wife] [you]1551-you have every reason to believe that then - - " "[0-i] [I]0-i have every reason to hope that at the end of the five or six weeks , between this time and harvest , that [you]1551-you say [you]1551-you are going to be away from [home]556-home , [I]0-i shall be able to promise to be [[your]1551-you wife]4111-your wife . " [she]0-i said , firmly . "[167-miss everdene] But remember this distinctly , [I]0-i do n't promise yet . " "[167-miss everdene] It is enough [I]0-i do n't ask more . [I]0-i can wait on those dear words . And now , [Miss Everdene]167-miss everdene , good- night ! " "[167-miss everdene] Good - night . " [she]0-i said , graciously - almost tenderly ; and [Boldwood]224-boldwood withdrew with a serene smile . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba knew more of [him]224-boldwood now ; [he]224-boldwood had entirely bared [his]224-boldwood heart before [her]0-i , even until [he]224-boldwood had almost worn in [her]0-i eyes the sorry look of a grand bird without the feathers that make it grand . [She]0-i had been awe- struck at [her]0-i past temerity , and was struggling to make amends without thinking whether the sin quite deserved the penalty [she]0-i was schooling [herself]0-i to pay . To have brought all this about [her]0-i ears was terrible ; but after a while the situation was not without a fearful joy . The facility with which [even the most timid woman]4686-even the most timid woman some- times acquire a relish for the dreadful when that is amalgamated with a little triumph , is marvellous . CHAPTER XXIV THE SAME NIGHT - THE FIR PLANTATION AMONG the multifarious duties which [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had voluntarily imposed upon [herself]243-bathsheba by dispensing with the services of [a bailiff]532-a bailiff , was the particular one of looking round [the homestead]3990-the homestead before going to bed , to see that all was right and safe for the night . [Gabriel]144-gabriel had almost constantly preceded [her]0-i in this tour every evening , watching [her]0-i affairs as carefully as [any specially appointed officer of surveillance]4689-any specially appointed officer of surveillance could have done ; but this tender devotion was to a great extent unknown to [[his]224-boldwood mistress]4518-his mistress , and as much as was known was somewhat thanklessly received . [Women]493-women are never tired of bewailing [man]3450-man 's fickleness in love , but [they]493-women only seem to snub [his]3450-man con- stancy . As watching is best done invisibly , [she]0-i usually carried a dark lantern in [her]0-i hand , and every now and then turned on the light to examine nooks and corners with the coolness of [a metropolitan policeman]4693-a metropolitan policeman . This cool- ness may have owed its existence not so much to [her]0-i fearlessness of expected danger as to [her]0-i freedom from the suspicion of any ; [her]0-i worst anticipated discovery being that a horse might not be well bedded , the fowls not all in , or a door not closed . This night [the buildings]4694-the buildings were inspected as usual , and [she]0-i went round to [the farm paddock]4695-the farm paddock . Here the only sounds disturbing the stillness were steady munch- ings of many mouths , and stentorian breathings from all but invisible noses , ending in snores and puffs like the blowing of bellows slowly . Then the munching would recommence , when the lively imagination might assist the eye to discern a group of pink - white nostrils , shaped as caverns , and very clammy and humid on [their]493-women sur- faces , not exactly pleasant to the touch until [one]4328-one got used to [them]493-women ; the mouths beneath having a great partiality for closing upon any loose end of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's apparel which came within reach of [their]493-women tongues . Above each of these a still keener vision suggested a brown forehead and two staring though not unfriendly eyes , and above all a pair of whitish crescent - shaped horns like two particularly new moons , an occasional stolid "[0-i] moo ! " proclaiming beyond the shade of a doubt that these phenomena were the features and persons of [Daisy]159-daisy , Whitefoot , [Bonny - lass]4697-bonny - lass , Jolly - O , Spot , Twinkle - eye , etc . , etc . - [the respectable dairy of Devon cows belonging to [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba aforesaid]4698-the respectable dairy of devon cows belonging to bathsheba aforesaid . [Her]0-i way back to [the house]552-the house was by [a path]4700-a path through [a young plantation of tapering firs]4701-a young plantation of tapering firs , which had been planted some years earlier to shelter [the premises]4702-the premises from the north wind . By reason of the density of the interwoven foliage overhead , it was gloomy there at cloudless noontide , twilight in the evening , dark as midnight at dusk , and black as the ninth plague of [Egypt]73-egypt at midnight . To describe [the spot]3757-the spot is to call [it]3757-the spot [a vast , low , naturally formed hall]4704-a vast , low , naturally formed hall , the plumy ceiling of which was supported by slender pillars of living wood , the floor being covered with a soft dun carpet of dead spikelets and mildewed cones , with a tuft of grass - blades here and there . [This bit of the path]4705-this bit of the path was always the crux of the night 's ramble , though , before starting , [her]0-i apprehen- sions of danger were not vivid enough to lead [her]0-i to take [a companion]4706-a companion . Slipping along here covertly as Time , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba fancied [she]0-i could hear footsteps enter- ing the track at the opposite end . It was certainly a rustle of footsteps . [Her]0-i own instantly fell as gently as snowflakes . [She]0-i reassured [herself]0-i by a remembrance that [the path]3518-the path was public , and that [the traveller]4708-the traveller was probably [some villager returning [home]556-home]4709-some villager returning home ; regetting , at the same time , that the meeting should be about to occur in the darkest point of [her]0-i route , even though only just outside [her]0-i own door . The noise approached , came close , and [a figure]4198-a figure was apparently on the point of gliding past [her]0-i when some- thing tugged at [her]0-i skirt and pinned it forcibly to the ground . The instantaneous check nearly threw [Bath- sheba]168-bath- sheba off [her]168-bath- sheba balance . In recovering [she]0-i struck against warm clothes and buttons . "[1554-mate] A rum start , upon [my]0-i soul ! " said a masculine voice , a foot or so above [her]0-i head . "[1554-mate] Have [I]0-i hurt [you]0-i , [mate]1554-mate ? " "[0-i] No . " said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , attempting to shrink a way . "[0-i] [We]1555-we have got hitched together somehow , [I]0-i think . " "[0-i] Yes . " "[611-a lady] Are [you]0-i [a woman]459-a woman ? " "[611-a lady] Yes . " "[611-a lady] [A lady]611-a lady , [I]0-i should have said . " "[0-i] It does n't matter . " "[0-i] [I]0-i am [a man]3474-a man . " "[0-i] Oh ! " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba softly tugged again , but to no purpose . "[0-i] Is that a dark lantern [you]0-i have ? [I]0-i fancy so . " said [the man]726-the man . "[0-i] Yes . " "[0-i] If [you]0-i 'll allow [me]0-i [I]0-i 'll open it , and set [you]0-i free . " A hand seized the lantern , the door was opened , the rays burst out from [[their]1555-we prison]4713-their prison , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba beheld [her]0-i position with astonishment . [The man to whom [she]0-i was hooked]4714-the man to whom she was hooked was brilliant in brass and scarlet . [He]4714-the man to whom she was hooked was [a soldier]995-a soldier . [His]4714-the man to whom she was hooked sudden appearance was to darkness what the sound of a trumpet is to silense . [Gloom]296-gloom , [the genius loci at all times hitherto]4716-the genius loci at all times hitherto , was now totally overthrown , less by the lantern - light than by what the lantern lighted . The contrast of this revelation with [her]0-i anticipations of [some sinister figure in sombre garb]4717-some sinister figure in sombre garb was so great that it had upon [her]0-i the effect of a fairy transformation . It was immediately apparent that [the military man]4718-the military man 's spur had become entangled in the gimp which decorated the skirt of [her]0-i dress . [He]4714-the man to whom she was hooked caught a view of [her]0-i face . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'll unfasten [you]0-i in one moment , [miss]1011-miss . " [he]4714-the man to whom she was hooked said , with new - born gallantry . "[0-i] O no - [I]0-i can do it , thank [you]0-i . " [she]0-i hastily replied , and stooped for the performance . The unfastening was not such a trifling affair . The rowel of the spur had so wound itself among the gimp cords in those few moments , that separation was likely to be a matter of time . [He]4714-the man to whom she was hooked too stooped , and the lantern standing on the ground betwixt [them]4719-them threw the gleam from its open side among the fir - tree needles and the blades of long damp grass with the effect of a large glowworm . It radiated upwards into [their]4719-them faces , and sent over half the planta- tion gigantic shadows of [both man]4720-both man and [woman]473-woman , each dusky shape becoming distorted and mangled upon the tree - trunks till it wasted to nothing . [He]4714-the man to whom she was hooked looked hard into [her]0-i eyes when [she]0-i raised them for a moment ; [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba looked down again , for [his]4714-the man to whom she was hooked gaze was too strong to be received point - blank with [her]0-i own . But [she]0-i had obliquely noticed that [he]4714-the man to whom she was hooked was young and slim , and that [he]4714-the man to whom she was hooked wore three chevrons upon [his]4714-the man to whom she was hooked sleeve . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba pulled again . "[0-i] [You]0-i are [a prisoner]1560-a prisoner , [miss]1011-miss ; it is no use blinking the matter . " said [the soldier]4298-the soldier , drily . "[0-i] [I]0-i must cut [your]0-i dress if [you]0-i are in such a hurry . " "[1562-you] Yes - please do ! " [she]1011-miss exclaimed , helplessly . "[1563-the young sergeant , without ceremony] " It would n't be necessary if [you]0-i could wait a moment , "[1011-miss] and [he]1562-you unwound a cord from the little wheel . [She]1011-miss withdrew [her]1011-miss own hand , but , whether by accident or design , [he]1562-you touched it . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was vexed ; [she]1011-miss hardly knew why . [His]1562-you unravelling went on , but it nevertheless seemed coming to no end . [She]1011-miss looked at [him]1562-you again . " Thank [you]0-i for the sight of such a beautiful face ! "[1562-you] said [the young sergeant , without ceremony]1563-the young sergeant , without ceremony . [She]1011-miss coloured with embarrassment . " ' Twas un- willingly shown . "[726-the man] After all , how could [a cheerful wearer of skirts]1573-a cheerful wearer of skirts be permanently offended with [the man]726-the man ? There are occasions when [girls like [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba]1575-girls like bathsheba will put up with a great deal of unconventional behaviour . When [they]1576-they want to be praised , which is often , when [they]1576-they want to be mastered , which is sometimes ; and when [they]1576-they want no nonsense , which is seldom . Just now the first feeling was in the ascendant with [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , with a dash of the second . Moreover , by chance or by devilry , [the ministrant]1577-the ministrant was antecedently made interesting by being [a handsome stranger who had evidently seen better days]1578-a handsome stranger who had evidently seen better days . CHAPTER XXV THE NEW ACQUAINTANCE DESCRIBED IDIOSYNCRASY and vicissitude had combined to stamp [Sergeant Troy]243-bathsheba as [an exceptional being]4759-an exceptional being . [He]243-bathsheba was [a man to whom memories were an in- cumbrance , and anticipations a superfluity]4760-a man to whom memories were an in- cumbrance , and anticipations a superfluity . Simply feeling , considering , and caring for what was before [his]243-bathsheba eyes , [he]243-bathsheba was vulnerable only in the present . [His]243-bathsheba out- look upon time was as a transient flash of the eye now and then : that projection of consciousness into days gone by and to come , which makes the past a synonym for the pathetic and the future a word for circum- spection , was foreign to [Troy]243-bathsheba . With [him]243-bathsheba the past was yesterday ; the future , to - morrow ; never , the day after . On this account [he]243-bathsheba might , in certain lights , have been regarded as [one of the most fortunate of [his]243-bathsheba order]4761-one of the most fortunate of his order . For it may be argued with great plausibility that reminiscence is less an endowment than a disease , and that expectation in its only comfortable form - that of absolute faith - is practically an impossibility ; whilst in the form of hope and the secondary compounds , patience , impatience , resolve , curiosity , it is a constant fluctuation between pleasure and pain . [Sergeant Troy]243-bathsheba , being entirely innocent of the practice of expectation , was never disappointed . To set against this negative gain there may have been some positive losses from a certain narrowing of the higher tastes and sensations which it entailed . But limitation of the capacity is never recognized as a loss by [the loser therefrom]4762-the loser therefrom : in this attribute moral or aesthetic poverty contrasts plausibly with material , since [those who suffer do not mind it]4763-those who suffer do not mind it , whilst [those who mind it]4764-those who mind it soon cease to suffer . It is not a denial of anything to have been always without it , and what [Troy]243-bathsheba had never enjoyed [he]243-bathsheba did not miss ; but , being fully conscious that what [sober people]4765-sober people missed [he]243-bathsheba enjoyed , [his]243-bathsheba capacity , though really less , seemed greater than [theirs]4765-sober people . [He]243-bathsheba was moderately truthful towards [men]474-men , but to [women]493-women lied like [a Cretan]4768-a cretan - a system of ethics above all others calculated to win popularity at the first flush of admission into [lively society]4769-lively society ; and the possibility of the favour gained being transitory had reference only to the future . [He]243-bathsheba never passed the line which divides the spruce vices from the ugly ; and hence , though [his]243-bathsheba morals had hardly been applauded , disapproval of them "[1330-the sergeant] had fre- quently been tempered with a smile . This treatment had led to [his]1580-his becoming a sort of regrater of [other men]1581-other men 's gallantries , to [his]1580-his own aggrandizement as [a Corinthian]1582-a corinthian , rather than to the moral profit of [[his]1580-his hearers]1583-his hearers . [His]1580-his reason and [his]1580-his propensities had seldom any reciprocating influence , having separated by mutual consent long ago : thence it sometimes happened that , while [his]1580-his intentions were as honourable as could be wished , any particular deed formed a dark background which threw [them]1584-them into fine relief . [The sergeant]1330-the sergeant 's vicious phases being the offspring of impulse , and [his]1580-his virtuous phases of cool meditation , the latter had a modest tendency to be oftener heard of than seen . [Troy]243-bathsheba was full of activity , but [his]243-bathsheba activities were less of a locomotive than a vegetative nature ; and , never being based upon any original choice of foundation or direc- tion , they were exercised on whatever object chance might place in [their]1584-them way . Hence , whilst [he]243-bathsheba sometimes reached the brilliant in speech because that -was spontaneous , [he]243-bathsheba fell below the commonplace in action , from inability to guide incipient effort . [He]1580-his had a quick comprehension and considerable force of char- acter ; but , being without the power to combine them , the comprehension became engaged with trivialities whilst waiting for the will to direct it , and the force wasted itself in useless grooves through unheeding the comprehension . [He]1580-his was [a fairly well - educated man]1586-a fairly well - educated man for [one of middle class]1587-one of middle class - exceptionally well educated for [a common soldier]1588-a common soldier . [He]1580-his spoke fluently and unceasingly . [He]1580-his could in this way be one thing and seem another : for instance , [he]1580-his could speak of love and think of dinner ; call on the intend to owe . The wondrous power of flattery in passados at [woman]473-woman is a perception so universal as to be remarked upon by [many people]1590-many people almost as automatically as [they]1590-many people repeat a proverb , or say that [they]1590-many people are [Christians and the like]1591-christians and the like , without thinking much of the enormous corollaries which spring from the proposition . Still less is it acted upon for the good of the complemental being alluded to . With [the majority]4306-the majority such an opinion is shelved with all those trite aphorisms which require some catastrophe to bring their tremendous meanings thoroughly [home]556-home . When expressed with some amount of reflectiveness it seems co - ordinate with a belief that this flattery must be reasonable to be effective . It is to the credit of [men]474-men that [few]4511-few attempt to settle the question by experi- ment , and it is for [their]474-men happiness , perhaps , that accident has never settled it for [them]474-men . Nevertheless , that [a male dissembler who by deluging [her]473-woman with untenable fictions charms [the female]1597-the female wisely , may acquire powers reaching to the extremity of perdition]1596-a male dissembler who by deluging her with untenable fictions charms the female wisely , may acquire powers reaching to the extremity of perdition , is a truth taught to [many by unsought and wringing occurrences]1598-many by unsought and wringing occurrences . And some profess to have attained to the same knowledge by experiment as aforesaid , and jauntily continue [their]1599-their indulgence in such experiments with terrible effect . [Sergeant Troy]243-bathsheba was one . [He]243-bathsheba had been known to observe casually that in dealing with [womankind the only alternative to flattery]1600-womankind the only alternative to flattery was cursing and swearing . There was no third method . " Treat [them]4770-them fairly , and [you]243-bathsheba are [a lost man]836-a lost man . "[1330-the sergeant] [he]243-bathsheba would say . [This philosopher]1601-this philosopher 's public appearance in [Weatherbury]196-joseph promptly followed [his]243-bathsheba arrival [there]3509-there . A week or two after the shearing , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , feeling a nameless relief of spirits on account of [Boldwood]224-boldwood 's absence , approached [[her]1603-her hayfields]1604-her hayfields and looked over the hedge towards [the haymakers]1605-the haymakers . [They]1605-the haymakers consisted in about equal proportions of gnarled and flexuous forms , [the former]1606-the former being [the men]3799-the men , [the latter]1608-the latter [the women]3489-the women , who wore tilt bonnets covered with nankeen , which hung in a curtain upon [their]3489-the women shoulders . [Coggan]180-coggan and [Mark Clark]178-mark clark were mowing in [a less forward meadow]1610-a less forward meadow , [Clark]178-mark clark humming a tune to the strokes of [his]178-mark clark scythe , to which [Jan]285-jan made no attempt to keep time with [his]285-jan . In the first mead [they]1605-the haymakers were already loading hay , [the women]3489-the women raking it into cocks and windrows , and [the men]3799-the men tossing it upon the waggon . From behind the waggon a bright scarlet spot emerged , and went on loading unconcernedly with the rest . It was [the gallant sergeant]1613-the gallant sergeant , who had come hay- making for pleasure ; and [nobody]439-nobody could deny that [he]1613-the gallant sergeant was doing [the mistress of [the farm]3760-the farm]1615-the mistress of the farm real knight - service by this voluntary contribution of [his]1613-the gallant sergeant labour at a busy time . As soon as [she]1615-the mistress of the farm had entered [the field]3467-the field [Troy]243-bathsheba saw [her]1615-the mistress of the farm , and sticking [his]243-bathsheba pitchfork into the ground and picking up [his]243-bathsheba crop or cane , [he]243-bathsheba came forward . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba blushed with half - angry embarrassment , and adjusted [her]1615-the mistress of the farm eyes as well as [her]1615-the mistress of the farm feet to the direct line of [her]1615-the mistress of the farm path . "[0-i] [I]0-i again say [you]0-i are [a most fascinating woman]1646-a most fascinating woman . There 's nothing remarkable in [my]0-i saying so , is there ? " "[0-i] Because it - it is n't a correct one . " [she]0-i femininely murmured . "[0-i] O , fie - fie- !
