"[3527-the woman] The tenderest and softest phases of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's nature were prominent now - advanced impulsively for [his]243-bathsheba acceptance , without any of the disguises and defences which the wariness of [her]2363-her character when [she]2363-her was cool too frequently threw over [them]2364-them . [Few men]2365-few men could have resisted the arch yet dignified entreaty of the beautiful face , thrown a little back and sideways in the well known attitude that expresses more than the words it accompanies , and which seems to have been designed for these special occasions . "[2371-i] " But just now [you]244-frank said "[2371-i] ties ; " and then - [that woman [we]5347-we met]5346-that woman we met ? "[2371-i] " Yes . There , now that [you]244-frank have wormed it out of [me]2371-i , [I]2371-i hope [you]244-frank are content . "[2371-i] " And what are the ties ? "[2372-she] " Oh ! that meant nothing - a mere jest . "[2372-she] " A mere jest ! "[2372-she] [she]2372-she said , in mournful astonishment . " Can [you]244-frank jest when [I]2373-i am so wretchedly in earnest ? Tell [me]2373-i the truth , [Frank]244-frank . [I]2373-i am not [a fool]4245-a fool , [you]244-frank know , although [I]2373-i am [a woman]459-a woman , and have [[my]2373-i woman]5350-my woman 's moments . Come ! treat [me]2373-i fairly . "[2373-i] [she]2372-she said , looking honestly and fearlessly into [his]2373-i face . " [I]2408-i do n't want much ; bare justice - that 's all ! Ah ! once [I]2408-i felt [I]2408-i could be content with nothing less than the highest homage from [the husband]2250-the husband [I]2408-i should choose . Now , anything short of cruelty will content [me]2408-i . Yes ! [the independent and spirited Bathsheba]5352-the independent and spirited bathsheba is come to this ! "[2408-i] " For [Heaven]269-heaven 's sake do n't be so [desperate!"Troy]350-desperate!"troy[243-bathsheba] said , snappishly , rising as [he]2373-i did so , and leaving [the room]4025-the room . Directly [he]2373-i had gone , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba burst into great sobs - dry - eyed sobs , which cut as they came , without any softening by tears . But [she]2372-she determined to repress all evidences of feeling . [She]2372-she was conquered ; but [she]2372-she would never own it as long as [she]2372-she lived . [Her]2372-she pride was indeed brought low by despairing discoveries of [her]2372-she spoliation by marriage with a less pure nature than [her]2372-she own . [She]2372-she chafed to and fro in rebelliousness , like a caged leopard ; [her]2372-she whole soul was in arms , and the blood fired [her]2372-she face . Until [she]2372-she had met [Troy , Bath-]351-bath- [sheba]243-bathsheba had been proud of [her]2372-she position as [a woman]459-a woman ; it had been a glory to [her]2372-she to know that [her]2372-she lips had been touched by [no man]3662-no man 's on [earth]499-earth - that [her]2372-she waist had never been encircled by [a lover]1382-a lover 's arm . [She]2372-she hated [herself]2372-she now . In those earlier days [she]2372-she had always nourished a secret contempt for [girls who were the slaves of [the first goodlooking young fellow who should choose to salute [them]2379-girls who were the slaves of the first goodlooking young fellow who should choose to salute them]2380-the first goodlooking young fellow who should choose to salute them]2379-girls who were the slaves of the first goodlooking young fellow who should choose to salute them . [She]2372-she had never taken kindly to the idea of marriage in the abstract as did [the majority of women [she]2372-she saw about [her]2372-she]2381-the majority of women she saw about her . In the turmoil of [her]2372-she anxiety for [[her]2372-she lover]1863-her lover [she]2372-she had agreed to marry [him]1863-her lover ; but the perception that had accompanied [her]2372-she happiest hours on this account was rather that of self - sacrifice than of promotion and honour . Although [she]2372-she scarcely knew [the divinity]2383-the divinity 's name , [Diana]352-diana was [the goddess whom [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba instinctively adored]2384-the goddess whom bathsheba instinctively adored . That [she]2372-she had never , by look , word , or sign , encouraged [a man]3474-a man to approach [her]2372-she - that [she]2372-she had felt [herself]2372-she sufficient to [herself]2372-she , and had in the independence of [her]2372-she girlish heart fancied there was a certain degradation in renouncing the simplicity of a maiden existence to become [the humbler half of an indifferent matrimonial whole]2386-the humbler half of an indifferent matrimonial whole - were facts now bitterly remembered . O , if [she]2372-she had never stooped to folly of this kind , respectable as it was , and could only stand again , as [she]2372-she had stood on [the hill at [Norcombe]18-norcombe]2387-the hill at norcombe , and dare [Troy]243-bathsheba or [any other man]2388-any other man to pollute a hair of [her]2372-she head by [his]243-bathsheba interference ! The next morning [she]2372-she rose earlier than usual , and had the horse saddled for [her]2372-she ride round [the farm]3760-the farm in the customary way . When [she]2372-she came in at half - past eight - [their]2390-their usual hour for breakfasting - [she]2372-she was in- formed that [[her]2372-she husband]2239-her husband had risen , taken [his]2239-her husband breakfast , and driven off to [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge with the gig and [Poppet]311-poppet . After breakfast [she]2372-she was cool and collected - quite [herself]2372-she in fact - and [she]2372-she rambled to the gate , intending to walk to [another quarter of [the farm]3760-the farm]2392-another quarter of the farm , which [she]2372-she still personally superintended as well as [her]2372-she duties in [the house]552-the house would permit , continually , however , finding [her-]2372-she self preceded in forethought by [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel , for whom [she]2372-she began to entertain the genuine friendship of [a sister]2395-a sister . Of course , [she]2372-she sometimes thought of [him]144-gabriel in the light of [an old lover]2396-an old lover , and had momentary imaginings of what life with [him]144-gabriel as [a husband]3655-a husband would have been like ; also of life with [Boldwood]224-boldwood under the same conditions . But [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , though [she]2372-she could feel , was not much given to futile dreaming , and [her]2372-she musings under this head were short and entirely confined to the times when [Troy]243-bathsheba 's neglect was more than ordinarily evident . [She]2372-she saw coming up [the road]477-the road [a man]3474-a man like [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood . It was [Mr. Boldwood]224-boldwood . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba blushed painfully , and watched . [The farmer]3540-the farmer stopped when still a long way off , and held up [his]3540-the farmer hand to [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel , who was in a footpath across [the field]3467-the field . [The two men]2095-the two men then approached [each other]3826-each other and seemed to engage in earnest conversation . Thus [they]2095-the two men continued for a long time . [Joseph Poor-]188-joseph grass now passed near [them]2095-the two men , wheeling a barrow of apples up [the hill]3452-the hill to [[Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's residence]2405-bathsheba 's residence . [Her]217-fanny death might have been brought on by biding in the night wind , [you]2432-you know , [ma'am]712-ma'am ; for [people]3461-people used to say [she]217-fanny 'd go off in a decline : [she]217-fanny used to cough a good deal in winter time . However , ' tisn't much odds to [us]2436-us about that now , for ' tis all over . " "[217-fanny] Have [you]144-gabriel heard a different story at all ? "[217-fanny] " [[Her]217-fanny young man]991-her young man was [a soldier]995-a soldier , was [he]991-her young man not ? "[304-mr. troy] " Yes . In the same regiment as [Mr. Troy]304-mr. troy . " "[304-mr. troy] One day [I]0-i just named it to [him]304-mr. troy , and asked [him]304-mr. troy if [he]304-mr. troy knew [[Fanny]217-fanny 's young man]1117-fanny 's young man . "[2492-the girl in waiting] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , with the nervous petulance that comes from worrying perceptions . CHAPTER XLII [JOSEPH]188-joseph AND [HIS]188-joseph BURDEN A WALL bounded [the site of [Casterbridge Union-]107-casterbridge union- house]2440-the site of casterbridge union- house , except along a portion of the end . Here a high gable stood prominent , and [it]2441-it was covered like the front with a mat of ivy . In [this gable]2442-this gable was no window , chimney , ornament , or protuberance of any kind . The single feature appertaining to [it]2441-it , beyond the expanse of dark green leaves , was a small door . The situation of the door was peculiar . [The sill]2443-the sill was three or four feet above the ground , and for a moment [one]4328-one was at a loss for an explanation of this exceptional altitude , till ruts immediately beneath sug- gested that the door was used solely for the passage of articles and [persons]2445-persons to and from the level of [a vehicle]685-a vehicle standing on the outside . Upon the whole , the door seemed to advertise itself as a species of [Traitor]356-traitor 's Gate translated to another sphere . That entry and exit hereby was only at rare intervals became apparent on noting that tufts of grass were allowed to flourish undis- turbed in the chinks of the sill . As the clock over [the South - street Alms - house]2447-the south - street alms - house pointed to five minutes to three , a blue spring waggon , picked out with red , and containing boughs and flowers , passed the end of [the street]3706-the street , and up towards this side of [the building]3834-the building . Whilst the chimes were yet stammering out a shattered form of " [Malbrook]357-malbrook . "[2493-the landlady] [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph rang the bell , and received directions to back [his]196-joseph waggon against the high door under the gable . The door then opened , and a plain elm coffin was slowly thrust forth , and laid by [two men in fustian along the middle of [the vehicle]460-the vehicle]2450-two men in fustian along the middle of the vehicle . [One of [the men]3799-the men]2452-one of the men then stepped up beside it , took from [his]2452-one of the men pocket a lump of chalk , and wrote upon the cover the name and a few other words in a large scrawling hand . [We]2454-we believe that [they]3799-the men do these things more tenderly now , and provide a plate . [He]196-joseph covered the whole with a black cloth , threadbare , but decent , the tailboard of the waggon was returned to its place , [one of [the men]3799-the men]2452-one of the men handed a certificate of registry to [Poorgrass]196-joseph , and [both]2457-both entered the door , closing it behind [them]2457-both . [Their]2457-both connection with [her]2458-her , short as it had been , was over for ever . [Joseph]196-joseph then placed the flowers as enjoined , and the evergreens around the flowers , till it was difficult to divine what the waggon contained ; [he]196-joseph smacked [his]196-joseph whip , and [the rather pleasing funeral car]2459-the rather pleasing funeral car crept down [the hill]3452-the hill , and along [the road]477-the road to [Weatherbury]196-joseph . The afternoon drew on apace , and , looking to the right towards [the sea]2462-the sea as [he]196-joseph walked beside the horse , Poor- grass saw strange clouds and scrolls of mist rolling over the long ridges which girt the landscape in that quarter . [They]3799-the men came in yet greater volumes , and indolently crept across [the intervening valleys]2463-the intervening valleys , and around the withered papery flags of [the moor]4636-the moor and [river brinks]2465-river brinks . Then their dank spongy forms closed in upon the sky . It was a sudden overgrowth of atmospheric fungi which had their roots in [the neighbouring sea]2466-the neighbouring sea , and by the time that horse , [man]3450-man , and corpse entered [Yalbury Great Wood]108-yalbury great wood , these silent workings of an invisible hand had reached [them]2457-both , and [they]2457-both were completely enveloped , this being the first arrival of the autumn fogs , and the first fog of the series . The air was as an eye suddenly struck blind . The waggon and its load rolled no longer on the horizontal division between clearness and opacity , but were imbedded in an elastic body of a monotonous pallor throughout . There was no perceptible motion in the air , not a visible drop of water fell upon a leaf of the beeches , birches , and firs composing the wood on either side . The trees stood in an attitude of intentness , as if [they]2468-they waited longingly for a wind to come and rock [them]2468-they . A startling quiet overhung all surrounding things - so completely , that the crunching of the waggon- wheels was as a great noise , and small rustles , which had never obtained a hearing except by night , were dis- tinctly individualized . [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph looked round upon [his]196-joseph sad burden as it loomed faintly through the flowering laurustinus , then at the unfathomable gloom amid the high trees on each hand , indistinct , shadowless , and spectrelike in their monochrome of grey . [He]196-joseph felt anything but cheer- ful , and wished [he]196-joseph had the company even of [a child]786-a child or dog . Stopping [the home]2470-the home , [he]196-joseph listened . Not a footstep or wheel was audible anywhere around , and the dead silence was broken only by a heavy particle falling from a tree through the evergreens and alighting with a smart rap upon the coffin of poor [Fanny]217-fanny . The fog had by this time saturated the trees , and this was the first dropping of water from the overbrimming leaves . The hollow echo of its fall reminded [the waggoner]461-the waggoner painfully of [the grim Leveller]2472-the grim leveller . Then hard by came down another drop , then two or three . Presently there was a continual tapping of these heavy drops upon the dead leaves , [the road]477-the road , and [the travellers]2474-the travellers . The nearer boughs were beaded with the mist to the greyness of [aged men]2475-aged men , and the rusty- red leaves of the beeches were hung with similar drops , like diamonds on auburn hair . At [the roadside hamlet called [Roy - Town]109-roy - town]2476-the roadside hamlet called roy - town , just beyond [this wood]2477-this wood , was [[the old inn]2478-the old inn [Buck]201-buck 's Head]2479-the old inn buck 's head . [It]2479-the old inn buck 's head was about a mile and a half from [Weatherbury]196-joseph , and in the meridian times of stage - coach travelling had been [the place where [many coaches]2481-many coaches changed and kept [their]2481-many coaches relays of horses]2480-the place where many coaches changed and kept their relays of horses . All the old stabling was now pulled down , and little remained besides [the habitable inn]2482-the habitable inn [itself]2482-the habitable inn , which , standing a little way back from [the road]477-the road , sig- nified its existence to [people]3461-people far up and down [the highway]2292-the highway by a sign hanging from the horizontal bough of an elm on the opposite side of the way . [Travellers]2486-travellers - for the variety [TOURIST]358-tourist had hardly developed into a distinct species at this date - some- times said in passing , when [they]2486-travellers cast [their]2486-travellers eyes up to the sign - bearing tree , that [artists]2487-artists were fond of repre- senting the signboard hanging thus , but that [they]2486-travellers [themselves]2486-travellers had never before noticed so perfect an instance in actual working order . It was near this tree that the waggon was standing into which [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel crept on [his]144-gabriel first journey to [Weatherbury]196-joseph ; but , owing to the darkness , the sign and [the inn]2488-the inn had been un- observed . The manners of [the inn]2488-the inn were of the old - established type . Indeed , in the minds of [[its]2488-the inn frequenters]2490-its frequenters they existed as unalterable formulae : E.G. - Rap with the bottom of [your]2491-your pint for more liquor . For tobacco , shout . In calling for [the girl in waiting]2492-the girl in waiting , say , " [Maid]5390-maid ! "[178-mark clark] Ditto for [the landlady]2493-the landlady , " [Old Soul]5391-old soul ! "[178-mark clark] etc . , etc . It was a relief to [Joseph]196-joseph 's heart when the friendly signboard came in view , and , stopping [his]196-joseph horse immediately beneath it , [he]196-joseph proceeded to fulfil an intention made a long time before . [His]196-joseph spirits were oozing out of [him]196-joseph quite . [He]196-joseph turned the horse 's head to [the green bank]2494-the green bank , and entered [the hostel]2495-the hostel for a mug of ale . Going down into [the kitchen of [the inn]2488-the inn]2496-the kitchen of the inn , the floor of which was a step below [the passage]4537-the passage , which in its turn was a step below [the road outside]3874-the road outside , what should [Joseph]196-joseph see to gladden [his]196-joseph eyes but two copper - coloured discs , in the form of the countenances of [Mr. Jan Coggan]180-coggan and [Mr. Mark Clark]178-mark clark . [These owners of [the two most appreciative throats in [the neighbourhood]615-the neighbourhood]2501-the two most appreciative throats in the neighbourhood]2500-these owners of the two most appreciative throats in the neighbourhood , within the pale of respectability , were now sitting face to face over a threelegged circular table , having an iron rim to keep cups and pots from being accidentally elbowed off ; they might have been said to resemble the setting sun and the full moon shining VIS - A - VIS across [the globe]2503-the globe . " Why , ' tis [neighbour Poorgrass]196-joseph ! "[196-joseph] said [Mark Clark]178-mark clark . " [I]196-joseph 'm sure [your]196-joseph face do n't praise [[your]196-joseph mistress]2139-your mistress 's table , [Joseph]196-joseph . "[196-joseph] " [I]180-coggan 've had [a very pale companion]5393-a very pale companion for the last four miles . "[180-coggan] said [Joseph]196-joseph , indulging in a shudder toned down by resignation . " And to speak the truth , ' twas beginning to tell upon [me]196-joseph . [I]196-joseph assure [ye]196-joseph , [I]196-joseph ha'n't seed the colour of victuals or drink since breakfast time this morning , and that was no more than a dew - bit afield . "[196-joseph] " Then drink , [Joseph]196-joseph , and do n't restrain [yourself]196-joseph ! "[180-coggan] said [Coggan]180-coggan , handing [him]196-joseph a hooped mug three- quarters full . [Joseph]196-joseph drank for a moderately long time , then for a longer time , saying , as [he]196-joseph lowered the jug , " ' Tis pretty drinking - very pretty drinking , and is more than cheerful on [my]196-joseph melancholy errand , so to speak it . "[196-joseph] " True , drink is a pleasant delight . "[196-joseph] said [Jan]180-coggan , as one who repeated a truism so familiar to [his]180-coggan brain that [he]180-coggan hardly noticed its passage over [his]180-coggan tongue ; and , lifting the cup , [Coggan]180-coggan tilted [his]180-coggan head gradually backwards , with closed eyes , that [his]180-coggan expectant soul might not be diverted for one instant from its bliss by irrelevant surroundings . " Well , [I]835-the lord must be on again . "[835-the lord] said [Poorgrass]196-joseph . "[835-the lord] " Ay - [i've]835-the lord heard of it . "[196-joseph] " [I]196-joseph do n't mind taking just the least thimbleful [ye]196-joseph can dream of more with [ye]196-joseph , [sonnies]5404-sonnies . But only a few minutes , because ' tis as ' tis . "[196-joseph] " Of course , [you]196-joseph 'll have another drop . [A man]3474-a man 's twice [the man]726-the man afterwards . [You]196-joseph feel so warm and glorious , and [you]196-joseph whop and slap at [your]196-joseph work without any trouble , and everything goes on like sticks a- breaking . "True[2510-they] . " said [Mark Clark]178-mark clark . "[0-i] ' Tis a talent [the Lord]835-the lord has mercifully bestowed upon [us]2505-we , and [we]2505-we ought not to neglect it . Sit down . " The longer [Joseph Poorgrass]196-joseph remained , the less [his]196-joseph spirit was troubled by the duties which devolved upon [him]196-joseph this afternoon . The minutes glided by uncounted , until the evening shades began perceptibly to deepen , and the eyes of the three were but sparkling points on the surface of darkness . [[Coggan]180-coggan 's repeater]5410-coggan 's repeater struck six from [his]180-coggan pocket in the usual still small tones . "[2556-we] [Nobody]439-nobody can hurt [a dead woman]2555-a dead woman . " at length said [Coggan]180-coggan , with the precision of a machine . "[144-gabriel] [Gabriel]144-gabriel , seeing that neither of the three was in a fit state to Cake charge of the waggon for the remainder of the journey , made no reply , but , closing the door again upon [them]2565-we , went across to where [the vehicle]460-the vehicle stood , now getting indistinct in the fog and gloom of this mildewy time . [He]144-gabriel pulled the horse 's head from the large patch of turf [it]460-the vehicle had eaten bare , readjusted the boughs over the coffin , and drove along through the unwholesome night . It had gradually become rumoured in [the village]3754-the village that the body to be brought and buried that day was all that was left of [the unfortunate Fanny Robin]217-fanny who had followed [the Eleventh]241-the eleventh from [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge through [Melchester]46-melchester and onwards . But , thanks to [Boldwood]231-boldwood 's reticence and [Oak]144-gabriel 's generosity , [the lover [she]217-fanny had followed]2568-the lover she had followed had never been individualized as [Troy]243-bathsheba . [Gabriel]144-gabriel hoped that the whole truth of the matter might not be published till at any rate [the girl]462-the girl had been in [her]462-the girl grave for a few days , when the interposing barriers of earth and time , and a sense that the events had been somewhat shut into oblivion , would deaden the sting that revelation and invidious remark would have for [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba just now . By the time that [Gabriel]144-gabriel reached [the old manor- house]2570-the old manor- house , [[her]217-fanny residence]2571-her residence , which lay in [his]144-gabriel way to [the church]489-the church , it was quite dark . [A man]3474-a man came from the gate and said through the fog , which hung between [them]2574-them like blown flour - " Is that [Poorgrass]363-poorgrass with the corpse ? "[144-gabriel] [Gabriel]144-gabriel recognized the voice as that of [the parson]2007-the parson . " The corpse is here , [sir]3717-sir . "[144-gabriel] said [Gabriel]144-gabriel . " [I]144-gabriel have just been to inquire of [Mrs. Troy]353-troy if [she]353-troy could tell [me]144-gabriel the reason of the delay . [I]144-gabriel am afraid it is too late now for the funeral to be performed with proper decency . Have [you]3717-sir [the registrar]5429-the registrar 's certificate ? "[144-gabriel] " No . "[144-gabriel] said [Gabriel]144-gabriel . " [I]4518-his mistress expect [Poorgrass]363-poorgrass has that ; and [he]363-poorgrass 's at the [Buck]201-buck 's Head . [I]4518-his mistress forgot to ask [him]363-poorgrass for it . "[4518-his mistress] " Then that settles the matter . [We]5430-we 'll put off the funeral till to - morrow morning . The body may be brought on to [the church]489-the church , or it may be left here at [the farm]3760-the farm and fetched by [the bearers]5433-the bearers in the morning . [They]5433-the bearers waited more than an hour , and have now gone [home]556-home . "[4518-his mistress] [Gabriel]144-gabriel had [his]144-gabriel reasons for thinking [the latter]1608-the latter a most objectionable plan , notwithstanding that [Fanny]217-fanny had been [an inmate of [the farm - house]2578-the farm - house]2577-an inmate of the farm - house for several years in the lifetime of [[Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's uncle]2579-bathsheba 's uncle . Visions of several unhappy contingencies which might arise from this delay flitted before [him]144-gabriel . But [his]144-gabriel will was not law , and [he]144-gabriel went [indoors]1439-indoors to inquire of [[his]144-gabriel mistress]4518-his mistress what were [her]4518-his mistress wishes on the subject . [He]144-gabriel found [her]4518-his mistress in an unusual mood : [her]4518-his mistress eyes as [she]4518-his mistress looked up to [him]144-gabriel were suspicious and perplexed as with some antecedent thought . [Troy]243-bathsheba had not yet returned . At first [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba assented with a mien of indifference to [his]144-gabriel proposition that [they]2582-they should go on to [the church]489-the church at once with [their]2582-they burden ; but immediately afterwards , following [Gabriel]144-gabriel to the gate , [she]4518-his mistress swerved to the extreme of solicitousness on [Fanny]217-fanny 's account , and desired that [the girl]462-the girl might be brought into [the house]552-the house . [Oak]144-gabriel argued upon the convenience of leaving [her]462-the girl in [the waggon]458-the waggon , just as [she]462-the girl lay now , with [her]462-the girl flowers and green leaves about [her]462-the girl , merely wheeling [the vehicle]460-the vehicle into [the coach - house]4991-the coach - house till the morning , but to no purpose , " It is unkind and unchristian . "[4518-his mistress] [she]4518-his mistress said , " to leave the poor thing in [a coach - house]5435-a coach - house all night . "[217-fanny] Very well , then . " said [the parson]2007-the parson . "[1228-child] And [I]0-i will arrange that the funeral shall take place early to- morrow . Perhaps [Mrs. Troy]353-troy is right in feeling that [we]2589-we can not treat [a dead fellow - creature]2590-a dead fellow - creature too thoughtfully [We]2589-we must remember that though [she]353-troy may have erred grievously in leaving [[her]353-troy [home]556-home]2591-her home , [she]353-troy is still [[our]2589-we sister]2593-our sister : and it is to be believed that [God]171-god 's uncovenanted mercies are extended towards [her]353-troy , and that [she]353-troy is a member of [the flock of [Christ]364-christ]2594-the flock of christ . " [The parson]2007-the parson 's words spread into the heavy air with a sad yet unperturbed cadence , and [Gabriel]144-gabriel shed an honest tear . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba seemed unmoved . [Mr. Thirdly]365-mr. thirdly then left [them]2589-we , and [Gabriel]144-gabriel lighted a lantern . Fetching [three other men]5438-three other men to assist [him]144-gabriel , [they]5438-three other men bore [the unconscious truant]5439-the unconscious truant indoors , placing the coffin on two benches in the middle of [a little sitting - room next [the hall]4051-the hall]5440-a little sitting - room next the hall , as [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba directed . Every one except [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel then left [the room]4025-the room . [He]144-gabriel still indecisively lingered beside the body . [He]144-gabriel was deeply troubled at the wretchedly ironical aspect that circumstances were putting on with regard to [[Troy]243-bathsheba 's wife]5443-troy 's wife , and at [his]144-gabriel own powerlessness to counteract [them]2589-we , n spite of [his]144-gabriel careful manoeuvring all this day , the very worst event that could in any way have happened in connection with the burial had happened now . [Oak]144-gabriel imagined a terrible discovery resulting from this after- noon 's work that might cast over [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's life a shade which the interposition of many lapsing years might but indifferently lighten , and which nothing at all might altogether remove . Suddenly , as in a last attempt to save [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba from , at any rate , immediate anguish , [he]144-gabriel looked again , as [he]144-gabriel had looked before , at the chalk writing upon the coffinlid . The scrawl was this simple one , "[1228-child] [Fanny Robin]217-fanny and [child]1228-child . " [Gabriel]144-gabriel took [his]144-gabriel handkerchief and carefully rubbed out the two latter words , leaving visible the inscription "[2596-you] [Fanny Robin]217-fanny " only . [He]144-gabriel then left [the room]4025-the room , and went out quietly by the front door . CHAPTER XLIII [FANNY]217-fanny 'S REVENGE "[191-liddy] DO [you]2596-you want [me]0-i any longer [ma'am]712-ma'am ? " inquired [Liddy]191-liddy , at a later hour the same evening , standing by the door with a chamber candlestick in [her]0-i hand and addressing [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , who sat cheerless and alone in the large parlour beside the first fire of the season . "[217-fanny] No more to - night , [Liddy]191-liddy . " "[0-i] [I]0-i 'll sit up for [master]537-master if [you]2596-you like , [ma'am]712-ma'am . [I]0-i am not at all afraid of [Fanny]217-fanny , if [I]0-i may sit in [[my]0-i own room]2600-my own room and have a candle . [She]217-fanny was such [a childlike , nesh young thing]2601-a childlike , nesh young thing that [her]217-fanny spirit could n't appear to [anybody]3643-anybody if it tried , [I]0-i 'm quite sure . " "[0-i] O no , no ! [You]2596-you go to bed . [I]0-i 'll sit up for [him]537-master [myself]0-i till twelve o'clock , and if [he]537-master has not arrived by that time , [I]0-i shall give [him]537-master up and go to bed too . " It is half - past ten now . "[2596-you] " Oh ! is it ? "[0-i] Why do n't [you]2596-you sit [upstairs]2603-upstairs , [ma'am]712-ma'am ? " "[191-liddy] Why do n't [I]0-i ? " said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , desultorily . "[191-liddy] It is n't worth while - there 's a fire here , [Liddy]191-liddy . " [She]0-i suddenly exclaimed in an impulsive and excited whisper , Have [you]191-liddy heard anything strange said of [Fanny]217-fanny ? "[0-i] The words had no sooner escaped [her]0-i than an expres- sion of unutterable regret crossed [her]0-i face , and [she]0-i burst into tears . " No - not a word ! "[0-i] said [Liddy]191-liddy , looking at [the weeping woman]2605-the weeping woman with astonishment . " What is it makes [you]2605-the weeping woman cry so , [ma'am]712-ma'am ; has anything hurt [you]2605-the weeping woman ? "[191-liddy] [She]0-i came to [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's side with a face full of sympathy . " No , [Liddy]191-liddy - [i]191-liddy do n't want [you]191-liddy any more . [I]191-liddy can hardly say why [I]191-liddy have taken to crying lately : [I]191-liddy never used to cry . Good - night . "[191-liddy] [Liddy]191-liddy then left [the parlour]4683-the parlour and closed the door . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was lonely and miserable now ; not lone- lier actually than [she]0-i had been before [her]0-i marriage ; but [her]0-i loneliness then was to that of the present time as the solitude of [a mountain]2607-a mountain is to the solitude of [a cave]2153-a cave . And within the last day or two had come these disquieting thoughts about [[her]0-i husband]2239-her husband 's past . [Her]0-i wayward sentiment that evening concerning [Fanny]217-fanny 's temporary resting - place had been the result of a strange complication of impulses in [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's bosom . Per- haps it would be more accurately described as a determined rebellion against [her]0-i prejudices , a revulsion from a lower instinct of uncharitableness , which would have withheld all sympathy from [the dead woman]2610-the dead woman , be- cause in life [she]0-i had preceded [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba in the atten- tions of [a man whom [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba]2611-a man whom bathsheba had by no means ceased from loving , though [her]0-i love was sick to death just now with the gravity of a further misgiving . In five or ten minutes there was another tap at the door . [Liddy]191-liddy reappeared , and coming in a little way stood hesitating , until at length [she]191-liddy said,!Maryann has just heard something very strange , but [I]0-i know it is n't true . And [we]2612-we shall be sure to know the rights of it in a day or two . " "[217-fanny] What is it ? " "[217-fanny] Oh , nothing connected with [you]191-liddy or [us]2612-we , [ma'am]712-ma'am . It is about [Fanny]217-fanny . That same thing [you]191-liddy have heard . " "[0-i] [I]0-i have heard nothing . " "[0-i] [I]0-i mean that a wicked story is got to [Weatherbury]196-joseph within this last hour - that - - " [Liddy]191-liddy came close to [[her]191-liddy mistress]4024-her mistress and whispered the remainder of the sentence slowly into [her]4024-her mistress ear , inclining [her]191-liddy head as [she]191-liddy spoke in the direction of [the room where [Fanny]217-fanny lay]5447-the room where fanny lay . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba trembled from head to foot . "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't believe it ! " [she]0-i said , excitedly . "[712-ma'am] And there 's only one name written on the coffin - cover . " "[2618-he] Nor [I]0-i , [ma'am]712-ma'am . And [a good many others]2615-a good many others do n't ; for [we]2616-we should surely have been told more about it if it had been true - do n't [you]712-ma'am think so , [ma'am]712-ma'am ? " "[2619-her] [We]2616-we might or [we]2616-we might not . " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba turned and looked into the fire , that [Liddy]191-liddy might not see [her]191-liddy face . Finding that [[her]191-liddy mistress]4024-her mistress was going to say no more , [Liddy]191-liddy glided out , closed the door softly , and went to bed . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's face , as [she]191-liddy continued looking into the fire that evening , might have excited solicitousness on [her]191-liddy account even among [those who loved [her]191-liddy least]5449-those who loved her least . The sadness of [Fanny Robin]217-fanny 's fate did not make [Bath-]351-bath- [sheba]243-bathsheba 's glorious , although [she]191-liddy was [the Esther to [this poor Vashti]5451-this poor vashti]5450-the esther to this poor vashti , and [their]5452-their fates might be supposed to stand in some respects as contrasts to [each other]3826-each other . When [Liddy]191-liddy came into [the room]4025-the room a second time the beautiful eyes which met [hers]191-liddy had worn a listless , weary look- When [she]191-liddy went out after telling the story [they]5452-their had ex- pressed wretchedness in full activity . [Her]191-liddy simple country nature , fed on old - fashioned principles , was troubled by that which would have troubled [a woman of [the world]447-the world]4844-a woman of the world very little , both [Fanny]217-fanny and [[her]217-fanny child]5457-her child , if [she]217-fanny had one , being dead . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had grounds for conjecturing a connection between [her]191-liddy own history and the dimly suspected tragedy of [Fanny]217-fanny 's end which [Oak]144-gabriel and [Boldwood]231-boldwood never for a moment credited [her]191-liddy with possessing . The meeting with [the lonely woman on the previous Saturday night]5458-the lonely woman on the previous saturday night had been unwitnessed and unspoken of . [Oak]144-gabriel may have had the best of intentions in withholding for as many days as possible the details of what had happened to [Fanny]217-fanny ; but had [he]144-gabriel known that [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's perceptions had already been exercised in the matter , [he]144-gabriel would have done nothing to lengthen the minutes of suspense [she]191-liddy was now undergoing , when the certainty which must terminate it would be the worst fact suspected after all . [She]191-liddy suddenly felt a longing desire to speak to [some one stronger than [herself]191-liddy]5459-some one stronger than herself , and so get strength to sustain [her]191-liddy surmised position with dignity and [her]191-liddy lurking doubts with stoicism . Where could [she]191-liddy find [such a friend]5460-such a friend ? nowhere in [the house]552-the house . [She]191-liddy was by far [the coolest of [the women under [her]191-liddy roof]5463-the women under her roof]5462-the coolest of the women under her roof . Patience and suspension of judgement for a few hours were what [she]191-liddy wanted to learn , and there was [nobody]439-nobody to teach [her]191-liddy . Might [she]191-liddy but go to [Gabriel Oak]144-gabriel ! - but that could not be . What a way [Oak]144-gabriel had , [she]191-liddy thought , of enduring things . [Boldwood]231-boldwood , who seemed so much deeper and higher and stronger in feeling than [Gabriel]144-gabriel , had not yet learnt , any more than [she]191-liddy [herself]191-liddy , the simple lesson which [Oak]144-gabriel showed a mastery of by every turn and look [he]144-gabriel gave - that among the multitude of interests by which [he]144-gabriel was surrounded , those which affected [his]144-gabriel personal wellbeing were not the most absorbing and important in [his]144-gabriel eyes . [Oak]144-gabriel meditatively looked upon the horizon of circumstances without any special regard to [his]144-gabriel own standpoint in the midst . That was how [she]191-liddy would wish to be . But then [Oak]144-gabriel was not racked by incertitude upon the inmost matter of [his]144-gabriel bosom , as [she]191-liddy was at this moment . [Oak]144-gabriel knew all about [Fanny]217-fanny that [he]144-gabriel wished to know - [she]191-liddy felt convinced of that . If [she]191-liddy were to go to [him]144-gabriel now at once and say no more than these few words,!What is the truth of the story ? "[2619-her] [he]2618-he would feel bound in honour to tell [her]2619-her . It would be an inexpressible relief . No further speech would need to be uttered . [He]2618-he knew [her]2619-her so well that no eccentricity of behaviour in [her]2619-her would alarm [him]2618-he . [She]2619-her flung a cloak round [her]2619-her , went to the door and opened it . Every blade , every twig was still . The air was yet thick with moisture , though somewhat less dense than during the afternoon , and a steady smack of drops upon the fallen leaves under the boughs was almost musical in its soothing regularity . lt seemed better to be out of [the house]552-the house than within [it]552-the house , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba closed the door , and walked slowly down [the lane]3664-the lane till [she]2619-her came opposite to [[Gabriel]144-gabriel 's cottage]2622-gabriel 's cottage , where [he]144-gabriel now lived alone , having left [[Coggan]180-coggan 's house]2623-coggan 's house through being pinched for [room]2624-room . There was a light in one window only ' , and that was [downstairs]1015-downstairs . The shutters were not closed , nor was any blind or curtain drawn over the window , neither robbery nor observation being a contingency which could do much injury to [the occupant of the domicile]2626-the occupant of the domicile . Yes , it was [Gabriel]144-gabriel [himself]144-gabriel who was sitting up : [he]144-gabriel was reading , From [her]2619-her standing - place in [the road]477-the road [she]2619-her could see [him]144-gabriel plainly , sitting quite still , [his]144-gabriel light curly head upon [his]144-gabriel hand , and only occasionally looking up to snuff the candle which stood beside [him]144-gabriel . At length [he]144-gabriel looked at the clock , seemed surprised at the lateness of the hour , closed [his]144-gabriel book , and arose . [He]144-gabriel was going to bed , [she]2619-her knew , and if [she]2619-her tapped it must be done at once . Alas for [her]2619-her resolve ! [She]2619-her felt [she]2619-her could not do it , Not for worlds now could [she]2619-her give a hint about [her]2619-her misery to [him]144-gabriel , much less ask [him]144-gabriel plainly for information on the cause of [Fanny]217-fanny 's death . [She]2619-her must suspect , and guess , and chafe , and bear it all alone . Like [a homeless wanderer]2628-a homeless wanderer [she]2619-her lingered by [the bank]4832-the bank , as if lulled and fascinated by the atmosphere of content which seemed to spread from [that little dwelling]2630-that little dwelling , and was so sadly lacking in [her]2619-her own . [Gabriel]144-gabriel appeared in [an upper room]2631-an upper room , placed [his]144-gabriel light in the window - bench , and then - knelt down to pray . The contrast of the picture with [her]2619-her rebellious and agitated existence at this same time was too much for [her]2619-her to bear to look upon longer . It was not for [her]2619-her to make a truce with trouble by any such means . [She]2619-her must tread [her]2619-her giddy distracting measure to its last note , as [she]2619-her had begun it . With a swollen heart [she]2619-her went again up [the lane]3664-the lane , and entered [her]2619-her own door . More fevered now by a reaction from the first feelings which [Oak]144-gabriel 's example had raised in [her]2619-her , [she]2619-her paused in [the hall]4051-the hall , looking at the door of [the room wherein [Fanny]217-fanny lay]2634-the room wherein fanny lay . [She]2619-her locked [her]2619-her fingers , threw back [her]2619-her head , and strained [her]2619-her hot hands rigidly across [her]2619-her forehead , saying , with a hysterical sob , " Would to God [you]217-fanny would speak and tell [me]2619-her [your]217-fanny secret , [Fanny]217-fanny ! . , . O , [I]2619-her hope , hope it is not true that there are two of [you]217-fanny ! ... If [I]2619-her could only look in upon [you]217-fanny for one little minute , [I]2619-her should know all ! "[2619-her] A few moments passed , and [she]2619-her added , slowly , " And [I]2619-her will "[2619-her] [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba in after times could never gauge the mood which carried [her]2619-her through the actions following this murmured resolution on this memorable evening of [her]2619-her life . [She]2619-her went to [the lumber - closet]2635-the lumber - closet for [a screw - driver]2636-a screw - driver . At the end of a short though undefined time [she]2619-her found [herself]2619-her in [the small room]2637-the small room , quivering with emotion , a mist before [her]2619-her eyes , and an excruciating pulsation in [her]2619-her brain , standing beside the uncovered coffin of [the girl whose conjectured end had so entirely engrossed [her]2619-her]2638-the girl whose conjectured end had so entirely engrossed her , and saying to [herself]2619-her in a husky voice as [she]2619-her gazed within - " It was best to know the worst , and [I]2619-her know it now ! "[2619-her] [She]2619-her was conscious of having brought about this situation by a series of actions done as by one in an extravagant dream ; of following that idea as to method , which had burst upon [her]2619-her in [the hall]4051-the hall with glaring obviousness , by gliding to the top of the stairs , assuring [herself]2619-her by listening to the heavy breathing of [[her]2619-her maids]2640-her maids that [they]2640-her maids were asleep , gliding down again , turning the handle of the door within which [the young girl]3829-the young girl lay , and deliberately setting [herself]2619-her to do what , if [she]2619-her had antici- pated any such undertaking at night and alone , would have horrified [her]2619-her , but which , when done , was not so dreadful as was the conclusive proof of [[her]2619-her husband]2239-her husband 's conduct which came with knowing beyond doubt the last chapter of [Fanny]217-fanny 's story . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's head sank upon [her]2619-her bosom , and the breath which had been bated in suspense , curiosity , and interest , was exhaled now in the form of a whispered wail : " Oh - h - h ! "[243-bathsheba] [she]2619-her said , and [the silent room]2643-the silent room added length to [her]2619-her moan . [Her]2619-her tears fell fast beside [the unconscious pair in the coffin]2644-the unconscious pair in the coffin : tears of a complicated origin , of a nature inde- scribable , almost indefinable except as other than those of simple sorrow . Assuredly [their]2644-the unconscious pair in the coffin wonted fires must have lived in [Fanny]217-fanny 's ashes when events were so shaped as to chariot [her]217-fanny hither in this natural , unobtrusive , yet effectual manner . The one feat alone - that of dying - by which a mean condition could be resolved into a grand one , [Fanny]217-fanny had achieved . And to that had destiny subjoined this rencounter to - night , which had , in [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's wild imagining , turned [[her]2619-her companion]3490-her companion 's failure to success , [her]2619-her humiliation to triumph , [her]2619-her luck- lessness to ascendency ; et had thrown over [herself]2619-her a garish light of mockery , and set upon all things about [her]2619-her an ironical smile . [Fanny]217-fanny 's face was framed in by that yellow hair of [hers]2619-her ; and there was no longer much room for doubt as to the origin of the curl owned by [Troy]243-bathsheba . In [Bath-]168-bath- sheba [sheba]243-bathsheba 's heated fancy the innocent white countenance expressed a dim triumphant consciousness of the pain [she]2619-her was retaliating for [her]2619-her pain with all the merciless rigour of the Mosaic law : " Burning for burning ; wound for wound : strife for strife . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba indulged in contemplations of escape from [her]2619-her position by immediate death , which thought [she]2619-her , though it was an inconvenient and awful way , had limits to its inconvenience and awfulness that could not be overpassed ; whilst the shames of life were measureless . Yet even this scheme of extinction by death was out tamely copying [[her]2619-her rival]5465-her rival 's method without the reasons which had glorified it in [[her]2619-her rival]5465-her rival 's case . [She]2619-her glided rapidly up and down [the room]4025-the room , as was mostly [her]2619-her habit hen excited , [her]2619-her hands hanging clasped in front of [her]2619-her , as [she]2619-her thought and in part expressed in broken words : O , [I]243-bathsheba hate [her]2619-her , yet [I]243-bathsheba do n't mean that [I]243-bathsheba hate [her]2619-her , for it is grievous and wicked ; and yet [I]243-bathsheba hate [her]2619-her a little ! yes , [my]243-bathsheba flesh insists upon hating [her]2619-her , whether [my]243-bathsheba spirit is willing or no ! ... If [she]2619-her had only lived , [I]243-bathsheba could ave been angry and cruel towards [her]2619-her with some justifi- cation ; but to be vindictive towards [a poor dead woman]5468-a poor dead woman recoils upon [myself]243-bathsheba . O God , have mercy , ! [I]243-bathsheba am miserable at all this ! "[243-bathsheba] [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba became at this moment so terrified at [her]2646-she own state of mind that [she]2646-she looked around for some sort of refuge from [herself]2646-she . The vision of [Oak]144-gabriel kneeling down that night recurred to [her]2646-she , and with the imitative instinct which animates [women]493-women [she]2646-she seized upon the idea , resolved to kneel , and , if possible , pray . [Gabriel]144-gabriel had prayed ; so would [she]2646-she . [She]2646-she knelt beside the coffin , covered [her]2646-she face with [her]2646-she hands , and for a time [the room]4025-the room was silent as [a tomb]2649-a tomb . whether from a purely mechanical , or from any other cause , when [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba arose it was with a quieted spirit , and a regret for the antagonistic instincts which had seized upon [her]2646-she just before . In [her]2646-she desire to make atonement [she]2646-she took flowers from a vase by the window , and began laying them around [the dead girl]2650-the dead girl 's head . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba knew no other way of showing kindness to [persons departed]2651-persons departed than by giving [them]2651-persons departed flowers . [She]2646-she knew not how long [she]2646-she remained engaged thus . [She]2646-she forgot time , life , where [she]2646-she was , what [she]2646-she was doing . A slamming together of the coach - house doors in [the yard]2175-the yard brought [her]2646-she to [her-]2646-she self again . An instant after , the front door opened and closed , steps crossed [the hall]4051-the hall , and [[her]2646-she husband]2239-her husband appeared at the entrance to [the room]4025-the room , looking in upon [her]2646-she . [He]2239-her husband beheld it all by degrees , stared in stupefaction at the scene , as if [he]2239-her husband thought it an illusion raised by some fiendish incantation . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , pallid as a corpse on end , gazed back at [him]2239-her husband in the same wild way . So little are instinctive guesses the fruit of a legitimate induction , that at this moment , as [he]2239-her husband stood with the door in [his]2239-her husband hand , [Troy]243-bathsheba never once thought of [Fanny]217-fanny in connection with what [he]243-bathsheba saw . [His]243-bathsheba first confused idea was that [somebody in [the house]552-the house]2656-somebody in the house had died . " Well - what ? "[243-bathsheba] said [Troy]243-bathsheba , blankly . " [I]2646-she must go ! [I]2646-she must go ! "[2646-she] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , to [herself]243-bathsheba more than to [him]2239-her husband . [She]2646-she came with a dilated eye towards the door , to push past [him]2239-her husband . " What 's the matter , in [God]171-god 's name ? who 's dead ? "[2646-she] said [Troy]243-bathsheba . " [I]243-bathsheba can not say ; let [me]243-bathsheba go out . [I]243-bathsheba want air ! "[243-bathsheba] [she]2646-she continued . " But no ; stay , [I]243-bathsheba insist ! "[243-bathsheba] [He]2239-her husband seized [her]2646-she hand , and then volition seemed to leave [her]2646-she , and [she]2646-she went off into a state of passivity . [He]2239-her husband , still holding [her]2646-she , came up [the room]4025-the room , and thus , hand in hand , [Troy]243-bathsheba and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba approached the coffin 's side . The candle was standing on a bureau close by [them]2659-them , and the light slanted down , distinctly enkindling the cold features of both [mother and babe]2660-mother and babe . [Troy]243-bathsheba looked in , dropped [[his]243-bathsheba wife]4301-his wife 's hand , knowledge of it all came over [him]243-bathsheba in a lurid sheen , and [he]243-bathsheba stood still . So still [he]243-bathsheba remained that [he]243-bathsheba could be imagined to have left in [him]243-bathsheba no motive power whatever . The clashes of feeling in all directions confounded one another , produced a neutrality , and there was motion in none . " Do [you]243-bathsheba know [her]4301-his wife ? "[243-bathsheba] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , in a small enclosed echo , as from the interior of [a cell]2662-a cell . " [I]243-bathsheba do . "[243-bathsheba] said [Troy]243-bathsheba . " Is it [she]4301-his wife ? "[217-fanny] " It is . "[243-bathsheba] [He]243-bathsheba had originally stood perfectly erect . And now , in the wellnigh congealed immobility of [his]243-bathsheba frame could be discerned an incipient movement , as in the darkest night may be discerned light after a while . [He]243-bathsheba was gradually sinking forwards . The lines of [his]243-bathsheba features softened , and dismay modulated to illimitable sadness . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was regarding [him]243-bathsheba from the other side , still with parted lips and distracted eyes . Capacity for intense feeling is proportionate to the general intensity of the nature , and perhaps in all [Fanny]217-fanny 's sufferings , much greater relatively to [her]217-fanny strength , there never was a time [she]217-fanny suffered in an absolute sense what [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba suffered now . What [Troy]243-bathsheba did was to sink upon [his]243-bathsheba knees with an indefinable union of remorse and reverence upon [his]243-bathsheba face , and , bending over [Fanny Robin]217-fanny , gently kissed [her]217-fanny , as [one]4328-one would kiss [an infant asleep to avoid awakening it]2664-an infant asleep to avoid awakening it . At the sight and sound of that , to [her]217-fanny , unendurable act , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba sprang towards [him]243-bathsheba . All the strong feelings which had been scattered over [her]217-fanny existence since [she]217-fanny knew what feeling was , seemed gathered together into one pulsation now . The revulsion from [her]217-fanny indignant mood a little earlier , when [she]217-fanny had meditated upon compromised honour , forestalment , eclipse in maternity by [another]3843-another , was violent and entire . All that was forgotten in the simple and still strong attachment of [wife]1328-wife to [husband]1327-husband . [She]217-fanny had sighed for [her]217-fanny self - completeness then , and now [she]217-fanny cried aloud against the severance of the union [she]217-fanny had deplored . [She]217-fanny flung [her]217-fanny arms round [Troy]243-bathsheba 's neck , exclaiming wildly from the deepest deep of [her]217-fanny heart - " Do n't - do n't kiss [them]5469-them ! O , [Frank]244-frank , [I]217-fanny ca n't bear it - [i]217-fanny ca n't ! [I]217-fanny love [you]244-frank better than [she]217-fanny did : kiss [me]217-fanny too , [Frank]244-frank - kiss [me]217-fanny ! [You]244-frank will , [Frank]244-frank , kiss [me]217-fanny too ! "[217-fanny] There was something so abnormal and startling in the childlike pain and simplicity of this appeal from [a woman of [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba]4363-a woman of bathsheba 's calibre and independence , that [Troy]243-bathsheba , loosening [her]217-fanny tightly clasped arms from [his]243-bathsheba neck , looked at [her]217-fanny in bewilderment . It was such and unex- pected revelation of [all women]2669-all women being alike at heart , even those so different in [their]2669-all women accessories as [Fanny]217-fanny and [this one beside [him]243-bathsheba]2670-this one beside him , that [Troy]243-bathsheba could hardly seem to believe [her]217-fanny to be [[his]243-bathsheba proud wife [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba]2671-his proud wife bathsheba . [Fanny]217-fanny 's own spirit seemed to be animating [her]217-fanny frame . But this was the mood of a few instants only . When the momentary " [I]243-bathsheba will not kiss [you]217-fanny ! "[243-bathsheba] [he]243-bathsheba said pushing [her]217-fanny away . Had [the wife]4091-the wife now but gone no further . Yet , perhaps . under the harrowing circumstances , to speak out was the one wrong act which can be better under- stood , if not forgiven in [her]217-fanny , than the right and politic one , [[her]217-fanny rival]5465-her rival being now but a corpse . All the feeling [she]217-fanny had been betrayed into showing [she]217-fanny drew back to [herself]217-fanny again by a strenuous effort of self - command . " What have [you]243-bathsheba to say as [your]243-bathsheba reason ? "[243-bathsheba] [she]217-fanny asked [her]217-fanny bitter voice being strangely low - quite that of [another woman]3779-another woman now . " [I]243-bathsheba have to say that [I]243-bathsheba have been [a bad , black - hearted man]5470-a bad , black - hearted man . "[243-bathsheba] [he]243-bathsheba answered . less than [she]4091-the wife . " "[217-fanny] Ah ! do n't taunt [me]0-i , [madam]1568-madam . [This woman]2299-this woman is more to [me]0-i , dead as [she]2299-this woman is , than ever [you]1568-madam were , or are , or can be . If [Satan]337-satan had not tempted [me]0-i with that face of [yours]1568-madam , and [those cursed coquetries]2677-those cursed coquetries , [I]0-i should have [He]243-bathsheba turned to [Fanny]217-fanny then . " But never mind , [darling]5333-darling , [wife]1328-wife ! "[243-bathsheba] At these words there arose from [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's lips a long , low cry of measureless despair and indignation , such a wail of anguish as had never before been heard within those old - inhabited walls . It was the product of [her]217-fanny union with [Troy]243-bathsheba . " If [she]2299-this woman 's - that , - what - am [I]243-bathsheba ? "[243-bathsheba] [she]217-fanny added , as a continuation of the same cry , and sobbing pitifully : and the rarity with [her]217-fanny of such abandonment only made the condition more dire . " [You]243-bathsheba are nothing to [me]2683-a ploughboy - nothing . "[2683-a ploughboy] said [Troy]243-bathsheba , heartlessly . " A ceremony before [a priest]5473-a priest does n't make a marriage . [I]2683-a ploughboy am not morally [yours]243-bathsheba . "[2683-a ploughboy] A vehement impulse to flee from [him]243-bathsheba , to run from [this place]561-this place , hide , and escape [his]243-bathsheba words at any price , not stopping short of death itself , mastered [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba now . [She]217-fanny waited not an instant , but turned to the door and ran out . CHAPTER XLIV UNDER A TREE - REACTION [BATHSHEBA]243-bathsheba went along [the dark road]2679-the dark road , neither know- ing nor caring about the direction or issue of [her]217-fanny flight . The first time that [she]217-fanny definitely noticed [her]217-fanny position was when [she]217-fanny reached a gate leading into a thicket over- hung by some large oak and beech trees . On looking into [the place]3486-the place , it occurred to [her]217-fanny that [she]217-fanny had seen [it]3486-the place by daylight on some previous occasion , and that what appeared like an impassable thicket was in reality a brake of fern now withering fast . [She]217-fanny could think of nothing better to do with [her]217-fanny palpitating self than to go in [here]575-here and hide ; and entering , [she]217-fanny lighted on a spot sheltered from the damp fog by a reclining trunk , where [she]217-fanny sank down upon a tangled couch of fronds and stems . [She]217-fanny mechanically pulled some armfuls round [her]217-fanny to keep off the breezes , and closed [her]217-fanny eyes . Whether [she]217-fanny slept or not that night [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was not clearly aware . But it was with a freshened exist- ence and a cooler brain that , a long time afterwards , [she]217-fanny became conscious of some interesting proceedings which were going on in the trees above [her]217-fanny head and around . A coarse - throated chatter was the first sound . It was a sparrow just waking . Next : " Chee - weeze - weeze - weeze ! "[2683-a ploughboy] from another retreat . It was a finch . Third : " Tink - tink - tink - tink - a - chink ! "[2683-a ploughboy] from the hedge , It was a robin . " [Chuck - chuck - chuck]175-charles ! "[2694-his] overhead . A squirrel . Then , from [the road]477-the road , " With [my]2694-his ra - ta - ta , and [my]2694-his rum - tum - tum ! "[2694-his] It was [a ploughboy]2683-a ploughboy . Presently [he]2683-a ploughboy came opposite , and [she]217-fanny believed from [his]2683-a ploughboy voice that [he]2683-a ploughboy was [one of the boys on [[her]217-fanny own farm]2685-her own farm]2684-one of the boys on her own farm . [He]2683-a ploughboy was followed by a shambling tramp of heavy feet , and looking through the ferns [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba could just discern in the wan light of daybreak [a team of [[her]217-fanny own horses]2687-her own horses]2686-a team of her own horses . [They]2686-a team of her own horses stopped to drink at [a pond on the other side of the way ']2688-a pond on the other side of the way ' . [She]217-fanny watched [them]2686-a team of her own horses flouncing into the pool , drinking , tossing up [their]2686-a team of her own horses heads , drinking again , the water dribbling from [their]2686-a team of her own horses lips in silver threads . There was another flounce , and [they]2686-a team of her own horses came out of [the pond]2689-the pond , and turned back again towards [the farm]3760-the farm . [She]217-fanny looked further around . Day was just dawning , and beside its cool air and colours [her]217-fanny heated actions and resolves of the night stood out in lurid contrast . [She]217-fanny perceived that in [her]217-fanny lap , and clinging to [her]217-fanny hair , were red and yellow leaves which had come down from the tree and settled silently upon [her]217-fanny during [her]217-fanny partial sleep . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba shook [her]217-fanny dress to get rid of them , when multitudes of [the same family]2691-the same family lying round about [her]217-fanny rose and fluttered away in the breeze thus created , like ghosts from an enchanter fleeing . " There was an opening towards [the east]5474-the east , and the glow from the as yet unrisen sun attracted [her]217-fanny eyes thither . From [her]217-fanny feet , and between the beautiful yellowing ferns with their feathery arms , the ground sloped downwards to a hollow , in which was [a species of swamp , dotted with fungi]5475-a species of swamp , dotted with fungi . A morning mist hung over [it]5476-it now - a fulsome yet magnificent silvery veil , full of light from the sun , yet semi - opaque - the hedge behind [it]5476-it being in some measure hidden by its hazy luminousness . Up the sides of this depression grew sheaves of the common rush , and here and there a peculiar species of flag , the blades of which glistened in the emerging sun , like scythes . But the general aspect of [the swamp]5477-the swamp was malignant . From its moist and poisonous coat seemed to be exhaled the essences of evil things in [the earth]1149-the earth , and in the waters under [the earth]1149-the earth . The fungi grew in all manner of positions from rotting leaves and tree stumps , some exhibiting to [her]217-fanny listless gaze [their]5480-their clammy tops , others [their]5480-their oozing gills . Some were marked with great splotches , red as arterial blood , others were saffron yellow , and others tall and attenuated , with stems like macaroni . Some were leathery and of richest browns . [The hollow]5481-the hollow seemed a nursery of pestilences small and great , in the immediate neighbourhood of comfort and health , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba arose with a tremor at the thought of having passed the night on [the brink of so dismal a place]5482-the brink of so dismal a place . "[0-i] There were now other footsteps to be heard along [the road]477-the road . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's nerves were still unstrung : [she]217-fanny crouched down out of sight again , and [the pedes- trian]2693-the pedes- trian came into view . [He]2694-his was [a schoolboy]2695-a schoolboy , with a bag slung over [his]2694-his shoulder containing [his]2694-his dinner , and a hook in [his]2694-his hand . [He]2694-his paused by the gate , and , without looking up , continued murmuring words in tones quite loud enough to reach [her]217-fanny ears . " [O Lord]1079-o lord , [O Lord]1079-o lord , [O Lord]1079-o lord , [O Lord]1079-o lord , [O Lord]1079-o lord "[0-i] : - that [I]0-i know out o ' book . " Give [us]5488-us , give [us]5488-us , give [us]5488-us , give [us]5488-us , give [us]5488-us "[0-i] : - that [I]0-i know . " Grace that , grace that , grace that , grace that "[0-i] : - that [I]0-i know . " Other words followed to the same effect . [The boy]444-the boy was of the dunce class apparently ; the book was [a psalter]5490-a psalter , and this was [his]2694-his way of learning the collect . In the worst attacks of trouble there appears to be always a super- ficial film of consciousness which is left disengaged and open to the notice of trifles , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was faintly amused at [the boy]444-the boy 's method , till [he]2694-his too passed on . By this time stupor had given place to anxiety , and anxiety began to make room for hunger and thirst . A form now appeared upon the rise on the other side of [the swamp]5477-the swamp , half - hidden by the mist , and came towards [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba . [The woman]3527-the woman - for it was [a woman]459-a woman - approached with [her]3527-the woman face askance , as if looking earnestly on all sides of [her]3527-the woman . When [she]3527-the woman got a little further round to the left , and drew nearer , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba could see [the newcomer]5495-the newcomer 's profile against the sunny sky ' , and knew the wavy sweep from forehead to chin , with neither angle nor decisive line anywhere about it , to be the familiar contour of [Liddy Smallbury]191-liddy . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's heart bounded with gratitude in the thought that [she]0-i was not altogether deserted , and [she]0-i jumped up . "[712-ma'am] O , [Liddy]191-liddy ! " [she]0-i said , or attempted to say ; but the words had only been framed by [her]0-i lips ; there came no sound . [She]0-i had lost [her]0-i voice by exposure to the clogged atmosphere all these hours of night . "[712-ma'am] O , [ma'am]712-ma'am ! [I]0-i am so glad [I]0-i have found [you]712-ma'am . " said [the girl]462-the girl , as soon as [she]462-the girl saw [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba . "[0-i] [You]712-ma'am ca n't come across . " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba said in a whisper , which [she]0-i vainly endeavoured to make loud enough to reach [Liddy]191-liddy 's ears . [Liddy]191-liddy , not knowing this , stepped down upon [the swamp]5477-the swamp , saying , as [she]0-i did so , "[712-ma'am] It will bear [me]0-i up , [I]0-i think . " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba never forgot that transient little picture of [Liddy]191-liddy crossing [the swamp]5477-the swamp to [her]0-i there in the morning light . Iridescent bubbles of dank subter- ranean breath rose from the sweating sod beside [the waiting maid]5499-the waiting maid 's feet as [she]0-i trod , hissing as they burst and expanded away to join the vapoury firmament above . [Liddy]191-liddy did not sink , as [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had anticipated . [She]0-i landed safely on the other side , and looked up at the beautiful though pale and weary face of [[her]0-i young mistress]5500-her young mistress . "[243-bathsheba] Poor thing ! " said [Liddy]191-liddy , with tears in [her]191-liddy eyes , Do hearten [yourself]191-liddy up a little , [ma'am]712-ma'am . However did - - "[243-bathsheba] " [I]712-ma'am ca n't speak above a whisper - [my]712-ma'am voice is gone for the present . "[712-ma'am] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , hurriedly . " [I]712-ma'am suppose the damp air from [that hollow]5502-that hollow has taken it away [Liddy]191-liddy , do n't question [me]712-ma'am , mind . Who sent [you]191-liddy - [anybody]3643-anybody ? "[712-ma'am] " [Nobody]439-nobody . [I]243-bathsheba thought , when [I]243-bathsheba found [you]191-liddy were not at [home]556-home , that something cruel had happened . [I]243-bathsheba fancy [I]243-bathsheba heard [his]5506-he voice late last night ; and so , knowing something was wrong - - "[243-bathsheba] " Is [he]5506-he at [home]556-home ? "[712-ma'am] " No ; [he]5506-he left just before [I]712-ma'am came out . "[712-ma'am] " Is [Fanny]217-fanny taken away ? "[191-liddy] " Not yet . [She]217-fanny will soon be - at nine o'clock . "[2697-we] " [we]2697-we wo n't go [home]556-home at present , then . Suppose [we]2697-we walk about in [this wood]2477-this wood ? "[712-ma'am] [Liddy]191-liddy , without exactly understanding everything , or anything , in this episode , assented , and [they]2697-we walked together further among the trees . " But [you]191-liddy had better come in , [ma'am]712-ma'am , and have something to eat . [You]191-liddy will die of a chill ! "[712-ma'am] " [I]191-liddy shall not come indoors yet - perhaps never . "[191-liddy] " Shall [I]243-bathsheba get [you]191-liddy something to eat , and something else to put over [your]191-liddy head besides that little shawl ? "[243-bathsheba] " If [you]191-liddy will , [Liddy]191-liddy . "[3490-her companion] [Liddy]191-liddy vanished , and at the end of twenty minutes returned with a cloak , hat , some slices of bread and butter , a tea - cup , and some hot tea in a little china jug " Is [Fanny]217-fanny gone ? "[191-liddy] said [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba . " No . "[191-liddy] said [[her]191-liddy companion]3490-her companion , pouring out the tea . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba wrapped [herself]243-bathsheba up and ate and drank sparingly . [Her]191-liddy voice was then a little clearer , and trifling colour returned to [her]191-liddy face . " Now [we]2699-we 'll walk about again . "[191-liddy] [she]191-liddy said . [They]2699-we wandered about [the wood]2700-the wood for nearly two hours , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba replying in monosyllables to [Liddy]191-liddy 's prattle , for [her]191-liddy mind ran on one subject , and one only . [She]191-liddy interrupted with - " l wonder if [Fanny]217-fanny is gone by this time ? "[191-liddy] " [I]191-liddy will go and see . "[191-liddy] [She]191-liddy came back with the information that [the men]3799-the men were just taking away the corpse ; that [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba had been inquired for ; that [she]191-liddy had replied to the effect that [[her]191-liddy mistress]4024-her mistress was unwell and could not be seen . " Then [they]3799-the men think [I]191-liddy am in [[my]191-liddy bedroom]5511-my bedroom ? "[191-liddy] " Yes . "[191-liddy] [Liddy]191-liddy then ventured to add : " [You]191-liddy said when [I]366-liddy,-taking first found [you]191-liddy that [you]191-liddy might never go [home]556-home again - [you]191-liddy did n't mean it , [ma'am]712-ma'am ? "[366-liddy,-taking] " No ; [I]366-liddy,-taking 've altered [my]366-liddy,-taking mind . It is [only women with no pride in [them]5514-only women with no pride in them who run away from their husbands who run away from [[their]5514-only women with no pride in them who run away from their husbands husbands]5515-their husbands]5514-only women with no pride in them who run away from their husbands . There is one position worse than that of being found dead in [[[your]191-liddy husband]5516-your husband 's house]5517-your husband 's house from [his]5516-your husband ill usage , and that is , to be found alive through having gone away to [The house of [somebody else]2033-somebody else]5518-the house of somebody else . [I]366-liddy,-taking 've thought of it all this morning , and [I]366-liddy,-taking 've chosen [my]366-liddy,-taking course . [A runaway wife]5520-a runaway wife is an encumbrance to [everybody]954-everybody , a burden to [herself]5520-a runaway wife and a byword - all of which make up a heap of misery greater than any that comes by staying at [home]556-home - though this may include the trifling items of insult , beating , and starvation . [Liddy]191-liddy , if ever [you]191-liddy marry - God forbid that [you]191-liddy ever should ! - [you]191-liddy 'll find [yourself]191-liddy in a fearful situation ; but mind this , do n't [you]191-liddy flinch . Stand [your]191-liddy ground , and be cut to pieces . That 's what [I]366-liddy,-taking 'm going to do . "[366-liddy,-taking] " O , [mistress]996-mistress , do n't talk so ! "[191-liddy] said [Liddy,-taking]366-liddy,-taking [her]366-liddy,-taking hand ; " but [I]366-liddy,-taking knew [you]996-mistress had too much sense to bide away . May [I]366-liddy,-taking ask what dreadful thing it is that has happened between [you]996-mistress and [him]3490-her companion ? "[366-liddy,-taking] " [You]996-mistress may ask ; but [I]366-liddy,-taking may not tell . "[366-liddy,-taking] In about ten minutes [they]2703-they returned to [the house]552-the house by a circuitous route , entering at the rear . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba glided up the back stairs to [a disused attic]2705-a disused attic , and [[her]366-liddy,-taking companion]3490-her companion followed . " [Liddy]191-liddy . "[191-liddy] [she]366-liddy,-taking said , with a lighter heart , for youth and hope had begun to reassert [themselves]2707-themselves ; " [you]191-liddy are to be [[my]191-liddy confidante]5524-my confidante for the present - [somebody]3576-somebody must be - and [I]191-liddy choose [you]191-liddy . Well , [I]191-liddy shall take up [[my]191-liddy abode]5526-my abode here for a while . Will [you]191-liddy get a fire lighted , put down a piece of carpet , and help [me]191-liddy to make [the place]3486-the place comfortable . What shall [I]191-liddy do to pass the heavy time away ? "[191-liddy] " Hemming handkerchiefs is a very good thing . "[366-liddy,-taking] said [Liddy]191-liddy . " O no , no ! [I]366-liddy,-taking hate needlework - [i]366-liddy,-taking always did . "[366-liddy,-taking] " knitting ? "[191-liddy] " And that , too . "[191-liddy] " [You]191-liddy might finish [your]191-liddy sampler . " "[712-ma'am] Samplers are out of date - horribly countrified . No [Liddy]191-liddy , [I]0-i 'll read . Bring up some books - not new ones . [I]0-i have n't heart to read anything new . " "[712-ma'am] Some of [[your]0-i uncle]613-your uncle 's old ones , [ma'am]712-ma'am ? " "[2714-the black man] Yes . Some of those [we]2711-we stowed away in boxes . " A faint gleam of humour passed over [her]0-i face as [she]0-i said : "[191-liddy] Bring [Beaumont]367-beaumont and [Fletcher]368-fletcher 's [Maid]5390-maid 's Tragedy , and [the Mourning Bride]2713-the mourning bride , and let [me]0-i see - Night Thoughts , and the Vanity of Human Wishes . " "[3772-the others] And that story of [the black man]2714-the black man , who murdered [[his]2714-the black man wife]4301-his wife [Desdemona]369-desdemona ? " "[2719-the spectator] But if [the others]3772-the others do - - " "[2720-the base - players] No , [they]3772-the others do n't ; and [I]0-i wo n't read dismal books .
