" All that day [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba and [Liddy]191-liddy lived in [the attic]5531-the attic in a state of barricade ; a precaution which proved to be needless as against [Troy]243-bathsheba , for [he]243-bathsheba did not appear in [the neighbourhood]615-the neighbourhood or trouble [them]5533-them at all . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba sat at the window till sunset , sometimes attempting to read , at other times watching every movement outside without much purpose , and listening without much interest to every sound . The sun went down almost blood - red that night , and a livid cloud received its rays in the east . Up against this dark background the west front of [the church tower]5534-the church tower - the only part of the edifice visible from [the farm - house]2578-the farm - house windows - rose distinct and lustrous , the vane upon the summit bristling with rays . Hereabouts , at six o'clock , [the young men of [the village]3754-the village]5536-the young men of the village gathered , as was [their]5536-the young men of the village custom , for a game of [[Prisoners]5538-prisoners ' base]5539-prisoners ' base . [The spot]3757-the spot had been consecrated to this ancient diversion from time immemorial , the old stocks conveniently forming a base facing the boundary of [the churchyard]3813-the churchyard , in front of which the ground was trodden hard and bare as a pavement by [the players]5542-the players . [She]191-liddy could see the brown and black heads of [the young lads]5543-the young lads darting about right and left , [their]5543-the young lads white shirt - sleeves gleaming in the sun ; whilst occasionally a shout and a peal of hearty laughter varied the stillness of the evening air . [They]5533-them continued playing for a quarter of an hour or so , when the game concluded abruptly , and [the players]5542-the players leapt over the wall and vanished round to the other side behind a yew - tree , which was also half behind a beech , now spreading in one mass of golden foliage , on which the branches traced black lines . "[2721-two men] Why did [the base - players]2720-the base - players finish [their]2720-the base - players game so suddenly ? " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba inquired , the next time that [Liddy]191-liddy entered [the room]4025-the room . "[2722-the lads] [I]0-i think ' twas because [two men]2721-two men came just then from [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge and began putting up grand carved tombstone . " said [Liddy]191-liddy . "[0-i] [The lads]2722-the lads went to see whose it was . " "[0-i] Do [you]0-i know ? " [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba asked . "[2724-i] [I]0-i do n't . " said [Liddy]191-liddy . CHAPTER XLV [TROY]243-bathsheba 'S ROMANTICISM WHEN [[Troy]243-bathsheba 's wife]5443-troy 's wife had left [the house]552-the house at the previous midnight [his]243-bathsheba first act was to cover the dead from sight . This done [he]243-bathsheba ascended the stairs , and throwing [himself]243-bathsheba down upon the bed dressed as [he]243-bathsheba was , [he]243-bathsheba waited miser- ably for the morning . [Fate]371-fate had dealt grimly with [him]243-bathsheba through the last four- and - twenty hours . [His]243-bathsheba day had been spent in a way which varied very materially from [his]243-bathsheba intentions regard- ing it . There is always an inertia to be overcome in striking out a new line of conduct - not more in [our-]5548-our- selves , it seems , than in circumscribing events , which appear as if leagued together to allow no novelties in the way of amelioration . Twenty pounds having been secured from [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba , [he]243-bathsheba had managed to add to the sum every farthing [he]243-bathsheba could muster on [his]243-bathsheba own account , which had been seven pounds ten . With this money , twenty - seven pounds ten in all , [he]243-bathsheba had hastily driven from the gate that morning to keep [his]243-bathsheba appointment with [Fanny Robin]217-fanny . On reaching [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge [he]243-bathsheba left the horse and trap at [an inn]5549-an inn , and at five minutes before ten came back to [the bridge]1424-the bridge at [the lower end of [the town]3722-the town]5551-the lower end of the town , and sat [himself]243-bathsheba upon the parapet . The clocks struck the hour , and no [Fanny]217-fanny appeared . In fact , at that moment [she]217-fanny was being robed in [her]217-fanny grave - clothes by [two attendants at [the Union poorhouse]5554-the union poorhouse]5553-two attendants at the union poorhouse - the first and last tiring - women [the gentle creature]5555-the gentle creature had ever been honoured with . The quarter went , the half hour . A rush of recollection came upon [Troy]243-bathsheba as [he]243-bathsheba waited : this was the second time [she]217-fanny had broken a serious engagement with [him]243-bathsheba In anger [he]243-bathsheba vowed it should be the last , and at eleven o'clock , when [he]243-bathsheba had lingered and watched the stone of [the bridge]1424-the bridge till [he]243-bathsheba knew every lichen upon [their]5553-two attendants at the union poorhouse face and heard the chink of the ripples underneath till [they]5553-two attendants at the union poorhouse oppressed [him]243-bathsheba , [he]243-bathsheba jumped from [his]243-bathsheba seat , went to [the inn]2488-the inn for [his]243-bathsheba gig , and in a bitter mood of indifference con- cerning the past , and recklessness about the future , drove on to [Budmouth]99-budmouth races . [He]243-bathsheba reached the race - course at two o'clock , and re- mained either there or in [the town]3722-the town till nine , But [Fanny]217-fanny 's image , as it had appeared to [him]243-bathsheba in the sombre shadows of that Saturday evening , returned to [his]243-bathsheba mind , backed up by [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's reproaches . [He]243-bathsheba vowed [he]243-bathsheba would not bet , and [he]243-bathsheba kept [his]243-bathsheba vow , for on leaving [the town]3722-the town at nine o'clock in the evening [he]243-bathsheba had diminish [his]243-bathsheba cash only to the extent of a few shillings . [He]243-bathsheba trotted slowly homeward , and it was now that was struck for the first time with a thought that [Fanny]217-fanny had been really prevented by illness from keeping [her]217-fanny promise . This time [she]217-fanny could have made no mistake [He]243-bathsheba regretted that [he]243-bathsheba had not remained in [Casterbridge]22-casterbridge and made inquiries . Reaching [home]556-home [he]243-bathsheba quietly un- harnessed the horse and came indoors , as [we]5561-we have seen , to the fearful shock that awaited [him]243-bathsheba . As soon as it grew light enough to distinguish objects , [Troy]243-bathsheba arose from the coverlet of the bed , and in a mood of absolute indifference to [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's whereabouts , a almost oblivious of [her]217-fanny existence , [he]243-bathsheba stalked [downstairs]1015-downstairs and left [the house]552-the house by the back door . [His]243-bathsheba walk was towards [the churchyard]3813-the churchyard , entering which [he]243-bathsheba searched around till [he]243-bathsheba found [a newly dug unoccupied grave]5565-a newly dug unoccupied grave - [the grave dug the day before for [Fanny]217-fanny]5566-the grave dug the day before for fanny . The position of this having been marked , [he]243-bathsheba hastened on to [Caster- bridge]34-caster- bridge , only pausing whereon [he]243-bathsheba had last seen [Fanny]217-fanny alive . Reaching [the town]3722-the town , [Troy]243-bathsheba descended into [a side street]5568-a side street and entered a pair of gates surmounted by a board bearing the words , "[2724-i] [Lester , stone and marble mason]2723-lester , stone and marble mason . " Within were lying about stones of all sizes and designs , inscribed as being sacred to the memory of [unnamed persons who had not yet died]5569-unnamed persons who had not yet died . [Troy]243-bathsheba was so unlike [himself]243-bathsheba now in look , word , and deed , that the want of likeness was perceptible even to [his]243-bathsheba own consciousness . [His]243-bathsheba method of engaging [himself]243-bathsheba in this business of purchasing [a tomb]2649-a tomb was that of [an absolutely unpractised man]5571-an absolutely unpractised man . [He]243-bathsheba could not bring [him-]243-bathsheba self to consider , calculate , or economize . [He]243-bathsheba waywardly wished for something , and [he]243-bathsheba set about obtaining it like [a child]786-a child in [a nursery]5573-a nursery . ' [I]2724-i want [a good tomb]5574-a good tomb . "[2724-i] [he]2724-i said to [the man who stood in [a little office within [the yard]2175-the yard]2726-a little office within the yard]2725-the man who stood in a little office within the yard . " [I]2724-i want as good a one as [you]2725-the man who stood in a little office within the yard can give [me]2724-i for twenty- seven pounds , "[2724-i] It was all the money [he]2724-i possessed . " That sum to include everything ? "[2724-i] " Everything . Cutting the name , carriage to [Weather-]316-weather- bury , and erection . And [I]2724-i want it now at once . "[2724-i] " [We]5575-we could not get anything special worked this week . "[2724-i] If [you]2725-the man who stood in a little office within the yard would like one of these in stock it could be got ready immediately . " "[2724-i] Very well . " said [Troy]243-bathsheba , impatiently . "[2724-i] Let 's see what [you]2725-the man who stood in a little office within the yard have . " "[0-i] The best [I]0-i have in stock is this one , " said [the stone- cutter]5576-the stone- cutter , going into [a shed]3484-a shed . "[2729-he] Here 's a marble headstone beautifully crocketed , with medallions beneath of typical subjects ; here 's the footstone after the same pattern , and here 's the coping to enclose [the- grave]2728-the- grave . The slabs are the best of their kind , and [I]0-i can warrant them " Well , [I]712-ma'am could add the name , and put it up at [visitor who wore not a shred of mourning]5578-visitor who wore not a shred of mourning . [Troy]243-bathsheba then settled the account and went away . In the afternoon almost done . [He]243-bathsheba waited in [the yard]2175-the yard till [the tomb]5580-the tomb was way to [Weatherbury]196-joseph , giving directions to [the two men]2095-the two men the grave of [the person named in the inscription]5582-the person named in the inscription . bridge . [He]243-bathsheba carried rather a heavy basket upon [his]243-bathsheba occasionally at [bridges]5583-bridges and gates , whereon [he]243-bathsheba deposited returning in the darkness , [the men]3799-the men and the waggon the work was done , and , on being assured that it was , [Troy]243-bathsheba entered [[Weatherbury]196-joseph churchyard]5585-weatherbury churchyard about ten had marked [the vacant grave]5586-the vacant grave early in the morning . [It]5586-the vacant grave extent from the view of passers along [the road]477-the road - a spot and bushes of alder , but now [it]5586-the vacant grave was cleared and made the ground elsewhere . Here now stood [the tomb]5580-the tomb as [the men]3799-the men had stated , snow- white and shapely in the gloom , consisting of head and foot - stone , and enclosing border of marble - work uniting [them]2095-the two men . In the midst was mould , suitable for plants . [Troy]243-bathsheba deposited [his]243-bathsheba basket beside [the tomb]5580-the tomb , and vanished for a few minutes . When [he]243-bathsheba returned [he]243-bathsheba carried a spade and a lantern , the light of which [he]243-bathsheba directed for a few moments upon the marble , whilst [he]243-bathsheba read the inscription . [He]243-bathsheba hung [his]243-bathsheba lantern on the lowest bough of the yew - tree , and took from [his]243-bathsheba basket flower- roots of several varieties . There were bundles of snow- drop , hyacinth and crocus bulbs , violets and double daisies , which were to bloom in early spring , and of carnations , pinks , picotees , lilies of [the valley]4550-the valley , forget - me- not , summer's - farewell , [meadow - saffron]5592-meadow - saffron and others , for the later seasons of the year . [Troy]243-bathsheba laid these out upon the grass , and with an im- passive face set to work to plant them . The snowdrops were arranged in a line on the outside of the coping , the remainder within the enclosure of [the grave]4208-the grave . The crocuses and hyacinths were to grow in rows ; some of the summer flowers [he]243-bathsheba placed over [her]4208-the grave head and feet , the lilies and forget - [me]712-ma'am - nots over [her]4208-the grave heart . The remainder were dispersed in the spaces between these . [Troy]243-bathsheba , in [his]243-bathsheba prostration at this time , had no percep- tion that in the futility of these romantic doings , dictated by a remorseful reaction from previous indifference , there was any element of absurdity . Deriving [his]243-bathsheba idiosyn- crasies from both sides of the Channel , [he]243-bathsheba showed at such junctures as the present the inelasticity of [the Englishman]372-the englishman , together with that blindness to the line where sentiment verges on mawkishness , characteristic of [the French]373-the french . lt was a cloudy , muggy , and very dark night , and the rays from [Troy]243-bathsheba 's lantern spread into the two old yews with a strange illuminating power , flickering , as it seemed , up to the black ceiling of cloud above . [He]243-bathsheba felt a large drop of rain upon the back of [his]243-bathsheba hand , and presently one came and entered one of the holes of the lantern , whereupon the candle sputtered and went out- [Troy]243-bathsheba was weary and it being now not far from midnight , and the rain threatening to increase , [he]243-bathsheba resolved to leave the finishing touches of [his]243-bathsheba labour until the day should break . [He]243-bathsheba groped along the wall and over the graves in the dark till [he]243-bathsheba found [himself]243-bathsheba round at [the north side]5594-the north side . Here [he]243-bathsheba entered [the porch]4287-the porch , and , reclining upon the bench within , fell asleep . CHAPTER XLVI THE GURGOYLE : [ITS]5596-its DOINGS [THE tower of [Weatherbury Church]113-weatherbury church]5597-the tower of weatherbury church was a square erection of fourteenth - century date , having two stone gurgoyles on each of the four faces of [its]5597-the tower of weatherbury church parapet . Of these eight carved protuberances only two at this time continued to serve the purpose of [their]5597-the tower of weatherbury church erection - that of spouting the water from the lead roof within . One mouth in each front had been closed by [bygone church- wardens]5598-bygone church- wardens as superfluous , and two others were broken away and choked - a matter not of much consequence to the wellbeing of [the tower]4309-the tower , for the two mouths which still remained open and active were gaping enough to do all the work . It has been sometimes argued that there is no truer criterion of the vitality of any given art - period than the power of [the master - spirits of that time]5600-the master - spirits of that time in grotesque ; and certainly in the instance of Gothic art there is no disputing the proposition . [Weatherbury tower]5601-weatherbury tower was a somewhat early instance of the use of an ornamental parapet in [parish]5397-parish as distinct from [cathedral churches]5603-cathedral churches , and the gurgoyles , which are the necessary correlatives of a parapet , were exceptionally prominent - of the boldest cut that the hand could shape , and of the most original design that [a human brain]5604-a human brain could conceive . There was , so to speak , that symmetry in their distortion which is less the characteristic of [British]374-british than of Continental grotesques of the period . All the eight were different from each other . [A beholder]3538-a beholder was con- vinced that nothing on [earth]499-earth could be more hideous than those [he]3538-a beholder saw on the north side until [he]3538-a beholder went round to the south . Of the two on this latter face , only that at the south - eastern corner concerns the story . It was too human to be called like a dragon , too impish to be like [a man]3474-a man , too animal to be like [a fiend]2186-a fiend , and not enough like a bird to be called a griffin . This horrible stone entity was fashioned as if covered with a wrinkled hide ; it had short , erect ears , eyes starting from their sockets , and its fingers and hands were seizing the corners of [its]5597-the tower of weatherbury church mouth , which they thus seemed to pull open to give free passage to the water it vomited . The lower row of teeth was quite washed away , though the upper still remained . Here and thus , jutting a couple of feet from the wall against which its feet rested as a support , the creature had for four hundred years laughed at [the surrounding landscape]5609-the surrounding landscape , voicelessly in dry weather , and in wet with a gurgling and snorting sound . [Troy]243-bathsheba slept on in [the porch]4287-the porch , and the rain increased outside . Presently [the gurgoyle]5611-the gurgoyle spat . In due time a small stream began to trickle through the seventy feet of aerial space between its mouth and the ground , which the water - drops smote like duckshot in their accelerated velocity . [The stream]668-the stream thickened in substance , and in- creased in power , gradually spouting further and yet further from the side of [the tower]4309-the tower . When the rain fell in a steady and ceaseless torrent the stream dashed downward in volumes . [We]5614-we follow its course to [the ground]4422-the ground at this point of time . The end of the liquid parabola has come forward from the wall , has advanced over the plinth mouldings , over a heap of stones , over the marble border , into the midst of [[Fanny Robin]217-fanny 's grave]5616-fanny robin 's grave . The force of the stream had , until very lately , been received upon some loose stones spread thereabout , which had acted as a shield to the soil under the onset . These during the summer had been cleared from the ground , and there was now nothing to resist the down- fall but the bare earth . For several years the stream had not spouted so far from [the tower]4309-the tower as it was doing on this night , and such a contingency had been over- looked . Sometimes this obscure corner received [no inhabitant]5618-no inhabitant for the space of two or three years , and then it was usually but [a pauper]5619-a pauper , [a poacher]5620-a poacher , or [other sinner of undignified sins]5621-other sinner of undignified sins . The persistent torrent from the gurgoyle 's jaws directed all its vengeance into [the grave]4208-the grave . The rich tawny mould was stirred into motion , and boiled like chocolate . The water accumulated and washed deeper down , and the roar of [the pool]3691-the pool thus formed spread into the night as the head and chief among other noises of the kind created by the deluging rain . The flowers so carefully planted by [[Fanny]217-fanny 's repentant lover]5624-fanny 's repentant lover began to move and writhe in [their]5625-their bed . The winter - violets turned slowly upside down , and became a mere mat of mud . Soon the snowdrop and other bulbs danced in the boiling mass like ingredients in a cauldron . Plants of the tufted species were loosened , rose to the surface , and floated of . [Troy]243-bathsheba did not awake from [his]243-bathsheba comfortless sleep till it was broad day . Not having been in bed for two nights [his]243-bathsheba shoulders felt stiff [his]243-bathsheba feet tender , and [his]243-bathsheba head heavy . [He]243-bathsheba remembered [his]243-bathsheba position , arose , shivered , took the spade , and again went out . The rain had quite ceased , and the sun was shining through the green , brown , and yellow leaves , now sparkling and varnished by the raindrops to the bright- ness of similar effects in the landscapes of [Ruysdael]114-ruysdael and [Hobbema]115-hobbema , and full of all those infinite beauties that arise from the union of water and colour with high lights . The air was rendered so transparent by the heavy fall of rain that the autumn hues of the middle distance were as rich as those near at hand , and the remote fields intercepted by the angle of the tower ap- peared in the same plane as [the tower]4309-the tower itself . [He]243-bathsheba entered [the gravel path which would take [him]243-bathsheba behind [the tower]4309-the tower]5627-the gravel path which would take him behind the tower . [The path]3518-the path , instead of being stony as [it]3518-the path had been the night before , was browned over with a thin coating of mud . At one place in [the path]3518-the path [he]243-bathsheba saw a tuft of stringy roots washed white and clean as a bundle of tendons . [He]243-bathsheba picked it up - surely it could not be one of the primroses [he]243-bathsheba had planted ? [He]243-bathsheba saw a bulb , another , and another as [he]243-bathsheba advanced . Beyond doubt they were the crocuses . With a face of perplexed dismay [Troy]243-bathsheba turned the corner and then beheld the wreck [the stream]668-the stream had made . [The pool upon [the grave]4208-the grave]5632-the pool upon the grave had soaked away into the ground , and in [its]5632-the pool upon the grave place was [a hollow]5634-a hollow . [The disturbed earth]5635-the disturbed earth was washed over the grass and pathway in the guise of the brown mud [he]243-bathsheba had already seen , and it spotted the marble tombstone with the same stains . Nearly all the flowers were washed clean out of the ground , and they lay , roots upwards , on the spots whither they had been splashed by [the stream]668-the stream . [Troy]243-bathsheba 's brow became heavily contracted . [He]243-bathsheba set [his]243-bathsheba teeth closely , and [his]243-bathsheba compressed lips moved as those of [one in great pain]5637-one in great pain . This singular accident , by a strange confluence of emotions in [him]243-bathsheba , was felt as the sharpest sting of all . [Troy]243-bathsheba 's face was very expressive , and [any observer who had seen [him]243-bathsheba]5638-any observer who had seen him now would hardly have believed [him]243-bathsheba to be [a man who had laughed , and sung , and poured love - trifles into a woman]5639-a man who had laughed , and sung , and poured love - trifles into a woman 's ear . To curse [his]243-bathsheba miserable lot was at first [his]243-bathsheba impulse , but even that lowest stage of rebellion needed an activity whose absence was necessarily antecedent to the existence of the morbid misery which wrung [him]243-bathsheba . The sight , coming as it did , superimposed upon the other dark scenery of the previous days , formed a sort of climax to the whole panorama , and it was more than [he]243-bathsheba could endure . Sanguine by nature , [Troy]243-bathsheba had a power of eluding grief by simply adjourning it . [He]243-bathsheba could put off the consideration of any particular spectre till the matter had become old and softened by time . The planting of flowers on [[Fanny]217-fanny 's grave]5640-fanny 's grave had been perhaps but a species of elusion of the primary grief , and now it was as if [his]243-bathsheba intention had been known and circumvented . Almost for the first time in [his]243-bathsheba life , [Troy]243-bathsheba , as [he]243-bathsheba stood by [this dismantled grave]5641-this dismantled grave , wished [himself]243-bathsheba [another man]4200-another man . lt is seldom that [a person with much animal spirit]5643-a person with much animal spirit does not feel that the fact of [his]5643-a person with much animal spirit life being [his]5643-a person with much animal spirit own is the one qualification which singles it out as a more hopeful life than that of [others who may actually resemble [him]5643-a person with much animal spirit in every particular]5644-others who may actually resemble him in every particular . [Troy]243-bathsheba had felt , in [his]243-bathsheba transient way , hundreds of times , that [he]243-bathsheba could not envy [other people]583-other people [their]583-other people condition , because the possession of that condition would have necessitated a different personality , when [he]243-bathsheba desired no other than [his]243-bathsheba own . [He]243-bathsheba had not minded the peculiarities of [his]243-bathsheba birth , the vicissitudes of [his]243-bathsheba life , the meteorlike uncertainty of all that related to [him]243-bathsheba , because these appertained to [the hero]5646-the hero of [his]243-bathsheba story , without [whom there would have been no story at all]5647-whom there would have been no story at all for [him]243-bathsheba ; and it seemed to be only in the nature of things that matters would right themselves at some proper date and wind up well . This very morning the illusion completed its disappearance , and , as it were , all of a sudden , [Troy]243-bathsheba hated [himself]243-bathsheba . The suddenness was probably more apparent than real . [A coral reef which just comes short of [the ocean surface]5649-the ocean surface]5648-a coral reef which just comes short of the ocean surface is no more to the horizon than if it had never been begun , and the mere finishing stroke is what often appears to create an event which has long been potentially an accomplished thing . [He]243-bathsheba stood and mediated - [a miserable man]5650-a miserable man . Whither should [he]243-bathsheba go ? "[712-ma'am] [He]2729-he that is accursed , let [him]2729-he be accursed still . " was the pitiless anathema written in this spoliated effort of [his]243-bathsheba new - born solicitousness . [A man who has spent [his]5651-a man who has spent his primal strength in journeying in one direction has not much spirit left for reversing his course primal strength in journeying in one direction has not much spirit left for reversing [his]5651-a man who has spent his primal strength in journeying in one direction has not much spirit left for reversing his course course]5651-a man who has spent his primal strength in journeying in one direction has not much spirit left for reversing his course . [Troy]243-bathsheba had , since yesterday , faintly reversed [his]243-bathsheba ; but the merest opposition had disheartened [him]243-bathsheba . To turn about would have been hard enough under the greatest providential encouragement ; but to find that [Providence]359-providence , far from helping [him]243-bathsheba into a new course , or showing any wish that [he]243-bathsheba might adopt one , actually jeered [his]243-bathsheba first trembling and critical attempt in that kind , was more than nature could bear . [He]243-bathsheba slowly withdrew from [the grave]4208-the grave . [He]243-bathsheba did not attempt to fill up the hole , replace the flowers , or do anything at all . [He]243-bathsheba simply threw up [his]243-bathsheba cards and forswore [his]243-bathsheba game for that time and always . Going out of [the churchyard]3813-the churchyard silently and unobserved - [none of [the villagers]749-the villagers]5654-none of the villagers having yet risen - [he]243-bathsheba passed down some fields at the back , and emerged just as secretly upon [the high road]5656-the high road . Shortly afterwards [he]243-bathsheba had gone from [the village]3754-the village . Meanwhile , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba remained [a voluntary prisoner]5658-a voluntary prisoner in [the attic]5531-the attic . The door was kept locked , except during the entries and exits of [Liddy]191-liddy , for whom a bed had been arranged in [a small adjoining room]5660-a small adjoining room . The light of [Troy]243-bathsheba 's lantern in [the churchyard]3813-the churchyard was noticed about ten o'clock by [the maid - servant]5662-the maid - servant , who casually glanced from the window in that direction whilst taking [her]5662-the maid - servant supper , and [she]5662-the maid - servant called [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba 's attention to it . [They]5663-they looked curiously at the phenomenon for a time , until [Liddy]191-liddy was sent to bed . [bathsheba]243-bathsheba did not sleep very heavily that night . When [[her]5662-the maid - servant attendant]5664-her attendant was unconscious and softly breath- ing in [the next room]5665-the next room , [the mistress of [the house]552-the house]5666-the mistress of the house was still looking out of the window at the faint gleam spreading from among the trees - not in a steady shine , but blinking like a revolving coastlight , though this appearance failed to suggest to [her]5662-the maid - servant that [a person]4741-a person was passing and repassing in front of [it]552-the house . [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba sat here till it began to rain , and the light vanished , when [she]5662-the maid - servant withdrew to lie restlessly in [her]5662-the maid - servant bed and re - enact in a worn mind the lurid scene of yesternight . Almost before the first faint sign of dawn appeared [she]5662-the maid - servant arose again , and opened the window to obtain a full breathing of the new morning air , the panes being now wet with trembling tears left by the night rain , each one rounded with a pale lustre caught from primrose- hued slashes through a cloud low down in the awaken- ing sky . From the trees came the sound of steady dripping upon the drifted leaves under them , and from the direction of [the church]489-the church [she]5662-the maid - servant could hear another noise - peculiar , and not intermittent like the rest , the purl of water falling into a pool . [Liddy]191-liddy knocked at eight o'clock , and [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba un- locked the door . "[712-ma'am] What a heavy rain [we]2730-we 've had in the night , [ma'am]712-ma'am ! "[0-i] [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba was momentarily relieved of that wayward heaviness of the past twenty - four hours which had quenched the vitality of youth in [her]0-i without sub- stituting the philosophy of maturer years , and the resolved to go out and walk a little way . "[692-the speaker] which was invisible from [the road]477-the road , it was impossible to resist the impulse to enter and look upon a spot which , from nameless feelings , [she]0-i at the same time dreaded to see . "[2851-the the person] [Oak]144-gabriel saw [her]0-i , and [his]144-gabriel first act was to gaze inquiringly and learn how [she]0-i received this knowledge of the authorship of the work , which to [himself]144-gabriel had caused considerable astonishment . Emotional convulsions seemed to have become the commonplaces of [her]0-i history , and [she]0-i bade [him]144-gabriel good morning , and asked [him]144-gabriel to fill in the hole with the spade which was standing by . Whilst [Oak]144-gabriel was doing as [she]0-i desired , [Bathsheba]243-bathsheba collected the flowers , and began planting them with that sympathetic manipulation of roots and leaves which is so conspicuous in [a woman]459-a woman 's gardening , and which flowers seem to understand and thrive upon .
